talk.start.para: âI think the basis of today's matter of public importance was given in the first and opening remarks by the Leader of the Opposition at the National Press Club on Tuesday this week, when he said that it had been a pretty tough year. He said, `It has been a pretty tough year for me'âthe Leader of the Oppositionâand then almost as an afterthought, `It has been a pretty tough year for the nation.'

speech.para: Australia in the year 2002 is a country that is changing, and changing very quickly. As a nation we crossed the threshold from the 20th to the 21st century. This year, in support of all Australians and in particular Australian families, this government has implemented carefully developed policies that will take Australia into the future, at least for the next quarter of a century. This year, amongst many other things, the government has been able to ensure that Australia's economy continues to grow. The fundamental purpose of that, of course, is to create employment. Unemployment, or not having a job, is the single biggest lifetime cause of poverty. The government has also moved to bring all the states and territories together to remove hand guns from our community. The Howard government has moved, as we have heard today from the Prime Minister, to give not only humane and caring support to the farmers and the communities in drought-stricken Australia but also in excess of $1 billion in support, which is some 20 times the level of support given by state and territory governments.

This government continues to very much support the choices that are made by Australians, whether they are in health care or indeed in education. The government has also worked assiduously, opposed by the Labor Party at almost every turn, to protect Australia's borders. It wants to make sure that the people who come to this country are people who are eligible to be here, as determined under the laws which the Australian government believes are the appropriate ones for immigration. The Labor Party, under its previous leader and, I suspect, its future leaderâthat is my prediction for 2003; I think the past will be coming back to the futureâthe member for Brand, was divided on whether Australia should take a strong stand in support of Australia's interests in determining who should come to this country. Only this week we had the Australian Labor Party say that it would not support the government in excising from our migration zone those islands that make it easier for people smugglers, already exploiting an overexploited group, to find illegal passage to Australia. So the Australian Labor Party will now go out to Australian families and say, `Yes, we support border protection; we support the government in all of this,' but then come in here and vote against measures that will assist the security of Australia and its families.

The other important event this year was of course the tragedy in Bali, where not only Australians and Indonesians but human beings from many other parts of the world were injured and killed. This government providedâand I think in this regard we were supported by the Leader of the Oppositionâleadership in effectively and very swiftly responding to the events in Bali and working cooperatively with the Indonesian government. We saw this in the Prime Minister especially. The Prime Minister has also shown his humanity and the strength of his leadership to the families affected and to those of us in Australia who feel a deep sense of insecurity about some of the changes that are happening in our world.

The best way to protect the interests of Australian families and to protect the nation, from its borders through to its economy, is to make sure that Australia's economic growth continues. The Labor Party's idea of protecting Australian families was to give Australia the recession that apparently we had to have. Thanks to the Howard government's reforms, the Treasurer has firewalled Australia against the Asian economic meltdown. But Labor is still damaging the interests of Australian families. It is interesting that, in the last five years in office, the Labor Party delivered five consecutive budgets that were more than $10 billion in deficit and ran up almost $80 billion in additional government debt.

In contrast, the coalition government has reintroduced responsible fiscal management. In fact, by 30 June 2002 this government had repaid more than $60 billion in debt that had been racked up by the Australian Labor Party. That means that Australian families now have a government which has more resources available to it to, among other things, secure us from the threats of terrorism and make sure that our borders are very sound. In fact, this program of debt repayment is now saving the Commonwealth governmentâthat is, the Australian taxpayerâaround $5 billion every year in interest costs. That money can now be dedicated to very vital areas of expenditure, such as health, education and transport.

It is also worth remembering that in this country todayâand there are Australians who may have some difficulty comprehending some of these figuresâour unemployment rate is 6.1 per cent. A decade ago, Australia's unemployment rate was 11 per cent. Under the Australian Labor Party, more than one million Australians did not have a job. They lost their homes and their businesses. In many families, the marriages and personal relationships were destroyed. The then Labor Prime Minister, Paul Keating, said: `What are you complaining about? This is as good as it gets.' At the same time, Australian familiesâwho today are experiencing home mortgage interest rates of between five and 6Â½ per centâwere paying an interest rate on their mortgages of 17Â½ per cent. This government has just offered interest rate subsidies to small businesses and farmers who are affected by the drought. But just 10 years ago small businesses were paying a 22Â½ per cent interest rate on their overdrafts. It was absolutely disgraceful.

One of the things that has happened to protect Australian families is that the Deputy Leader of the Australian Labor Party, the member for Jagajaga, has chosen not to take an economic portfolio and is instead the shadow minister for education, science and training. I think that is something for which we all ought to be grateful. One of the problems that Australian families have at the moment is that they do not quite know what the Australian Labor Party really stands for. You might remember that the member for Rankin decided he would get a name for himself by personally attacking the Prime Minister; a Prime Minister who is highly respected in this country and beyond. On 8 November this year, he said:

quote.para: We owe it to our supporters to be frank.

speech.para: He then went on to say:

quote.para: Too often Labor statements are heavily qualified, such that the message is lost and the electorate is left wondering what we stand for.

speech.para: I think the member for Jagajaga is probably the person who, amongst others, was on the mind of the member for Rankin when he made those remarks. Alan Wood, who writes for the Australian, summarised it very well on 29 October when he said:

quote.para: ... Labor has to say clearly what it stands for. It seems chronically unable to decide just what it is. Unlike Whitlam, Crean has no vision ...

speech.para: On the Labor policy review, Wood went on to say:

quote.para: ... there are those on Labor's frontbench who have serious doubts. One reason for such doubts is that the policy review is led by Labor's deputy leader, Jenny Macklin, whose inclinations are soft-Left and populist.

speech.para: I think the member for Rankin has got it right.

If honourable members are wondering why the Labor Party, a year after the election, still has no clearly defined policiesâin-cluding for familiesâI can give them an insight. The Deputy Leader of the Australian Labor Party, who is responsible for developing policy, has made all sorts of commitmentsâfor example, some $1.2 billion for Australian higher education. This is what the member for Rankin is contending with and the problem the Labor Party has. I chanced upon a document, which I read, entitled the Labour Resourcer. The edition I have is volume 3, number 2, April 1983. This publication was intended for families, I suspect, and was edited by none other than the member for Jagajaga. One of the advantages of being the editor of a newspaper is that you can decide what you publish. I will read from a section of the publication. Under the headline `Prospects for socialist change' is the text of a speech given by Jenny Macklin to the Marx Centenary Conference held on 16 and 17 April. Keep in mind that this person is the Deputy Leader of the Australian Labor Party and, if there were to be a change of government, she would be the deputy leader of the government. She said:

quote.para: What does the dismantling of capitalism and the building of socialism involve? It is all too clear that spontaneous uprising is not around the corner. Planned insurrection is also only a dream in some people's heads ...

speech.para: She goes on to say:

quote.para: We are talking about transformation of people's capacities and through that, and at a similar pace, the economic institutions of capital.

speech.para: Australian families have every reason to look at the Australian Labor Party with some trepidation, because they are fearful of people with those views getting anywhere near the Treasury portfolio. Of course, that is why the member for Jagajaga is in the shadow portfolio of education, science and training.

One of the things we need to examine, amongst many others, is health care. We have heard a lot from the Labor Party about people getting access to health care and choice. It ought to be understood that Australians strongly believe, as does this government, that every Australian should make a contribution to the financing of health care and Medicare through their taxes. But, having done so, if they then choose to go into a private hospital for treatment, and choose not take up a place in the public hospital system, they ought to be supported by the government, both morally and financially, in making that choice. This government has supported Australian families by offering a 30 per cent rebate. In other words, the government pays 30 per cent of the cost of their private health insurance, which means that families save anywhere between $600 and $1,200 on their private health insurance. The Labor Party, in saying that it is going to remove this private health insurance support, does not understand that one million families in this country who earn less than $20,000 a yearâthat is, $53 a dayâhave private health insurance. The Labor Party is criticising this government's policy on families. Worse still, it wants to take that support away from families. As Ethel Guyâa great woman who has led the representation of pensioners in Tasmaniaâonce said to me, `A lot of my members'âthat is, poor Australiansâ`go without food to pay their private health insurance.' The Labor Party wants to take that support away from them.

On 11 September, at the Australian National University, in response to a question about how she was going to fund the grandiose promises that she has made to universities, the member for Jagajaga said, `You can reorder your priorities.' She said this government has been giving too much money to non-government schools. One in five families that earn less than $73 a day have their kids in Catholic and independent schools. The Labor Party wants to say you cannot choose the kind of school that you want for your child, and the Labor Party does not want to support you. I say to the Labor Party, as Albert Einstein once said: `I now know why people like to chop woodâbecause it is so easy to understand the outcome.' The Labor Party does not get the fact that Australian families need support in education and in making a choice. They need support in making choices in health care. They want secure borders. They want Australia to be led by a statesman, not by somebody running around in somebody's rubbish. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI find it very strange that the only person the government could put up to talk about its failure to protect and prioritise the interests of Australian families as a matter of public importance is the now Minister for Education, Science and Training, who had the audacity to say recently that our kids are not biologically up to obtaining a full and right education. The minister wants to go back to 1983. I too have been around a long time and, if I had time in this debate, I could tell the minister what he was doing 20 years ago, line by line and clause by clause. But it might embarrass him too much and I will not do that.

speech.para: I rise with pleasure to support the Leader of the Opposition's motion regarding this government's failure to protect and prioritise the interests of Australian families. In this House we constantly hear rhetoric from the Prime Minister about how his government is family friendly. However, the facts show the true picture. This government is anything but family friendly. It provides constant smokescreens to cover its regressive economic and social policies.

Firstly, let us look at the issue of paid maternity leave. What is the only party that is committed to implementing a policy that will assist working mothers? It is the Labor Party. The Labor Party supports paid maternity leave. The Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Pru Goward, has said that it is quite within the government's abilities to provide a form of maternity leave. Might I add that the government is one of only two OECD countries that do not have some form of paid maternity leave. There is no prize for guessing what the other country is. Yes, let us tug our forelock: it is the United Statesâthe government that refuses to sign the ILO's revised Maternity Protection Convention, which calls for a minimum of 14 weeks paid maternity leave. It is quite apparent on this issue that the government would rather pander to the business sector than even contemplate what reforms are required to allow a woman to work and have a family.

What about child care? I have heard outrageous stories that people now have to fork out $15,000 a year to have their child cared for. How does a normal family afford that? That is nearly half the median wage, yet we had the minister for education telling us what people earn and how they manage. With mortgages hanging over their heads and the increasing costs of feeding, clothing and keeping their children healthy, it is a deplorable situation. Does the government care? Of course it does not. It constantly says it does; it keeps telling us it does. It boasts about its baby bonus, but who does that benefit? A parent who earns over $55,000 in the year prior to the birth of their first child receives an annual refund of $2,500 if they choose to stay at home, while a parent in my electorate who earns $10,000 a year gets $500 if they choose to stay home. Today, in this House, the Treasurer reminded the member for Dunkley to go home and start having a family so that he can get the family bonus and the government can implement its policy. What a disgrace! How pathetic is that? This government lives in a dream world. How is it going to entice women to stay at home? They cannot afford to. This government has put up a pathetic bribe, an absurd piece of rhetoric that is picked up by its shock jock mates in the media and trumpeted as another example of our Prime Minister's commitment to families. But that is what this government is about: propaganda and rhetoricâanything to hide the truth behind its smokescreens.

This government have paid lip-service to looking after workers' entitlements. Unless you worked for the Prime Minister's brother or for Ansett, you got sod all. The Auditor-General's report into the government's employee entitlements scheme shows not only that the government have no commitment to workers but that they are hopelessly incompetentâand they are the Auditor-General's words, not mine. The truth of the matter is that the government set up this scheme to attempt to quell public anger following the National Textiles fiasco. It was never a genuine attempt to protect entitlements. They have absolutely no commitment to this area. If they did, they would have supported the Labor Party's private member's bill protecting 100 per cent of workers' entitlements.

We see in this place, year after year, the government putting forward a range of workplace relations bills that are focused on reinstating the old master-servant relationship. That is their real commitment to the workers and their families of this nation. Since the Howard government came into office, the casualisation of our work force has increased at a rapid rate, as has the amount of part--time work. Again, how are families supposed to survive in a climate in which they do not know if they will be working next week?

Added to this are the recent comments by the Prime Minister suggesting that people should consider working longer. This is a comment from a person who really is out of touch with reality. With constant economic change, people in their middle age are frequently being forced out of their jobs and forced onto Newstart. These are the people who have been hardworking members of our communities for 30 or so years, and they are forced into unemployment. Many of these people lack the skills that are required in the new economy. Without the retraining that we provided through Working Nation, these people are suffering economic and emotional hardships. They are forced to trudge around the streets with a diary, attempting to find a job when they know few employers are even willing to employ them. The Prime Minister says they should work longer. How can they? These people still have family commitments and bills to pay, and they have been used to a steady flow of income, and suddenly and ruthlessly they are forced onto the economic scrap heap. What does the government do? I will tell you what it does: nothing. `That is their problem,' according to the government. `They should be able to retrain.' On what program? This shows how much the government cares.

The government talks about security. I will tell the Prime Minister what security is all about in this country: it is knowing where that next meal is coming from, it is knowing that you can pay your bills, it is knowing that you have got a roof over your kids' head and that you are going to keep it there. That is security to the families of this nation. We want to be able to protect our kids when they are sick. Yet the Prime Minister, in his former guise as opposition leader, constantly espoused destroying Medicare. He knows he cannot do it, but he will do his best to rip the guts out of it. Bulk-billing has been in constant decline under this government, and in some areasâas our leader has stated in the debate today before the Houseâtrying to find a bulk-billing doctor in some areas is like trying to look for hen's teeth.

They think that reforming the PBS is done by getting the poor to pay an extra 30 per cent for their medicines instead of getting down to the hard task of reforming the system, which would mean reforming the way their pharmaceutical industry mates do things. The former minister, Michael Wooldridge, was quite willing to put his pharmaceutical industry mates on the PBAC, but they just ignore the consumers and the health care associations. So to prop up these huge multinational companies' profits, this government are willing to compromise the provision of essential medical services. Reform means having intellectual nous and embracing the concerns of all those who are involved in the community, not continuing to pander to sectional interests. That is what this government are about. They pander to their donors and their friends that provide them with the money and the propaganda facilities to con the electorateâand they are the ones looking after them.

The other disgusting thing about this government is that they have their snouts in the trough. The former member for Flinders was quite willing to use taxpayers' money to fund his family's international telephone bills. I would not think Mr Reith was living on the edge of the poverty line. Can you imagine any of that frontbench ever struggling to survive? They would not know how to. Mr Reith is indicative of this born-to-rule mob: they think that it is their right to be on the Treasury benches. There are a number of former ministers who have thought that fleecing the taxpayer for their own personal gain is the way to go. John Sharp, Jim Short, Michael Wooldridge and Reith, along with Warwick Parer, think it is okay to go to work in the same industry straight after they have left office. They do not believe that they have a conflict of interest; the Prime Minister says they do not.

The Reith situation regarding Tenix is an example of the arrogance of these people on the government benches. They truly believe they can get away with it. How can anyone truly believe that a minister for defence can announce his retirement, take up a consultancy in the defence industry and end a tender process for the DIDS, when six months later the company that he joins wins the new tender? Don't you think we should be suspicious, especially with a person who has the very dubious track record that he has? Why doesn't the Prime Minister share the view of the Australian people that it is inappropriate for a minister to have knowledge of and participate in contrived living arrangements which minimise tax, to exercise ministerial authority to benefit the business affairs of his or her immediate family, to misuse his or her ministerial power and resources to benefit his or her own private interests, and to not to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth? That is what the people want in Australia.

I will give you a tip, especially to the minister for education: never underestimate the Labor Party. We have been here from the start; you lot have not. What have you been? You have been protectionists, free traders, Liberals for a while, nationalists, United Australia, and back to the Liberals again. The thing is, there is no soul. Like their counterparts in Britain, they do not know where they stand or what to do. Through all of the states and territories in this wonderful country of ours, the state of the Liberal Party is in decline. Even their mates in the business community ran away from them in Victoria when they realised what a pathetic rabble they were.

We in the Labor Party have survived and will survive. Why? Because we are a party of principle and we are a party of inclusiveness. We care about our community and we want our community to be secure and prosperous, not to have to worry about whether they have a job or whether they can afford to clothe the kids. The government, though, has survived by dividing and conquering. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to start my remarks by saying how much I regret that we find ourselves in this situation, a couple of weeks out from Christmas and on the last scheduled day of the 2002 sittings in the national parliament of Australia, with the Australian Labor Party abusing the office of the opposition in taking up the time of the House on matters that are so frivolous. I think the other thing that is interesting to note is that the Leader of the Opposition spoke on this MPI for 15 minutes, and throughout that 15 minutes there was not one interjection from the government. The Chief Opposition Whip has just spoken on the MPI for 10 minutes, and throughout that 10 minutes there was not one interjection from the government. So we have heard 25 minutes on this MPI from the opposition, with not one interjection.

speech.para: The first government speaker was the Minister for Education, Science and Training. He spoke for 15 minutes, and there was interjection after interjection from the Australian Labor Party. I think that demonstrates and reflects the difference between those of us in the government and those in the opposition. We will sit and listen to their view, and we did that for 25 minutes; yet the Minister for Education, Science and Training could not speak without being constantly harangued by the opposition. We listened for 25 minutes, despite the drivel and despite the mealy-mouthed comments, without making one interjection, and the best we can get from the Australian Labor Party is interjection after interjection. What is amazing is that the Australian Labor Party still do not understandâand that is why they are in opposition. That is why the people of Australia rejected them.

talk.start.para: âBecause of interjections?

âBecause of your behaviour and your nature. That is why you were rejected by the Australian people and why you will continue to be rejected. You are not worthy of holding that position in the parliament because you cannot and you will not have the decency to even listen. We listened for 25 minutes.

speech.para: This MPI has as its basis the interests of Australian families. I am offended by the MPI, because I think almost all of us in this House are in a family. I would have thought that, after meeting the people I have met from all sides of this House in the 18 months I have been here, the one thing we all cared about was families. Here we have one side of the House suggesting that the other side does not have the interests of families at heart. I would have thought that each and every person who bothered to run for office in the parliament, who bothered to come to this place, cared about families. I thought the people I have met in this place from both sides of the House in the time I have been here cared about families. I am offended by the MPI, because the government does care about families. It may do things that the opposition does not like or does not agree with, but to suggest that the Australian family is not a priority of this government is just frivolous, it is just wrong and it is a misuse of this place. This is the Australian national parliament, where we should be doing what is to the benefit of Australia and Australians going forward.

If you want to talk about the interests of Australian families, there are certain things that Australian families need in this world to prosper and to survive. They fall into two key areas, in my view. The first thing they need is economic security. They need to feel secure. They need to feel that they are going to have a life going forward, and they need to be in control of their destiny. They need economic security. What are the things that make up economic security? They are things like home loan interest rates. I am not going to stand here for the next few minutes and throw assertions at the other side that are wrong; I am just going to state some facts. When I did my schooling, I understood that if things were facts you could not argue about them. So let us look at the facts. The last time the Australian Labor Party held my seat of Aston, in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne, home loan interest rates were 17 per cent. I lived in Aston then. What are interest rates today? They are around six to 6Â½ per cent. That is a fact. What more can a government do in the area of home loan interest rates to support the interests of Australian families than to have economic policies and principles that take the interest rates from 17 per cent to six to 6Â½ per cent?

Have a look at average earnings. During 13 years of Labor, average earnings in Australia increased by two per cent. That is a fact. In the 6Â½ years of this government, average earnings have increased by 11 per cent. They increased by two per cent in 13 years and 11 per cent in 6Â½ years. That is a fact. Is that not in the interests of Australian families? Let us have a look at economic growth. Madam Deputy Speaker, you will remember that it was back in 1990-91 when we were told by the then Labor Treasurer that we were having the `recession we had to have'. In the 6Â½ years of this government, have we had a recession? I do not think we have. We have not had a recession. As a matter of fact, Australia's growth rate is at 3.8 per cent. It is fact: there has been no recession.

Have a look at income tax rates. For the first time in Australia's history, as a result of this coalition government's new tax system, over 75 per cent of taxpayers have a marginal tax rate of 30 per cent or less. When the Australian Labor Party was in government, 30 per cent of people fitted into that categoryâthat is, only 30 per cent of people had tax rates of 30 per cent or less. Under this government, it is now 75 per cent. Most people with any sense of intelligence would agree that one of the greatest expenses an individual has across their lifetime is income tax. We, through our tax system, have increased the number of people who pay 30 per cent or less from 30 per cent to 75 per cent. Is that not in the interests of Australian families?

Let us have a look at inflation. All Australian families are impacted by inflation. Across 13 years of Labor, inflation averaged 5.2 per cent. The 6Â½-year average of this government is 2.4 per cent. That is half of Labor's inflation rate. That means that Australian families have not had the price increases in goods and all sorts of household things. Is that not in the interests of Australian families? Let us have a look at the unemployment rate. In order to help Australians and to help them achieve what they want to achieve, we need to make sure that they can do what they want to do. If they want to work, we need to create an environment that allows them to work. Under Labor, the unemployment rate peaked at 10.9 per cent in December 1992; that was the highest unemployment rate in Australia since the Great Depression. It was when the Leader of the Opposition was the employment minister for this countryâ

talk.start.para: âWhat about the Prime Minister's record?

âRemember what I saidâwe listened for 25 minutes without interjection. It was when the Leader of the Opposition was the employment minister of Australia that the unemployment rate was in excess of 10 per cent. What is it today? It is 6.1 per cent. In 6Â½ years, this government has created over one million new jobs. Is that not in the interests of Australian families? Here we are in the national parliament of Australia on the last scheduled sitting day, and the best that the Australian Labor Party can do is come into this place with frivolous MPIs that have no basis in fact and talk to us about the interests of Australian families. As I said earlier, I would have thought that each and every person in the Australian parliament cared about Australian families. I think we do all care. I think this is a frivolous MPI; it is an MPI that has no basis, no substance, no factual underlying evidence to support it. Australia is a better country because of this government.
