talk.start.para: âIt is customary for the House, whatever turmoil and vigorous exchange has gone before, to end the year on a relatively harmonious and cooperative note. I will endeavour to honour that tradition. I would like to address a few words to what has occurred over the last year and, on a personal note, express my gratitude to a number of people. This year, of course, has been, above all, a year of enormous challenge and sad-ness for the Australian community. You cannot look back over the last 12 months without reflecting upon the terrible wounds that were inflicted upon Australia by the attack in Bali. You cannot look back on the last year without reflecting on the incredible sadness and grief suffered by so many of our fellow Australians.

speech.para: You cannot look back on the last year without being filled with admiration for the courage of so many and the comradeship of Australians from all walks of life who rallied to respond. I have reflected that, for all the imperfections that our country has, the relative absence of division on class and other grounds means that, in a time of crisis, we come together more easily, more spontaneously and more readily than other societies. We are less inhibited in working with each other, we are less in awe of any position held by others and, as a consequence, we have a capacity, I believe, beyond other Western countries, to come together in a quite remarkable fashion. That was very much in evidence in the days that followed what occurred in Bali.

I have told the House beforeâand I would like to repeat itâof the experience I had of thanking the young aircrew at Richmond RAAF base for the tremendous work they had done in evacuating the injured. When I had the opportunity of doing that, to move around and talk to them, one young womanâobviously still very traumatised, if I could use that expression, by the experience that she had suddenly been confronted withâexpressed her sheer pride in being part of a cooperative effort and having worked for a period of time side by side with the group captain by saying, `We don't care about rank; we are just all pitching in to do something for Australia.' That is a characteristic, of course, of the Australian armed forces. They have an egalitarian spirit which gives them a special capacity.

Although it was a very sad period in the life of our country and certainly the sadest period that I have experienced as Prime Minister in the last 6Â½ years, it was also an opportunity to experience immense pride and humility that we belong to a country that can respond in that wayâin such an uninhibited outpouring of compassion and willingness to help. Although we have been bloodied and bowed, we have certainly not had our courage or our spirit in any way diminishedâindeed, it has been enhanced. Those who imagine that they can weaken and cower this country by attacks of that kind misunderstand the mood, the temper and the spirit of the Australian people.

So, most of all, as we come to Christmas, our thoughts are with the people who have suffered so much. We are also determined to reach out to our fellow Australians and to ensure that people of Islamic faith are not discriminated against and do not feel they are a lesser part of the Australian community because their religion is Islam. That should be something that we all endorse and something that we should all practice. The terrorists who murdered our fellow Australians in Bali are no friends of true Islam. The terrorists who struck them down are repugnant to the beliefs of Islam and they do a monstrous obscenity to the religion of Islam in doing what they do in the name of that religion. As we go to the season which celebrates the birth of Christ, we reach out in friendship to people of other religions not only here but also around the world.

It has also been an important year for Australia in terms of the hosting of international events. We had a very successful Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Coolum at the beginning of the year. It has also been a year of very significant international exchanges between this country and other nations of the world.

It has been a year in which our country has fallen into the grip of a very severe drought. Although we have had some welcome rain in certain parts of the country, we are a long way from the breaking of that drought. We think particularly of our country folk at this time and we think particularly of the people who have been ravaged by bushfires. Again, we express our admiration to the emergency services and all of those who performed so well and spontaneously in a spirit of camaraderie in the face of the challenge of bushfires.

For me personally, let me say a few words about a few peopleâsome of whom are here and some of whom are not. Can I first express my thanks to the Deputy Prime Ministerâa finer, more decent man in politics I have not met. He is a person who is a very faithful servant of his electorate and a person who cares very deeply about the people of rural Australia. Matched in his concern for the people of rural Australia, of course, are many members of my own party who have a great affinity with and connection to rural Australia. To you, Deputy Prime Minister: I wish you and Julia a very merry Christmas with your wonderful children and a little bit of respite until you assume the duties of Acting Prime Minister on 1 January. I wish you well during that period, as well, and I hope you have a very enjoyable Christmas.

To my deputy, the Treasurer and member for Higgins: in my view the country has had no finer Treasurer. To him is owed immense credit and praise for the great economic performance of Australia over the last 6Â½ years. It is a reality that the strength of this economy is acclaimed around the world. It is a talking point; it is not just a Liberal Party PR release to say thatâyou do actually get told when you go to other parts of the world that we are a great economic success story. So to the Treasurer and his wife, Tanya, and their children: I wish you a very merry Christmas. Thank you, Peter and Tanya, for your great friendship and support and contribution over the last year. To Senator Robert Hill and Senator Richard Alston, who do not have the luxury of the numbers in the Senateâand that may be of passing comfort, I know, to our colleagues opposite: you handle your affairs and provide leadership extremely well, and I thank you.

I thank all of my ministerial colleagues. I thank Jim Lloyd, the member for Robertson; Stewart McArthur; John Forrest; and all the whips in the other place. Very generally, I want to extend my thanks to all my parliamentary colleagues. When you have an election you get some new people, and I want especially to welcome and thank the class of 2001 for their contribution. I guess I will always have a special place in my heart for the class of '96 because that was the class that resulted in a change of where we sit in this chamber. But I would not want the class of '96 to imagine for a moment that I am not equally impressed with the class of 2001. They are a wonderful group and they represent a fine cross-section of the Australian community. I am very nourished and encouraged by the fact that we continue to draw such a wide cross-section of people. I wish them all well. This is the first set of valedictories that they have attended, and I hope they have years of valedictories ahead of them as they represent their electorates in the national parliament.
I thank you, Mr Speaker, and wish you and your wife, Carolyn, a very merry Christmas. I hope you have some time with your growing family and its addition of grandchildren. I wish you well.

To the unfailingly professional, courteous and likeable Clerk, Ian Harris, I say thank you. You do the role great honour and you perform it very well. You have the regard and affection of all of us. Bernard Wright had a mishap at his family property and is recovering from a broken sternum. We hope to see him back in the new year.

I also take this opportunity to thank those outside this parliament. I owe an enormous debt of gratitude to a group of people who are not here but who played a very great role in an event that means that I am speaking from the dispatch box again, and that group is the organisation of the Liberal Party and the National Party around Australia. I want to thank the federal president, Shane Stone, for his leadership of the organisation. Very particularly, I extend my thanks to Lynton Crosby, who was the organisational architect of our victories in 1998 and 2001. He has now left the Liberal Party organisation. I wish Lynton and Dawn well. I know that across the political divide there is recognition of professional competence, although it may not be expressed. I think many on the opposite side of the House would recognise and acknowledge Lynton's professional competence and ability, just as in the past I recognised and even publicly acknowledged the professional competence of the shadow Treasurer when he was the national secretary of the Labor Party. I confine it to the national secretaryship, but I meant it then and I mean it as I say it today. I think Lynton did a wonderful job for the Liberal Party of Australia. I think he did a magnificent job and I want to record in this parliament my thanks to him for the calm professionalism he brought to that job.

I record my thanks to all the other members of the party organisation. We would not be here without the help of our party membership. That applies to the Liberal Party and the National Party, and I know it applies to the Australian Labor Party. None of us should ever forget the debt we owe to our party organisation. Once you start doing that you start to lose contact with reality. So to all of those people I express my thanks.

I thank my great personal staff. They are too numerous to mention, but I hope that if I name some of them my thanks will flow through them to the rest. There is Arthur Sinodinos, who has been my chief of staff since late 1997. There is Tony Nutt, my principal private secretary, who had a great term of service in the Liberal Party organisation and, as the language goes, knows where more bodies are buried than many other people in the Liberal organisationâparticularly in his home state of Western Australia. I also extend my thanks to Tony O'Leary, who has been a great press secretary and a great adviser in that field for the whole time I have been Prime Minister. I thank Max Moore-Wilton, the secretary of my department. He is an indefatigable worker, a great bureaucrat, a person who gets things done and a person who believes that the role of the Public Service is to give fearless advice and then, the decision of government having been taken, to implement that decision and not second-guess it. I thank him and all of the bureaucracy.

I particularly want to express my gratitude to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, who bore much of the heat and burden of the aftermath of Bali. I single out Ross Tysoe, the consul general, who was confronted with that awful carnage in the early hours of 13 October and had to cope with it. He did that magnificently. I have had the opportunity to thank him personally, but I again want to record my gratitude to him and, through him, to all the other people on the DFAT staff.

I thank the people who make this place work: the clerks and the attendants. I especially want to mention somebody who is doing it hard at the moment: Ali Kafrawi, the House accountant, who has gone on sick leave as he is very ill. We wish him well. Obviously, his health is not good. I particularly want to single him out as somebody to whom we send our very warm good wishes.

I want to record the fact that Senator Margaret Reid, who has been a great member of the Liberal Party and a senator for the ACT for 21 years, and who was the first woman president of the Senate, will be retiring. She may be back for two or three days early next year until her replacement, whoever he or she may be, is appointed formally by the Senate. I wish Margaret and Tom well and hope that they enjoy good health and happiness in the many years ahead.

I thank the Hansard staff and the people who manage the transport. My very warm thanks to the staff at the Lodge and at Kirribilli House, who are very kind and helpful, and my drivers. I felt for one of them very badly, and he would not mind me mentioning his name: Greg Wright. He is my main driver in Sydney and a great follower of the Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs football club. The poor bloke had to endure the pain of the team being right at the top of the competition, driving someone who is a No. 1 ticket holder for St George, with the other relief driver also a fanatical St George follower, and then right on the death knock, for good and proper reasonsâand I think it was an outstanding example of tough and proper sports administrationâthe team had all their points taken away. He bore it manfully and said, `We'll be back next year,' and I fear he is dead right. All of them do a fantastic job, and they are very gracious to my family.

On the personal side, I thank the people who work with me. I would like to record very special thanks again to the members of my Australian Federal Police detail, led by Blen Rowley. They are a terrific group of men and women. They go everywhere with me, and we have been in some interesting situations this year and had some interesting and challenging experiences. They really do an absolutely fantastic job. I have great admiration for the Australian Federal Police. They have done a fantastic job in BaliâI mentioned it at question timeâand their colleagues who escort me do a wonderful job.

Finally, I would like to wish the Leader of the Opposition and his wife, Carol, and their two daughters a very happy Christmas. I hope he has an enjoyable holiday. I extend the same good wishes to Jenny Macklin, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, and to all their colleagues. I wish them well.

This is a time when the spiritual roots of this country are important. For those who find comfort in the Christian religion, it is a very important time. For those who do notâthat is their right in a secular society such as oursâmay they nonetheless draw a sense of tranquillity and peace from the season. We all need that. We are all a bit different now from how we were a year ago, because of what has happened. We have all been reminded of what an incredibly lucky country this is but we have also been reminded that, as a nation, you must in a sense make your own luck. We cannot assume that things that have fallen our way so easily and conveniently in the past are going to do so again in the future. It is very much a time to be charitable to each other. We think of those in the community who are not as well off as we are, and there are many. We should try and help them in different ways. We should try, all of us, to embrace that sense of goodwill which is the hallmark of this time of the year.

Again, my thanks to my colleagues. I should have mentioned both the Leader of the House and his opposite number. Fancy forgetting the Leader of the House! How could you ever forget the Leader of the House? But I did. Something reminded me of him. I thank Tony, who has brought flair and eloquence to the job. I also thank his opposite number, Wayne Swan, for the contribution that he makes. Wayne is a warrior in the Labor Party cause. I had better say no more; I might get into trouble! This is a moment of charity. I thank you all very much and I wish you well. I will say in advance that, if I depart during the Leader of the Opposition's address, it is not through any discourtesy but because it is traditional at this time of the year for me to host a little function at the Lodge for all the departmental secretaries and senior officers. I would not want to keep them waiting for too long. I hope you understand that, Leader of the Opposition. To all of you: I wish you well. I extend across the table to shake the hand of the Leader of the Opposition. I wish you all a very merry Christmas.
Honourable membersâHear, hear!

talk.start.para: âI have pleasure in supporting the motion. Given that the Prime Minister has indicated that he may have to leave early, for valid reasons, I will say that I also have drinks in my office, Prime Minister.

speech.para: Government members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt is not an invitation! It is an indication that both of us have pressing commitments. I wish the Prime Minister, Janette and the family the very best for Christmas and the festive season. He, like me, holds his family very close and very dearly, and it is an important time for all of us to be together. I wish him and his family all the very best for the season.

speech.para: I begin by acknowledging that this has been a very tough year for the nation, and parliament has been the focal pointânot just in terms of the debate and the accountability arguments that we think are important in a robust democracy but also as the focus for the day of national mourning. The memorial service for the Bali victims was very moving, and none of us will be able to look back on this year without thinking of the events that led to that service. And that is why, during this festive season, our thoughts go out to the families of those who perished in Bali. Christmas will be a terribly sad time for them in that many of them would have shared it together. The first Christmas from which loved ones are missing is the hardest of the lot. There will be many grief-stricken families, and our hearts really go out to them. The nation came together in the national capital, and again, from the national capital, our sincere best wishes and thoughts go to those families at this difficult time.

It has also been a difficult year for those who are on the land. They have experienced the worst drought on record. I have previous experience in having to deal, from a portfolio perspective, with the ravages of drought and the hurt of the people. I had that opportunity again when visiting the drought affected areas. As we talk about the need to celebrate, they can really only celebrate when the rains come, and I hope they do. There has been some welcome relief in parts over recent days. We have an obligation as a nation to get behind them and to understand it from the beginning, when it first impacts upon them, and not just when we see its effects in our national accounts figures. There is real suffering out there, and these are elements which we as a nation have to confront. As much as people are hurting at the moment, it will not be the last time, as it is not the first time. Our thoughts go out to them. I acknowledge the assistance that the government has given. We welcome that, but what will be welcome most of all to them, of course, will be the drought-breaking rains.

At the same time as we talk about the drought we also have to acknowledge the national impact of the bushfires in this country. They have come again, but earlier this time. I was out the other day with some firefighters in the Canberra district who, as volunteers, fought the fires here this time last year. As much as we recognise the great effort that the volunteers have given and will continue to give in serving over Christmas, we remember last Christmas when they were called out on Christmas Day. We hope it is an easy time for them because, if that is the case, it means that families will not be threatened in the same way as they were over the last Christmas periodâinstead of celebrating, they were wondering what was happening to their possessions, their homes and indeed their lives.

It is also important to acknowledge the Australian troops who are overseas in Bougainville, in the Solomons and in East Timor. Fortunately, the SAS troops in Afghanistan, the 3rd Division, will be returning home. They will arrive next Thursday and will have the opportunity to spend time with their families. But those people serving in the peacekeeping operations in the Middle East and in Africa and our naval personnel in the Gulf will not have the opportunity to spend Christmas and the festive season with their loved ones, and our thoughts go out to them.

I thank my colleagues on our side of the House. I thank my deputy, Jenny Macklin. She has been a fantastic deputy and has been overseeing our policy development. I genuinely appreciate the loyalty that has been given by her, as I do that of my frontbench and my parliamentary colleagues. I do not single out any particular class because all of them are important, all of them make up the great thing that is the Labor caucusâthe vigour of it, the differences in it and the capacity to resolve those differences. The great thing about the caucus this year has been its capacity to deal with difficult issues, to have our differences, to resolve them and then to accept the decision. To Jenny, Ross and family: I wish you a very merry Christmas. I know that you will be covering for me for a few weeks, but that goes with the job of deputy. To all of my frontbench colleagues and caucus: I wish you the very best also.

Of course, I want to pay particular attention to Wayne Swan as the Manager of Opposition Business in the House. It is actually a great job. It gives plenty of opportunity and plenty of scope but it also gives a few headaches in the need to take strategic decisions at the appropriate time. Wayne has been terrific in the task and I genuinely thank him for that. It is an important function in the parliament, and I acknowledge that on the other side that task is equally as important. To you, Tony: I wish you well over Christmas as well. To the whips, Janice and your team, Michael and Harry: you are the ones who make this place flow in an organisational sense. The three of you have performed fantastically in the job and I pay particular tribute to you. All of us on this side of the House appreciate the way in which the whips' office is run. It rules with an iron fist, I might say.

talk.start.para: âThe velvet glove.

âIn the nicest way. It is the velvet glove; that is exactly right. Mr Speaker, I think that yours is a difficult task in the parliament. It has not been without complaint from our side. I am sure it has not been without complaint from the other side too. I make the point that, at the beginning of the year, we made a genuine effort to improve the function of your role by advocating that there be an independent speaker and by being prepared to support you in that regard. We also proposed some important changes to the way in which the parliament functions not just in relation to question time but, importantly, around question time. This would be a better place if those recommendations were adopted. It is a pity that, despite the Prime Minister saying at the beginning of the year that he would take those recommendations on board, they have not been followed up. They should be. The place would run better. Mr Speaker, I wish you and Carolyn the very best over the festive season. We will no doubt continue to have our disagreements, but that is what comes from trying to make a government accountable. In circumstances where we feel the frustration in that role, at various times it will spill over into the way rulings are made and the way the House operates.

speech.para: I want to say thanks particularly to the staff of the parliament, to Ian and to Bernard. I wish Bernard well in his recovery. The place is not right without him. I was sorry to hear about his injury, but I know that he is recovering well. The attendants, the staff in the Clerk's office, the Bills and Papers Office, the Table Office, the research staff, the Parliamentary Library and the Serjeant-at-Arms and his office all make the parliament function, and they do a great job. We thank them for all their service over the course of the year. There are the Joint House staff as well, who service us and enable the House to function: the cleaners; the gardeners; the marketing and visitors staff, who do a great job with the schools that come through the place; the security staff, who have had a very difficult time over recent months; the switchboard staff who have to field all the calls; and the Health and Recreation Centre staff. It is good to get down there with them in the morning and practise some sparring in a different capacity. The facility is important to the members. The way in which they carry out their function and the individualism of the place is terrific. To the staff in the dining room who look after us, to Kate and her team, a genuine thanks. They are always pleasant. We turn up at different times of the night, expect to be fed and complain when it is not good enough. The staff do it with grace. We do not complain too often. Kate and her staff do a great job. We thank all the services in the building for the way in which they carry out their duties.

I want to thank my staff. There are too many to mention, but I will mention Chief of Staff Phil Tardif. He has been with me for a long time now and a more loyal servant you could not find. Karina, my personal assistant, has been with me for practically all the time I have been in the parliament. All of them play a great roleânot just my staff but the staff of the shadow ministry. They are a great and dedicated team, they work well together and they will have plenty to do next year.

It is the end of a turbulent year, but it has been a year on which we can reflect. Hopefully, we can learn from it and determine to do better next year, not just for ourselves but for the community at large. We are here not for ourselves but to serve the people who elect us. I believe that being a member of parliament is a great and noble cause. To put yourself forward in public office invites criticism and blame but it also gets accolades when you get it right. All of us understand the importance of that role.

To the constituents, not just in our own electorates, who get in touch with us, I urge them to continue to communicate with us. Many people who send us emails and letters comment about what we are doing, suggest how we can do it differently and congratulate us when we do it right. That is a very important part of the democratic process. Whilst people might think at times that we do not take terribly much notice of what people communicate to us, we do. I certainly do. I place great importance on the views, aspirations and concerns that people have. So, on behalf of the opposition, I wish all Australians the very best over the festive season. I wish them a happy and safe season, one which gives them the opportunity to get together with family and to reflect on not just what this year has held but also what the new one holds for them. It has been a great privilege to serve in this parliament. As leader of the Australian Labor Party, it gives me great pleasure to wish everyone, on behalf of that party, the very best for Christmas and the New Year.
Honourable membersâHear, hear!

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âI rise to support this motion. As he departs, for reasons he has explained, I extend to the Prime Minister and his wife, Janette, Julia's and my best wishes for the Christmas season. I have enjoyed very much being in harness with him over this year. I know that I speak for all members of this place when I say we recognise very much the responsibilities of leadership that fall to him at a tough and uncertain time in Australia's history.

speech.para: Shortly after Bali, I addressed a group of high school students in my electorate, in Gunnedah. They were concerned and disturbed by what had happened, as are all Australians. I asked them who they felt was responsible for ensuring the security of the nation in the future. They responded, `The government,' not surprisingly. It is of course the Prime Minister who heads that up. That important responsibility falls on his shoulders. I know that he has the very strong support of the Australian people in pursuing that end. I made this comment yesterday, and I make it again today: in the context of the Australian community, given that leadership is about drawing people along with you and taking people with you, it requires a capacity to seek to walkâin the saying that the Irish put to usâa mile in another person's shoes so that you understand their perspective, even if subsequently you do beg to differ. Understanding people and the Australian psyche and mood is very important to leadershipâand the PM does that superbly.

This year began with recovery workers still clearing the rubble from the World Trade Centre site in New York. It ends with the cruelest drought of all, because it is a drought that interrupts the strongest recovery in rural fortunes that I can remember in my 46 years. It was the Year of the Outback. It began with high hopes, high commodity prices and the celebration of the achievements of rural Australia; it ends ends, quite frankly, in the shattering of hope for many rural families. I only hope that good rains restore that hope very shortly.

Bali, which has been referred to, changed the way we feel about ourselves. I was interested in and to some extent concerned byâalthough I understand itâthe work done by Clemengers which shows that Australians have reacted to the Bali tragedy by coming to the view that it changes the idea that Australia is a sanctuary, that somehow we are beyond reach, and that we are safe. They say that we have no sanctuary anymore. That is the insidious and evil aspect of a highly mobile force for darkness called terrorism. Just as we move around the world freelyâand younger Australians move around even more freely than Australians did when I was in my early 20s backpacking my way around Europeâunfortunately so do terrorists. In that sense, we are a global community confronted by a global problem, and we all have to be involved in the struggle against it. I know that will weigh heavily on many over Christmas who have lost loved ones.

I was particularly reminded that that pain does not ease quickly when I was with the member for Hinkler recently at Childers, where we opened the restored backpackers motel. There were parents and loved ones of those who had been lost there, from Australia and other parts of world, some two years after the tragedy, who struck me as being still deeply saddened. In some cases, they were still as emotional as those people that the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and I met in Bali. Our thoughts do go out to those who have lost people they love.

I thank the Prime Minister and wish him and his wife all the best. I do that on behalf of myself, the National Party and all of those who sit on this side. I know that the Leader of the Opposition has spoken for his party. Mr Speaker, I extend those wishes to you and Carolyn as well. She is in the gallery, if my eyesight does not fail me. You have a difficult task; it is a high office. You are an ambassador in many ways for this parliament and frequently for the nation. You discharge that with great distinction. I would like to thank Mark Vaile, my deputy. It has been fun working with the Prime Minister this year, but it has been fun working with Mark as well. Mark is a great fellow, and I wish him and Wendy all the very best for a good time over Christmas and a chance to recharge the batteries. Mark does an extraordinary amount of travelling. I believe he has assumed a mantle of leadership in his responsibilities as trade minister, not just for this country but for all countries committed to a freer, more open system of trading. That is extraordinarily important to the Australian economy. It is very important to the farming sector in Australia.

This year we have been reminded of how valuable light is because we have seen darkness. One of the things it is important for us to remember is that, wherever we are not acting appropriately internationally, we ought to be prepared to face that. I believe that the trading practices some supposedly free-enterprise Western societies engage in do discriminate against the less fortunate in the worldânot just Australia's efficient exportersâbecause they restrict opportunities for those people who desperately need trading opportunities to break out of their constricted circumstances. I believe that very strongly. Trade reform benefits the weak, the vulnerable and those who might be drawn into the orbit of people with less than healthy attitudes towards life, society and others.

I thank the Clerk, Ian Harris, his fellows and their families for their work and wish them all very best. I join with the Prime Minister in thanking the Australian Federal Police for all of their work on behalf of the nation in some of the world's trouble spots and also here at home. I thank the Prime Minister's protective team. In all, the Prime Ministerâcounting his leave at the beginning of the yearâhas left me with the keys no less than eight times this year. During those times, his team have also looked after me. They are a great group of Australians. We have had some fun together as well, out in the backblocksâsometimes at the expense of their state counterparts. One particularly notable occasion was when we were belting along a bush road and the state police lost their car on a gravel road. There was immense rivalry and ribaldry, which continues to this day, between the state and the Federal Police over that particular issue.

I would like also to thank my principal adviser, Peter Langhorne. Three members of my staff have recently left: Jenny Morris, Jessica Maine and Rhonda Le Nevez. Rhonda has taken up a posting with her husband overseas, with DFAT. I thank, too, the Federal President of the National Party, Helen Dickie, and Andrew Hall, the Federal Director. I acknowledge the hard work that they do and the role they play in ensuring that I speak here and that I have a team and a party behind me. I certainly wish all of them, as I wish all of my Liberal colleagues, all the very best for Christmas. I thank my wife, Julia. All of our partners wear the pain and difficulty that our lives in this occupation can bring. As in the cliched and hackneyed old saying, they keep the home fires burning. We appreciate that very much, I know. I do thank Julia and acknowledge what she has put up with for my sake in recent times.

In the context of the drought, I also thank my farm manager. Those of you who know me would recognise how passionately committed I am to my own place. He has had the very difficult task of keeping it togetherâas so many farmers haveâover the years, and he is a fine Australian. I acknowledge the very valuable role he has performed in enabling me, as much as anything else, to keep doing what I do.

To the Leader of the Opposition and to the Deputy Leader of the Oppositionâshe and I have something of an understanding of the challenge of the role that deputyship brings with it, and we have quipped about it from time to timeâI extend the greetings of the season. I wish them, in a personal sense, all the very best and, in a political sense, not too much of the best. Nonetheless, it is important for us to have a good opposition to take up the fight and to highlight the issues. That would be a good objective for next year. Christmas is a chance to spend some time with our families and to look beyond the events of the year to one that occurred a very long time ago beneath a star outside an inn. Mr Speaker, I wish you and all honourable members the very best for Christmas and a prosperous and happy 2003.

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to join with the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition in wishing all members of the parliament, both in the House and in the Senate, and everybody who works here the very best for Christmas and the new year. It is at this time of year, when most of us are going off and enjoying a break with our families, that I am sure we would all want to extend our thoughts and sympathies to those families around Australia who will have an empty place at the table on Christmas Day. The tragic loss of life in Bali has been keenly felt by all Australians but no more than by those who lost loved ones in that terrible event. We know that that sense of loss and grief will be particularly bad at this time of year, and our hearts go out to them.

speech.para: The Deputy Prime Minister talked about the people in Bali, the young people who lost their lives and the impact that that may have, particularly on young people. On a happier note, one of the things I take great heart in is seeing the way young people can bounce back from these terrible events. From my personal experience, it is wonderful to see young people heading off at this timeâone of my own children is about to head off overseas for this university breakâand to see the way they are able to take on the challenges of the world and not be deterred by the actions of terrorists who we know have done so much damage. We know there are going to be a lot of other people who are suffering over Christmas. Some of them are families who still have people in hospital, and our thoughts go out to all of them.

It is also important for us to think about those who will be working over this time, particularly those people in our hospitals who will be dedicating their time and care not only to the people who were injured in Bali but also to the many others who, whether through accident or illness, will spend Christmas in hospital. Our thanks go out to all of the people who are prepared to give up their Christmas Day and not spend the time with their families, as we will all enjoy doing. There are a lot of other people who will be working over the Christmas period, and all of us rely on their hard work. There is an army of unsung heroesâthe people who actually keep things operating while we all try to have a holiday. Whether they be people delivering things such as gifts or flowers, people cleaning and catering or shopkeepers, they will be working day and night to keep all of our essential services going.

The ones we hope will not have to swing into gear, although we have seen a lot of them latelyâand others have already mentioned it tonightâare the firefighters. We need to pay tribute to the enormous and hard work done by volunteers and to those who have already been out fighting the bushfires. We all say thank you, especially to the volunteer firefighters, who do so much. I say a special word of thanks to the volunteer firefighters in my own electorate, who unfortunately have had to regularly troop up to New South Wales to help out. Last summer many of them were away from their families over Christmas, and I very much hope that the fires abate and that all firefighters will be able to be with their families this summer. Many of you would know that I am a bit of a fanatical surfer. I thank all of those who work on the beaches: the lifesavers, those who save us from the terrible things in the sea that sting and those who patrol our beaches. There are also those who do a wonderful job looking after those who do not have a home and who need food and shelter at what can be a very lonely time. Our thoughts go out to all of those volunteers.

I thank all of my colleagues. There is nothing like the Australian Labor Party caucus. We are a very tight-knit group, and all of us know that it has been a very tough year on this side of the parliament. I think everyone in the parliament knows what opposition is like, and the first year after an election defeat is always difficult. I think the Prime Minister would agree that the toughest job of all in the parliament is that of the Leader of the Opposition. I think we have the toughest Leader of the Opposition this country has seen. He shows enormous guts and determination in leading our party, and we all thank him very much for that. We all hope he has a very peaceful break over the next few weeks and that nothing bad happens while I have to look after the show!

The Leader of the Opposition has been ably assisted by the Manager of Opposition Business, Wayne Swan, who is an extraordinarily hard workerâas well as a terrier, as the government well knows. The Chief Opposition Whip is a fantastic person to work with, and the staff in both Wayne's and Janice's offices also do a wonderful job, not only in supporting the opposition but in helping the parliament to run smoothly. I say a special thank you to Joan and Courtney in Janice's and Wayne's offices. I gather Joan's voice is almost gone so we certainly wish her a very relaxing break. She keeps us all very well organised. I would like to say a special thank you to my own staff both here in Canberra and in my electorate. They do an outstanding job; they are totally dedicated and nobody could wish for a more talented group of people. To the people in the Australian Labor Party, so well led by Geoff Walsh: we appreciate your creativity and your dedication to seeing the Labor Party continues its success all around the country and sometime soon, we hope, federally.

To you, Mr Speaker: I know I sometimes test your patience. Some of my constituents say they hear the member for Jagajaga being asked to sit down or be quiet a bit too often but I know you mean it well. I do thank you for your patience and dedication to the task, and I thank all of your staff for trying to keep us in order; we know that it is not always an easy task. Oppositions of any political persuasion are, as is the government, always very keen on robust political debate, and we are certainly no exception. I know that can sometimes be difficult both for you and the clerks and the staff of the parliament. We do not make any apology for that; I am sure it will continue, but we do thank you for working with us. To all the staff of the parliament, whether they are the clerks and their staff, Hansard, the Comcar drivers, the people who organise our travel, the library, the cleaners, the attendants, the maintenance workers, the security staffâthere are enormous numbers of people who keep this place functioning so well. We wish them all the very best for Christmas.

We go into this break with the shadow of international conflict hanging over us. This is a time when we often talk about peace, but I am sure I speak for all of us here when I say tonight that our hope is very much for peace to prevail in the world. I do hope that we have a very happy summer break and that we look forward to a very prosperous and peaceful 2003.

talk.start.para: âI should begin these comments by letting people know where the House's business is at. My understanding is that the Senate hopes to have a message back to us by about 7.30 p.m. and I hope that we might be able to deal with that, have a dinner adjournment of about an hour and a half and then come back to deal with further matters as required. That is my understanding of where things are at. Obviously the House will be updated as things develop.

speech.para: It has been a tough year; it has been a tough year for Australia, and obviously it has been the toughest year of all for the relatives and friends of the victims of Bali. I suspect that most of them are bearing their loss with the grit and stoicism traditionally associated with the Australian character, but I do hope that the knowledge that 20 million Australians are feeling for them and grieving with them sustains them at this time. It has been a hard year for Australia and therefore it has been a hard year for the parliament. The vicissitudes of our national life, one way or another, are always reflected in this place. It has also been a year, as I understand it, when the parliament has made a bit of history. The stem cell debateâremarkably conducted in a great spirit of generosity and bipartisanship on both sides of the issue, which is rareâis, I believe, the longest debate that this House, indeed this parliament, has ever had. It showed us at our best. I am not sure that we were necessarily at our best at all other times.

Mr Speaker, it is appropriate at this time for me, as Manager of Government Business, to thank you and the others who fill the chair of this place for your hard work. I know it is your profound and heartfelt wish that we in this chamber should dwell more on the things that unite us and less on the things that divide us and that we should see more of the better angles of our nature in evidence here. I think it is pretty obvious, from what has transpired in the House over the last hour or so, that we do not, as members of parliament, dislike each other as much as our daily conduct would suggest. Nevertheless, Mr Speaker, I fear your hopes will be dashed next year as they have been this year. I fear that the feral quality of modern Australian politics will persist, despite the hopes of so many people.

It is also appropriate for me to add my word of thanks to all the other people who allow our parliamentary proceedings to take place, particularly the clerks, led by Ian Harris and Bernie Wright, who are, I suspect, the truest and the most devoted guardians of the traditions of this place. They do a magnificent job and the nation ought to be grateful. The rest of the team that keeps the parliament goingâthe sergeant and the sergeant's office, the attendants, the APS personnel, the librarians, the Hansard reporters, the gardeners, the staff who keep the building looking beautifulâall deserve our gratitude. We tend to take them for granted. We should not, but we do. Let us at least acknowledge them now.

As Leader of the House, I should also add a particular word of thanks to the Government Whip's Office, led very well by the member for Robertson and assisted magnificently by the member for Gilmore. I also add a special word of thanks and gratitude to the member for Corangamite, the sharpest eye and the fastest counter in the business of the parliamentâthanks very much. If your eyes could get just a bit sharper and your hearing just a bit more acute and your counting just a bit quicker in the new year, we will all be thrilled. But you do a fantastic job, Stewie, as you are.

I should offer a word of thanks and pay tribute to my opposite number, the Manager of Opposition Business. I am not going to exonerate the member for Lilley from his various political crimes. Nevertheless, I think he has done a good job as Manager of Opposition Business. You can always have a conversation with him. He does not play games. If he agrees to something, he sticks to his agreement. He has been a very straight and straightforward Manager of Opposition Business. For me, it has been a pleasure to deal with him.

I was very conscious at the start of the year, when the Prime Minister made me Leader of the House, that I was slipping into pretty big shoes. Peter Reith was a giant parliamentary personality as well as being a leading member of this government. I probably should say that the mistakes and the misjudgments that I have made over the past 12 months are entirely my own but, to the extent that I have developed any ability and sure-footedness in this role, it is almost entirely due to the extraordinarily good advice of the Deputy Leader of the House, the member for Gippsland. I am sorry he is not here today. If the House was not conducted as well as it normally is, it is probably because I have been missing his good counsel today. He does a very good job, and his experience is much appreciated.

Finally let me say that I am very proud to be a member of parliament. I am even prouder to be a minister in this government. Notwithstanding the inevitable human error, it is a pretty damn good government and I think history will be pretty kind to it. Along with my parliamentary seniors, I thank you, Mr Speaker, and everyone else associated with the running of the parliament. I wish all my colleagues a very happy and perhaps even a holy Christmas.

talk.start.para: âI rise to wish every member of this parliament the best for the festive season. As a number of speakers have referred to tonight, it has been a tough year for the country and a particularly tough year for those families who are so affected by the events in Bali. If there was one event this year that reinforced for me the enormous responsibility we have to our community and to our country, it was the memorial service here in the Great Hall some months ago. It said to me that we were living in a new environment in this country and that that environment was something that would be affecting us for many years to come and particularly affecting the futures of not only the country but also our young people and our children. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Jenny Macklin, said before, it is the young people of this country who will live with the consequences of the decisions that we take in this area. I know that each and every member of this parliament takes their responsibilities in that area extremely seriously.

speech.para: Mr Speaker, I wish to thank you for your guidance throughout this year. I have appreciated the patience with which you have dealt with us as an opposition. I know you are reminded on a daily basis that the standing orders can be frustrating, and I know that will not change in the near future. However, I certainly reiterate that those on this side of the House do remain committed to fundamental parliamentary reform. We will continue to work for that. We hope that we can achieve some of those reforms in the year ahead, and I certainly do look forward to talking to the government and to the manager of government business about those matters in the New Year. I recognise that the government, initially, was favourably inclined to some reform. We will certainly continue to argue for it because, in so doing, we will make this parliament a better parliamentâand we might just make your job, Mr Speaker, a little easier.

Let me also thank the Leader of the House. I have found him to be a straightforward and forthright person whom you can deal with. That has been appreciated. I, like he, have come to this job for the first time, and I recognise that I have a lot to learn. I have certainly appreciated the assistance of many of my colleaguesâfrom the Leader of the Opposition, who is a former Manager of Opposition Business in this House, through to the member for Fraser and the member for Perth. We do not always get it right in this House, and we certainly do need the advice of many so we can do our job as best and as effectively as we can.

I would also like to pay tribute to the highly efficient and effective support network that ensures our successful legislative process. There are many people who provide daily assistance to me, to the opposition and to the parliament, and they should be mentioned. I am particularly thankful for the guidance and assistance of Ian Harris and Bernard Wright and all the staff from the Clerk's office. I especially wish to thank Judy Middlebrook and her team in the chamber research office who provide terrific and swift information, and Alistair Sherwin and his staff. They all continue to work tirelessly in pulling the legislative schedule togetherâand at no time will that be better demonstrated than tonight and the events which will occur in this parliament over the next few hours. They work hard and they work long hours, but they are committed to this parliament.

I would particularly like to pay tribute to the Leader of the Opposition. He is tenacious and he has worked hard. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has said, he has the toughest job in Australian politicsâprobably the toughest job in the country. It is not easy in opposition, as the current Prime Minister knows. Importantly, you need to work hard, be tenacious and be forthright. I would also like to thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition for her support and her friendship. She too has been working very hard behind the scenes, particularly in our policy process, to make sure that we are a very effective opposition. I would also like to thank the Chief Opposition Whip. She has tutored me on many occasions, and I have been a better person for it. I know there are many members of the caucus who appreciate the backup of our Whip and her staff, particularly Joan.

I would also like to thank my own staffâCourtney, particularly, and also Matt, Michael and all of the staff in the electoral office. There is an enormous amount of pressure that comes with our new role. It involves working with many people on many difficult issues, and they have laboured long and mightily. Their efforts and commitment are deeply appreciated. I should also mention our two assistant whipsâHarry Quick and Michael Danby. They have worked hard, particularly when it comes to organising the affairs of the Main Committee.

As we are about to enter this break for Christmas, I wish each and every member of this parliament and all of the staff who work so hard to make this the effective parliament that it is all the best for Christmas. I also thank my familyâmy wife Kim and my three childrenâfor their forbearance and patience. They put up with a lot. I think that is true of the families of all members of parliamentâalthough in my case it is a hell of a lot. But that is true not only of the families of members of parliament but also of the families of everybody who works here. The pressures between our working life and our family life just seem to grow, and we should not forget the sacrifices that our families make so that we are allowed to, in some ways, indulge ourselves in the passion of our work. Our families are all part and parcel of that, and at this time of year it is appropriate that we thank them for that.

talk.start.para: âI rise to thank members for their remarks and to associate Carolyn and I and my office and the staff of Parliament House with the remarks that have been made. As everyone has rightly observed, this has been an extraordinary year. This will be a year in which Christmas is particularly poignant for a number of familiesâas stressed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and by others who have spokenâwhen around the table they have an empty seat. If Bali taught us one thing, I believe it is that we are actually quite a unique nation and there is a level of cohesiveness about this nation that frequently is not widely understood. It seems to me that what has emerged out of the Australian psycheâto pick up a term used by the Deputy Prime Ministerâhas been an underlying sense of gratitude on the part of Australians that they are in fact Australians and gratitude for the history and background which has ensured that our nation has emerged as it is.

speech.para: It is perhaps also poignant to remember that this time last year, while we were reflecting on the awful tragedy of the twin towers events in New York, we were also remembering that 2001 had been a year of celebration for Australians as we recognised the Centenary of Federation. It is fair, I think, to observe 101 years later that our nation was 101 years ago the envy of much of the world and that 101 years later it remains the envy of much of the world. That is not extraordinarily a credit to the parliament, but it is extraordinarily a credit to the Australian people. It is a fair indication that whoever has been in office in this great institution over that 101 years has managed at least to reflect the will of the Australian people and offer guidance and ensure that we have enjoyed 101 years of prosperity that makes us, as I said, the envy of much of the world.

There are thoseânot those in the parliament but those outside of itâwho would observe that this opportunity at the end of each year to express goodwill to each other is somehow uncharacteristic of the parliament. I take issue with them, actually. This parliament is much more a place of goodwill than is recognised, and everyone in this parliament is passionate about peace. The goodwill is often exhibited when members are on committees, in meeting rooms around this place and from time to time in this chamberâbut is all too rarely portrayed realistically in the Australian community.

I want to join all others in extending seasons greetings to all of those who make it possible for us to do our work and make it possible for us to have the relationships we enjoy across the parliament. They have all been named by previous speakers, so I will not name them. Many of the team on which we are so reliant are people we do not frequently see. They work under the building; they work in offices that are not frequently seen; they work long hoursâand we all stand indebted to them.

I do, however, want to single out one or two people, and I am sure you will understand why. I want to express the sentiments of everyone in this chamber to those in the Senate, but most particularly to the Senate President. Some people may not know, but the Senate President in fact suffered the loss of his mother yesterday morning, so, for him, Christmas this year will be a little different. I want the Senate President to know that all of those who are aware of that will in fact be identifying with him and his family in their grief. I know that, when I spoke to him this morning, he was conscious of the number of colleagues who had contacted him and had been supportive of him.

It would also be appropriate for me on this occasion to acknowledge the support I received as Speaker of the House of Representatives from Senator Reid, when she was President of the Senate, and the way in which she so sensitively and professionally allowed us to go about our mutual roles, to respect the sovereignty of each of our chambers and yet also to ensure that there was an opportunity for us jointly to be involvedâI hope effectivelyâin the management of this place.

I cannot, as the Speaker, express this sort of sentiment without recognising, as everyone else has, the remarkable role played by the clerks and the staff in the Clerk's office. I join everyone else in expressing our appreciation to Ian, Bernie and their team, and in expressing our best wishes to Bernie at this time. I am also indebted, as the Speaker, to the departmental heads who make it possible for this building and its offices to function as they do. I am extraordinarily indebted, of course, to my own staff. Marie, who is known to everybody, Pauline, Barb and Dennis all work part time in Canberra, although Dennis is full time with his electoral responsibilities as well. Yvonne and Peter are the full-time people. I want to single out Mr Peter Gibson, who will be known to you all, for the extraordinary support that he gives to me and to people who make inquiries of my office.

I also would be failing in my duty if I did not recognise the extraordinary support that I have had from the Deputy Speaker. Deputy Speaker Causley has not been well, as many members know. He is making an encouraging recovery and expects to be back with us when we recommence in February, so we wish him well. In his absence, I have been utterly reliant on Deputy Speaker Jenkins, and it will not be a surprise to anyone in this chamber to known that Deputy Speaker Jenkins has been a pivotal member of the team and totally cooperative. I want to express my appreciation to him and my best wishes to him and his family. I want to recognise the role played by all in the Speaker's panel in helping to ensure that the parliament runs efficiently.

I should recognise the role, of course, of my Gawler staff. None of us could be here without each of our electorate staff. I want to express to the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Prime Minister, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the House and the Manager of Opposition Business in the House my appreciation for their sentiments. As they have observed, the view from this chair is a little different to the view from any other chair of the parliament, and this is a place in which there is a great deal more cooperation and goodwill, as I said earlier, than is popularly believed. When there are occasions where members are passionate, I remind the electorate that that is precisely what they elected their representatives to be. I remind the schools that I visit that, whether members sit on my right or my left, they are charged with representing at least 80,000 Australian constituents who have elected them all to be here. They are charged with ensuring that transparency is a key word in Australian parliaments so that the hundred years of relative prosperity that we have enjoyed can be projected into the future.

Finally, let me thank my family. As has been said, Carolyn, my wife, is in the gallery. Those of you who know my family will know that what seems to be the relative stability in the family would not have occurred without her total commitment to it. That has allowed me to do the things I have wanted to do, so I stand indebted to you, darling, for your assistance. Thank you. The family now is growing to include grandchildren, so Christmas for us will be a particularly happy and meaningful time, as it is for all of those who have had a similar experience. Carolyn joins me in wishing everyone in this building and beyond best wishes for a joyous Christmas time and a peaceful New Year.
