talk.start.para: âI present the report from the Committee of Privileges concerning an application from Ms Jane Singleton for the publication of a response to a reference made in the House of Representatives.
âI present the report of the Committee of Privileges entitled Parliamentary privilege: the operation of the committee, some historical notes and guidelines for members.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI thank the House. The report I have just tabled provides members with a number of documents for their information. The committee considers it will be helpful to make witnesses and others who may be involved with the committee aware of the procedures under which the committee will operate. The first of the documents attached with this report is procedures which the committee will adhere to when undertaking its inquiries. Earlier this year, the committee considered undertaking an inquiry into the Parliamentary Privileges Act. The act has been in place since 1987 and the committee thought it might be timely to conduct a review of the operation of the act to ensure its provisions were meeting current requirements of providing the protection of privilege to the House.

speech.para: The committee prepared a paper which commented both on the operation of the provisions of the act and on areas that may be relevant to the law of privilege that are not covered by the act. The paper examined cases of the House and Senate committees of privileges and relevant court cases. The committee decided not to proceed with a review of the act. However, it considered that the paper was a useful reference to make available for the information of members. It is the second paper attached to this report. Finally, attached to the report are draft guidelines for members on the status and handling of their records and correspondence.

In November 2000, the committee presented a report on the legal status of the records and correspondence of members. In that report the committee indicated that it would prepare draft guidelines to assist members with issues that arise from their records and correspondence. The status of these records, particularly the correspondence with constituents, has been of considerable concern to members. The guidelines are designed to help members navigate the maze of issues that can arise when there is a threat to the confidentiality and integrity of their communications with constituents. The committee has issued the guidelines as a draft for discussion and comment. The committee would welcome comment on the guidelines from members and others who may wish to make a contribution. The committee intends to hold a workshop in the new year to enable those with an interest to discuss and refine the guidelines. The committee will then prepare a final version of the guidelines.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Egypt, September 2002

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI present the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Egypt's report, entitled Australia and Egypt: a parliamentary perspective, and seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation which visited Egypt in September. Our report outlines the information we gathered during our visit along with our observations based on that information. We were fortunate during our visit to meet with a number of senior representatives of the Egyptian government and parliament, including the foreign minister, the Minister for Supply and Home Trade and the senior adviser to the Egyptian president. We also met with the Secretary-General of the League of Arab States. As a result of those meetings, we have come away with a good understanding of the views that exist within Egypt on significant events currently unfolding in the Middle East. The discussions at those meetings are summarised in the report which I have presented today.

speech.para: Two key issues are currently influencing events and attitudes in Egypt. Firstly, the war on terrorism, and, secondly, the Israeli-Palestinian situation. Those issues were raised time and time again during the meetings we held in Cairo. Our report details current Egyptian views on both those issues. One of the clear messages from those meetings is that peace is vital for regional stability and the economic development of the Middle East. Within Egypt, there are significant concerns about the possibility of escalating conflict in the region and how this will impact on all the nations of the region. The delegation was told on numerous occasions that Egypt welcomes Australia's interest in the region and hopes that Australia, with its history of involvement in peacekeeping efforts around the world, can play a constructive role in helping to bring peace to the region.

During our visit, we had the opportunity to hear about one peace initiative that is working in the Middle East; namely, the peace treaty between Egypt and Israel. We met with representatives of the multinational force and observers, including the Australian contingent commander. The multinational force plays a significant role in helping to maintain the peace treaty between Egypt and Israel, and we congratulate the Australian Defence Force personnel who are making such a vital contribution. The success of that treaty arrangement indicates to the delegation that there are models for peace in the Middle East which are viable and enduring. Political will and broad international support are the two critical factors.

Another important emphasis of the delegation was to examine ways in which the bilateral relationship between Australia and Egypt can be strengthened. The healthy trading links that we enjoy with Egypt were discussed at various meetings we attended. Egyptian representatives praised the quality of Australian produce exported to Egypt, particularly Australian wheat and meat. The reliability of Australian exporters in delivering produce and goods was seen as a particular benefit of trading with Australia. The delegation was told that Egypt was keen to provide Australia with greater market access for its wheat. At the same time, Egypt is seeking greater trade with Australia in relation to some of its goods, such as furniture and citrus products. Future trading and investment opportunities were also discussed, with agribusiness, oil exploration and production, and information technology and communications being areas that show potential.

The delegation was pleased to inspect one current joint venture in Egyptâthe Five Star Flour Mill at the Red Sea port of Adabiya, which involves an investment of $11 million by the Australian Wheat Board. That mill is regarded as a very positive sign of Australia's commitment to broadening our bilateral relationship with Egypt.

As part of its visit, the delegation was also honoured to lay wreaths at the Commonwealth War Cemetery at El Alamein. In the year that we commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Battle of El Alamein, we were keen to pay tribute to the many Australians who lost their lives so that we could live in peace. In the memory of those who made the ultimate sacrifice, our efforts should always be directed to peace.

In conclusion, let me express our appreciation for the warm welcome we received in Egypt from the representatives of the Egyptian government and parliament. Let me also congratulate Australia's Ambassador to Egypt, Robert Newton, for the good work that he and his staff are undertaking in enhancing Australia's bilateral relationship with Egypt. I thank Ambassador Newton and our liaison officer during the visit, Melissa Bray, for the effort they devoted to our program and for helping to secure such high-level and significant meetings for the delegation. Thanks are also due to the Parliamentary Relations Office, particularly Russell Chafer, for their contribution.

The delegation is hopeful that our report will contribute to a better understanding in this parliament of the importance of our bilateral relationship with Egypt. We are also hopeful that our visit has helped to show the significance with which Australia views that relationship. I thank the committee's secretary, Andres Lomp, for an excellent report. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâThe Australian delegation to Egypt in September 2002 created considerable interest in Egyptian government circles and the Egyptian press due no doubt to the continuing conflict in Palestine and the Australian Prime Minister's support for an American pre-emptive strike against Iraq. Because of this climate, the Australian delegation met a number of senior Egyptian government and parliamentary representatives, including: Foreign Minister Ahmed Maher; Dr Osama El-Baz, Senior Adviser to Egyptian President Mubarak; and the Secretary-General of the League of Arab States, Mr Amr Moussa.

speech.para: The delegation on a number of occasions was unexpectedly confronted by the Egyptian press, which required the leader of the delegation, the member for La Trobe, to carefully respond to the many questions relating to Australia's policy on Iraq and the Middle East in general. Mr Charles responded very professionally to these approaches. The Egyptian representatives expressed the view that, with their economy relying very much on the tourist trade, they were strongly opposed to any military activity that would lead to regional instability. Foreign Minister Ahmed Maher and President Mubarak's senior adviser, Dr El-Baz, expressed concern about statements from the US polarising the world by categorising countries as either for or against the US. This created doubt in Middle East countries' minds whether they were considered friends or enemies of the US.

The Australian delegation reassured our Egyptian hosts that the Australian parliament did not have a fixed view on an American pre-emptive strike and that we supported a full and open debate in parliament before any decision was made by the Australian government. It was made clear to the delegation that Australia is well regarded in Egypt but that we should be mindful that inflammatory remarks such as those by the Prime Minister and the foreign minister could jeopardise that good standing in the longer term. Egypt and Australia have a long history of cooperation, and this delegation reinforced those links. Egypt ranks in the top 30 of our trading partners, with Australian exports to Egypt totalling around $740 million in 2001. Thousands of Australians visit Egypt each year, attracted by their rich culture and heritage, so there is much to be said for maintaining our strong bilateral links with that country.

When we visited the Australian Embassy, we saw long queues of people seeking information about travel to Australia, both as tourists and as migrants. The embassy in Cairo deals with some 2,500 inquiries each month. This shows not only that there is a great link between our two countries but that there is also a great deal of strain placed on resources at the embassy. Some thought should be given to increasing those resources. On the day we visited there were a large number of Somalis wishing to come to Australia. Increasing resources to process applications more efficiently at our overseas embassies, I am sure, would help to reduce the number of refugees arriving in Australia unauthorised.

As a small demonstration of the many and varied links between Egypt and Australiaâand, indeed, the diversity of both countriesâthe delegation visited with Pope Shenouda III's adviser, Father Mauritius, who is in fact an Australian. Pope Shenouda III is, as members would be aware, the head of the Coptic Orthodox Church.

I am sure I speak for the other delegation members when I say that we were honoured to be able to lay a wreath at the memorial to the Australian fallen at El Alamein to mark the 60th anniversary of the battle that saw so much Australian loss of life. Australia and Egypt have a good and solid relationship, and our delegation's visit helped to reinforce that. I am sure that the reciprocal visit by Egyptian parliamentarians will also build on the links that we have. However, as the report shows, we should be cautious in our dealings in the Middle East or that solid relationship may diminish in the longer term. That would be a great shame.

The delegation was very appreciative of the briefing given by the Egyptian Ambassador to Australia, His Excellency Mr Assem Ahmed Megahed, prior to our visit as well as discussions on our return. I would like to thank my fellow delegation members and the parliamentary staff who accompanied us, as well as all those in Egypt who showed us such great hospitality. I also commend the report to the House.

subdebateinfo.title: Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund Committee

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, I present the committee's report on the examination of annual reports for 2000-01, together with evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâThe report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund on the examination of annual reports for 2000-01 reviews the performance of the National Native Title Tribunal, the Indigenous Land Corporation and the land fund in the reporting period.

speech.para: The Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Fund has a statutory duty to examine the annual report of the National Native Title Tribunal. This report is prepared pursuant to section 206(c) of the Native Title Act 1993. Section 206(c) of the act requires the committee to report at its discretion to both houses of parliament on matters concerning annual reports to which parliament's attention should be directed. This, the eighth annual report of the tribunal, covers the financial year 2000-01. It was presented out of session on 5 October 2001, and tabled in the Senate on 12 February 2002 and in the House of Representatives on 13 February 2002. To assist in its evaluation, the committee held public hearings in Canberra on 25 June 2002 for the National Native Title Tribunal and on 17 June for the Indigenous Land Corporation.

I would like to outline briefly some of the issues that have arisen in the course of the committee's perusal of the annual report for the National Native Title Tribunal. On the last occasion the committee expressed some disquiet about the number and level of consultants retained by the tribunal. The committee is pleased to note that expenditure on consultants has been reduced by $700,000 and that there has been a decrease from 43 to 15 consultants over the period 2001-02.

The tribunal has taken steps to increase the number of Indigenous land use agreements registered. In the previous reporting period the committee noted that a number of ILUAs presented for registration did not comply with the act. The tribunal has taken a number of initiatives, including the issuing of guidelines and early compliance checking to increase the compliance rate. The committee notes that these improvements have increased the cost to the tribunal of registering an ILUA but have increased the efficiency with which applications are moved through the process.

The committee also notes the efforts made by the tribunal to inform parties about native title generally and to provide appropriate material to assist this process. This material included a CD-ROM, a videotape and a number of question and answer booklets. The committee noted that the National Native Title Tribunal annual report covers the required reporting areas, and complies with the legislative and other formal requirements concerning the provision of annual reports. Overall I am pleased to report that the tribunal has again produced an informative and accessible annual report.

I now turn to the annual report of the Indigenous Land Corporation, which also includes the report on the operation of the Indigenous Land Fund. The corporation has a primary responsibility to assist Indigenous Australians to purchase land and also to assist in the management of Indigenous-held land. The corporation's annual reporting requirements can be found in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989. The report for the year 2000-01 was provided to the minister on 27 August 2001, and tabled in the Senate on 15 February 2002 and in the House of Representatives on 13 February 2002.

The committee notes that the ILC has adopted suggestions made by the committee in its 18th report. These included a suggestion that the ILC return to the previous report format and include information about the factors to be accorded priority when the ILC exercises its land acquisition and management functions.

The ILC report notes that there was a decline in the number of properties approved for purchase, purchased and divested. The ILC explained that this was due to a revision of its major policies during the reporting period. However, there was also a decline in this activity in the period 1999-2000, and the committee expressed some concern on that occasion. The committee will continue to monitor this aspect of the ILC's work, and notes that the revised National Indigenous Land Strategy and the Land Acquisition and Land Management Programs Guide were launched on 4 December 2002. In the light of this the committee expects that the ILC will be able to devote more of its resources to these responsibilities.

The committee notes that the 2000-01 annual report confirms the committee's concerns regarding the ILC's financial performance over the last two years. The committee hopes that this trend has been reversed with the appointment of a new chairperson and that the 2001-02 annual report demonstrates an improvement in the performance of the corporation. The committee notes that the presentation of the annual report of the Indigenous Land Corporation complies with the legislative and other formal requirements.

Finally, I refer to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund report for 2000-01. The requirements for this report are established by section 193I of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989. The report was provided to the minister on 15 October 2001, and was tabled in the Senate on 12 February 2002 and in the House of Representatives on 13 February 2002.

The Land Fund was established in the 1994-95 budget. In 2004 government allocations to the fund will cease, and the intention was that the capital base of the fund would be sufficient to guarantee ongoing operational funding for the ILC. The return on investment may not yet be sufficient to allow this to occur. The committee has noted that the target amount is assured by the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Site remediation and construction of infrastructure for the Defence site at Randwick, NSW.

speech.para: The Department of Defence proposes to undertake works for the site remediation and development of infrastructure at Randwick Barracks, Sydney, in support of the proposed disposal of surplus land. In 1990, the Defence Logistics Redevelopment Project was initiated to fundamentally reorientate the combined Australian Defence Force logistics and supply functions. This program consolidates the large military warehousing facilities throughout the Sydney metropolitan area, which had previously been independently operated by the services, into one joint warehouse facility at Moorebank in western Sydney. This strategy has resulted in the closure of 49 hectares of the former Navy Stores at Bundock Street, Randwick, as well as other large storage areas throughout Sydney. The remaining portion of approximately 20 hectares will continue to be occupied by Defence for the foreseeable future.

The proposal to undertake site remediation and infrastructure development of surplus land has been developed in close consultation with the Randwick City Council and is seen to offer significant advantages to the Commonwealth, the council, Sydney based development and construction industries and the wider community. The proposed works will be staged to achieve an orderly and economic development of the site and maximise revenue return. The proposed works will consist of demolition of the remaining structures and clearing of necessary vegetation to permit other works to be undertaken; bulk earthworks; remediation of the site, including decontamination, to allow residential usage; construction of trunk infrastructure, including drainage, roads, sewer, water and telecommunications; construction of a new oval; development of an environmental park; and construction of a new community facility for the City of Randwick.

The works are expected to generate employment for some 80 people directly engaged on site in construction or construction related activities. Other off-site employment opportunities will be generated in areas such as material supply and support, off-site fabrication, management and administration. The cost of the proposed works is estimated at $85.4 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction will commence by June next year and be completed in 2006. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: âI am happy to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. It is an omnibus bill that gathers together a range of measures in the migration area, none of which is deemed to be controversial. It has been indicated that these are necessary tidying up pieces of this legislation jigsaw, covering various parts of the Migration Act. I will deal with these measures seriatimâone at a time. The very first provision this bill deals with provides that non-citizen children born in Australia are immigration cleared for the purposes of their birth entry. This and all the other matters we are dealing with here relate to questions of clarification. The purpose of the bill is to make as clear as possible the intent of the original act, and its associated parts, for people who find themselves in particular situations or who are attempting to challenge decisions taken by the minister or his delegates. The bill also provides general information for the community at large. But the underlying and most important purpose of the bill is to ensure the integrity of our migration legislation, and that is often the most difficult part to ensure.

speech.para: I have had experience in dealing with migration matters over many yearsâsome 17 years all up, of which 11Â¼ years were spent running the former member's electoral office in Blaxland, which I then took over. I have a reasonable amount of knowledge of immigration matters and of what Labor did in government, particularly the 1990 act and the 1992 act which toughened up the approach to immigration policy and also added an enormous layer of complexity. I will come to that a bit later and particularly to the PAMS introduced by former Minister Hand, which were the immigration department equivalent of the GST act in terms of just how high they might rise on a table.

In trying to ascertain certainty with regard to decisions taken by officers of the immigration department, everything had to be spelt out. When spelling everything out and in attempting to be as clear as crystal, everyone knows that that presents two significant problems. One is legalese or bureaucratese. The second is that, if you are trying to write it in plain, simple, straightforward Englishâlike they were attempting to rewrite the NRMA rules or parts of the parallel importation bill, I think it was, the other dayâit is very difficult to do, particularly when you are dealing with legal matters. This bill encompasses a range of particular legal matters with the attempt to clarify them. One of those goes to the question back in 1992 that Mr Hand was trying to deal withâto provide codification of the departmental processes of decision making. There has already been a related bill put to the House. It dealt in detail with those questions and it was directly related to procedural fairness and how you ensure that. I aim to come back to that in later comments.

There are challenges almost every day to decisions that have been taken by officers of the department. The challenges go to the point of what was meant in the original legislation. This government, like our government when it was dealing with these matters, has had to bring bills like this before the House to clarify such situations. I will give you an example of this. Whatever a person's status once they are in Australiaâwhether they are here on a tourist visa, a student visa or any other legal visaâif they give birth to a child in Australia then the question of the status of that child generally has been taken, in the past, and certainly in our legislation, to be one of equivalence to the status of the mother. We thought that was pretty clear. Given the length of time that people who are here unlawfully can be detained, there have been cases where people have had children in detention. This bill tries to fix the question of the legal situation for that child.

There has been an argument put, contrary to the department's expectation in terms of this, that the child's legal status should be different to that of the parent. Of course, going back a number of years, the classic case related to this was that of Nancy Presad. Her situation was that she had been born to parents who were not Australian citizens and the question was whether simply being born in Australia allowed her to achieve Australian citizenship. We know that that can be the situation in the United States, but in this case our courts held that it was not so. This bill clearly makes it known that, if a parent is immigration cleared and lawfully here, the child will be immigration cleared and lawfully here. Equally, if the person is held not to be immigration cleared, such as an asylum seeker in detention, this amendment provides that the child is not immigration cleared and that the child's immigration status will then be dealt with in the substantive visa application process. So there is an absolute equivalence between the status of the child and status of the parent: whether the status is lawful or unlawful, the child takes on the same status as the parent.

It is at this point that Labor's amendment to this bill becomes relevant. Whether a child has just been born in Australia to an unlawful non-citizenâthat is, an asylum seeker in detentionâor whether an older child accompanied that person to Australia, Labor's says that the regime needs to change. We need to take into account the situation of mothers and children. We need to have a very fast processing regime, and we have proposed a series of changes to achieve that end. But there is an equivalence in that mothers and children should be treated in a different way. This bill declares absolutely the status of a child born to a mother in detention. Given that clarification, which we support, the question that our amendment goes to is: how and where that mother and child should then be kept in detention. The shadow minister has outlined the case. We believe:

quote.para: ... as soon as possible after the commencement of detention under section 189, a detained child must be accommodated with his or her family members in immigration detention conditions which meet the same amenity and security standards as are required by the Woomera alternative detention arrangements for women and children operated by the department from 7 August 2001.

speech.para: We note that there is a series of members on the other side of the House who have indicated some support for that approach, quite clearly because the department has been operating this on a trial basis since August 2001. The reports from the department are that this has worked pretty well and that there should be no fear on the part of the minister or others in taking this kind of step. The very first part of our consideration is that unaccompanied minorsâthose who are not with their parents or guardiansâshould be placed as soon as possible in a situation outside the detention centres, but that where the children are accompanied they should be reunited with their parents as soon as possible in a situation like Woomera. The department has run with that.

I will pass over and come back to the second matter that is dealt with here, which is that of special purpose visas. That relates to the 1992 situation: what Mr Hand was trying to achieve and the question of procedural fairness. There is a direct relationship there. I want to go to another element of this bill, which relates to the Criminal Code and strict liability for people-smuggling offences. In a way, I am a bit bemused about this. We have just heard from the Deputy Speaker that the Crimes Legislation Amendment (People Smuggling, Firearms Trafficking and Other Measures) Bill 2002 has been passed by the Senate. I know the bill went through the Main Committee the other day, because I made a speech on it. I noted in that speech that the very provisions that are in this omnibus bill also happen to be in that bill. However, there were more provisions in the latter bill. I know that since the bill has been through the House and the Senate I cannot add to any argument about it except to say that both bills have some of the same provisions. If a person is taken to be assisting someone to unlawfully enter Australia, they can face 10 years jail and a $110,00 fine. The bill that has just gone through, the Crimes Legislation Amendment (People Smuggling, Firearms Trafficking and Other Measures) Bill 2002, has a further provision to double that amount to 20 years imprisonment and a $220,000 fine.

This is a matter of tidying up unintended consequences or the fact that there are questions about what strict and absolute liability are. The problem here is that, when the Migration Legislation Amendment (Application of the Criminal Code) Act 2001 came into effect, there was a question about whether a person committing the act was mindful of the consequences of what they were doing, and, if they were not, whether or not that could be taken as a defence under the act. The bill that we are discussing today tries to reinforce what liability is and add clarity to that. It is a difficult concept to get around but it is an important one in dealing with not only those who have been smuggled but those who smuggle. If they are bringing people into Australia, it is important that the severity of the law is exercised as strictly as possible. So there is a conjunction of the two pieces of legislation in relation to that.

There is a further conjunction when we deal with older legislation which informs one of the other changes that this bill proposes, and I will go to that now. It is the matter of special purpose visas. This is an excellent example of particular situations where people who one would not think were in particular difficulty might seek to be treated in a different way from what would be expected in immigration law. Who are the people who get special purpose visas? They are aircraft crews, crews of visiting vessels and members of foreign armed forces visiting for exercises or training. There have been cases in the past where people have jumped ship and sought to stay in Australia. My aunty, Gwen Charisiadis, was married to Gerasimos Charisiadis, who jumped ship in the late 1940s. He was a ship's engineer and a great cook. He jumped ship, and, given that it was the forties, there was not much of a penalty, even though he had a Mediterranean background. It was probably the quality of Gerry's cooking that got him a guernsey in the first place. He was allowed to stay in Australia. He worked on Australian National Line ships, going from one port in Australia to another. After a long and successful career as a ship's engineer, he moved on to work on the fireboats on Sydney Harbour. Under this provision, my uncle Gerry would not have got a guernsey; he would not have been able to stay in Australia. On this matterâex post facto, because it certainly will not affect my uncleâit is necessary to consider that, where people are given a special permit to do their work, it is possible for them to take advantage of our largesse.

Here we get to the question of procedural fairness and the question of natural justice. The shadow minister at the table, the member for Lalor, is a lawyer of distinction and someone who has put together a very strong policy for the Labor Party to take us forward in this regard. But we know what the lawyers in the immigration area get up toâI have suffered them for 17 years. I know that there is pedantic nitpicking to pull out every thread from the immigration law to try and get a further step forward. The argument that has been put up is that, if a person is in one of these categories and they happen to decide to apply to stay in Australia, you should extend to them natural justice. They should be able to put in an application, put their hand up and have a chance to stay in Australia.

Gerry Hand not only had a great sense of humour but was also a pretty tough old immigration minister, and anyone who had to deal with him was aware of that. The law that he brought into operation in 1992 attempted to codify once and for all Labor's immigration law, to get a tough set of codified laws that was as specific as possible. The immigration regulations arising out of that were about six feet long. They attempted to give clarity and certainty to immigration law. Labor entirely supports the provision within this bill, quite simply because this bill makes clear that the rules of natural justice do not apply to such a visa cancellation. The person involved simply has no right to be heard. Why is that a sensible clarification? The shadow minister has made this point in her brief, and it could not be any clearer. This sums up our approach to a tough immigration policy that should be there to protect our borders and to protect our people. I quote:

quote.para: Australia does not owe hearing rights to non-citizens in such circumstances because it is pushing it too far.

speech.para: There are certain hearing rights to non-citizens in other circumstances, particularly offshore refugees, but for these categories we believe there should not be a question of whether natural justice should operate. Rather, the bill clarifies that and states it absolutely. The reason it does so is that, in the procedural fairness bill, the explanation given by the minister and by the department went to considerable lengths to underline the fact that the certainty that should have been there with regard to what procedural fairness was in immigration matters had been gradually eroded.

In fact, if you run back 50 years, the fundamental principles in relation to procedural fairness were laid down by Justice Dixon, our greatest High Court judge, the most influential person when it came to making fundamental law in a range of areas and the person who set this doctrine in place. It is arguable on a range of grounds that he may have been wrong. I personally do not think so; I think he actually got it pretty right. People who are arguing the toss from one angle or another are doing so in order to push the bounds of credibility and to push the bounds of immigration law as far as they go. The reinforcement of this ruling in this bill is all to the good.

A range of matters are dealt with in this bill. The last one I will go to in the short amount of time I have left is the question of restrictions on bridging visas for onshore applications for visas. Section 48 of the act deals with this. I am a bit concerned about the way it will practically operate. They say that, essentially, you have to be careful that people on bridging visas do not have a range of reasons to try to stay in Australia. I agree with that absolutely. What this bill goes on to try to ensure is that you cannot, if you want to make a change, nick off to Auckland or go on a bit of a trip to Port Moresby or to Fiji and then come back into Australia. What this says is: if you go to Auckland, Port Moresby or Fijiâand we know there is a bit of a precedent for thisâit will be taken to be part of Australia's migration zone. The problem with that is that we have had case after case of spouse applicants where the department has had to arrange for them to nick off to Auckland, New Guinea, Port Moresby, Fiji or somewhere else rather than send them back to Sverdlovsk or Denmark and then have them come back into Australia given the fact that they are legally married. With that in train, I would support the bill and support our amendment. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Ms King) adjourned.
