talk.start.para: âI rise in the House to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. Since January this year, Labor has been calling for the release of children from Australian detention centres. In August, Labor foreshadowed amendments to the bill. These amendments would compel the government to release any unaccompanied children from high-security detention and to have children accompanied by family members live in accommodation like that in the Woomera alternative detention trial. They lay down a challenge to those moderate Liberals who are telling refugee advocacy groups that they are concerned about children in detention. These amendments have already forced the government to move on these issues. But the response of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs to this House last week goes nowhere near far enough, and moderate Liberals who are claiming to be concerned about children in detention should be measured against how they respond to Labor's amendments. If they fail to vote with Labor on these amendments then it will be clear that they are merely espousing the rhetoric of compassion while they sit on their hands and do nothing.

speech.para: Labor, in contrast to the government, believes that Australia can have a policy that restores both integrity and compassion to our immigration program. The ministerial response to Labor's amendments to the bill was billed in the media as a great change. We read headlines like `Ruddock rehouses women, children', `About-face on detention centres policy' and `PM changes tune on asylum seekers'. But what we got instead was a meaningless document that was aggrandising the government's achievements in managing migration while doing little to change the situation in detention centres, especially for children. We got an extension of the eligibility criteria for a trial, we got the government issuing a migration series instruction on unaccompanied minors and we got the government saying it was thinking about engaging in a process that might lead to community consultations on something that they might do.

What we did not get was a legislative change to protect unaccompanied minors; what we did not get was a recognition that fathers and young boys should also be allowed to live with their families in accommodation like the Woomera alternative detention trial. In fact, the minister seems to find it hard to even refer to them as `fathers', `sons' or `brothers'. We heard him in question time this week calling them `any adult male partner', as he was unable to call them fathers, sons or brothers. What we did not get was any acknowledgment that the children on Manus Island and Nauru even exist, let alone that they are the responsibility of this government. Whatever stance one has with regard to asylum seekers who come to Australia, any individual with a sense of humanity must acknowledge that children are the innocent participants who are caught in a situation which is not of their making.

The amendments that were foreshadowed ask those moderate Liberals on the other side of this House to start where there can be no disputeâthat is, by getting kids out from behind the razor wire. Why is it important? Children are the most vulnerable of all social groups. They do not have access to the means of exerting power, nor are they capable of protecting themselves. They are restricted in the extent to which they are able to make decisions about their lives. They do not play any part in the processes which determine the policies that affect them. How do we know the Australian detention centres are inhumane places for children to live? The Damaging kids report, published by the Catholic Commission for Justice, Development and Peace in May 2002, was the first paper to really document the extremely high rates of self-harm in Australian detention centres and the harrowing psychological impact of detention on the children living in these centres in Australia. Life for children in Australian immigration detention centres means being under constant video surveillance. It means being addressed by a number and not by a name. It means having no playing facilities. It means sharing meagre recreation space with angry, often dejected and frequently suicidal adults.

Think about the case of Shayan Badraie. We all heard about his fate last week in this House and saw the harrowing pictures on Four Corners. He was exposed to violence and to constant contact with despondent, depressed adults. He had been so disturbed by his experiences at Woomera Detention Centre that he had stopped eating and drinking. In a new report, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission president recommended that the federal government pay the Badraie family $70,000 for Shayan's pain and suffering and the costs of ongoing psychiatric counselling for post-traumatic stress disorder. In this report, the president also said that the minister should apologise in writing to the family for his department's mishandling of this boy's care and its decision to ignore expert psychiatric advice. Doctors had urged that alternative accommodation be found for Shayan and his family, but the advice was ignored.

The parents of this boy will now launch a legal action against the minister. Many cases will follow if we do not act now. But it is not the threat of court cases that should force the minister to act; this is about basic humanity and compassion. We cannot begin to imagine what these children have already suffered in their own countries. How can we allow their trauma to be intensified by being locked in these camps? Instead of providing an environment where healing can occur, we perpetuate the trauma.

Two women in my electorate have worked as nurses in Woomera. Earlier this year, they came to see me as they were devastated by what they had experienced. They told me of the impact that detention was having on children, that almost all the children they saw experienced severe developmental delay, were well below normal weight and height measures for children of their age and culture and that they frequently bed-wet. They told me of children clinging to them, as they were desperate to stay in the nurses' station rather than be returned to the yards. They told me of children traumatised by the constant checks conducted during the night that meant they rarely got more than two hours consecutive sleep. These women had no barrow to push with the government. They had no barrow to push in relation to immigration policy. All they had was their judgement, their years of professional experience and their fundamental decency as community members who believe that children should never be treated like this.

The Australian public would still be almost completely in the dark about the situation inside Australian detention centres had it not been for Labor's effort in demanding that the government allow the Independent Detention Advisory Committee access to these centres. It was Labor who called for the Independent Detention Advisory Committee to have admittance to the Woomera detention centre on 21 January this year, one day before the minister permitted the visit. The regional representative of the UNHCR described Australia's mandatory detention system on 29 July this year as the most severe in the Western world. After a five-day visit to Woomera detention centre, HREOC came to the conclusion that children were being inadequately educated and that the health services and general living standards were poor. The organisation reported 13 threats of self-harm, five lip sewings, one attempted hanging and three self-slashings in just two weeks. One 14-year-old was reported to have sewn his lips twice and slashed the word `freedom' into his arm. Children in our detention centres are being deprived of basic human rights such as adequate education and opportunities for safe play and development. How much more criticism is needed for the government to change its stance? A consistent, lasting and more humane policy is urgently needed.

The public release of the evaluation of the Woomera alternate detention trial on 20 August 2002 demonstrated the success of more humane arrangements for mothers and children. The project established by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs enables some women and their children to live in family style accommodation whilst still being in detention. The Australian Labor Party and the Howard government's own independent advisory body, the Immigration Detention Advisory Group, proposed to expand the Woomera alternate detention trial to family groups, including fathers and older male children. If, according to the minister's assessment, this alternative was successful, why has it not yet been extended? Why does the Howard government continue to insist on locking up children behind razor wire? The amendments foreshadowed today are designed to meet the needs of children without endangering the health and security of Australians. Labor has drafted the amendments with precisely this balance in mind. It seems necessary to emphasise this point because one of the Howard government's almost constant excuses for its lack of activity with regard to the fate of innocent children has been the issue of security. There have been no security problems with the Woomera alternative detention trial. No-one has absconded from the trial. The 25 women and children involved in the detention trial lived in former Defence housing under ACM supervision. As the women and children are still formally in detention, they are not able to freely come and go.

Moreover, the Howard government is engaging in a campaign to deliberately dehumanise asylum seekers in the eyes of the Australian community and to create a climate of fear. The most immediate victims of this strategy are the children. It seems to make a lot more senseâand this is one of Labor's aimsâto seek to promote community understanding of the facts about asylum seekers. When these amendments were first foreshadowed, the minister responded by saying they were ridiculous and would lead to endless litigation. He claimed that Labor's definition of `unaccompanied detained child' would lead to endless litigation, yet this is exactly the definition the minister included in his ministerial response last week. While it can be argued that the government has a duty of care for all children in detention centres, the minister for immigration is the guardian of and has responsibility for children in detention. How can the minister claim to meet his responsibility in this regard when he locks up these children and young people in detention centres managed by a privately contracted company? How can the government, falsely or otherwise, accuse parents of abuse when it now has more power to change the situation for these children than their parents do, and yet fails to do anything about the systems of abuse and neglect that it perpetuates?

The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, representing the minister, has the duty to care for all detainees and the ultimate responsibility for their welfare, although day-to-day operations are contracted out to ACM. If any parent or guardian acted in the way the Australian government has towards children in immigration centres, they would be immediately subject to child care and protection orders. It is not hard to imagine how history will judge the holding of children at detention centres or how it will judge the government responsible. Liberal moderate members of this House have a clear choice: vote for Labor's foreshadowed amendments and get kids out of detention or do nothing and be judged accordingly. If your pressure has already resulted in a small step forward you should keep that pressure up. You should stand and be counted on this issue and vote with Labor on our amendments.

talk.start.para: âThe Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 is an omnibus bill that amends the Migration Act 1958 with the purpose of changing aspects of the Australian legal regime in relation to visas, creating a deputy principal member for the Migration Review Tribunal, harmonising the Criminal Code and relevant offences under the act and making some minor technical amendments. The main provision of the bill deals with the immigration clearance status of non-citizen children born in Australia. Item 1 of schedule 1 deals with birth entry and immigration status. The Bills Digest says:

quote.para: A non-citizen child who is born in the `migration zone' is taken to have `entered Australia' when s/he was born (section 10).

speech.para: There would be little dispute over that statement. To the extent that this amendment deals with children of parents who are seeking immigration rights in Australiaâbe they boat people, unauthorised arrivals, refugees or whatever we might call themâthe amendments raise many contentious issues that have been the subject of a great deal of political debate over the past year, for example, children overboard, children in detention and boat people fatalities. To this end, the shadow minister for immigration and population has foreshadowed an amendment: a new schedule 7, `Immigration detentionâSpecial arrangements for children', which clarifies the terms `appropriate qualified child protection officer', `detained children' and `unaccompanied detained children'. The amendment also calls for the release from detention of unaccompanied detained children into the care of a foster family or other appropriate community based care arrangements determined by an appropriately qualified child protection officer.

In this ongoing debate on asylum seekers, the issue that was first addressed by the Labor Party was the issue of children in detention. Although the government have now moved to introduce guidelines for such children, this has only come about after the Labor Party advocated the release of children from detentionâindeed, it has been the official Labor Party policy to remove children from behind the razor wire since Simon Crean's Australia Day speech in January this year. If the government were serious about the issue, they would not simply issue guidelines regarding children; they would support the amendment moved by the shadow minister, the member for Lalor, that would enshrine in legislation a more humane policy regarding children in detention. Issues relating to children cannot be seen as separate from Australia's general policy on refugees and asylum seekers.

In their first five years in office, the federal government have been able to turn their neglect of the issue of asylum seekers into a political plusâan achievement, I am sure, that would have the admiration of all political opportunists no matter how deceitful their policy was. From the time the Howard government came to office in March 1996 until the arrival of MV Tampa in August 2001 on the eve of the federal election, no fewer than 213 unauthorised boats with 11,513 people arrived in the Australian migration zone. These arrivals were dotted right around the west and east coasts of Australia, as far south as Port Kembla. It was saidâfacetiously, I would suggestâthat these refugees were seeking employment in the steel industry. At no time during those five years did the Prime Minister clench his fist and cry, `We will decide who comes to this country.' He saved it for the fear-and-smear election campaign.

Just to refresh your memory, Madam Deputy Speaker Gambaro, and the memory of other members, a couple of newspaper articles appeared in the state press prior to the last federal election. On 8 November 2001, an article by Tom Allard and Andrew Clennell was headed `Howard links terrorism to boat people'. The article said:

quote.para: The Prime Minister linked the terrorist threat to asylum seekers yesterday as Coalition advertisements attacking Labor's boat people policies reached near-saturation levels.

speech.para: Further on it said:

quote.para: Mr Howard said: âThere is a possibility some people having links with organisations that we don't want in this country might use the path of asylum seekers in order to get here.â He also drew a comparison between the current situation and the refugees influx after World War II. âQuite properly people got concerns when they thought war criminals, in the rush after World War II were allowed in,â he told the Brisbane Courier-Mail. Mr Howard stressed that he had no evidence the recent boats turned away from Australia contained any terrorists or undesirables but, by the same token, there could be no âguaranteesâ that there weren't.

speech.para: As the previous speaker, the member for Ballarat, said, that was quite clearly an attempt to dehumanise refugees. In an earlier article in the Sydney Morning Herald, on 19 September, Mike Seccombe said:

quote.para: People of good conscience on all sides of politics have no doubt that the aim of everything the Government has done over the past couple of months has been to generate irrational fear amongst Australians over Islamic asylum seekers.

speech.para: That same article made reference to comments by members of the government at that particular time, including Peter Reith's `none-too-subtle suggestions that boat people arriving in Australia included potential terrorists'. At this point, there were some uncomplimentary remarks about the member for Fisher, who said:

quote.para: âThere is an undeniable link between illegals and terrorism.â

speech.para: It is difficult to get around that statement and to not understand exactly what is going on. I repeat:

quote.para: âThere is an undeniable link between illegals and terrorists.â

speech.para: That is what the member for Fisher is quoted as saying. The article goes on to say:

quote.para: We checked with the office of the Immigration Minister. The nearest thing they could point to was one refugee who had once been a member of the intelligence service of the previous Afghani governmentâthat's the one overthrown by the Taliban, with whom we are effectively at war.

speech.para: That was the background of the last federal election campaign, on which the government's refugee policy is based. As in so many of the recent security breaches, such as the Bali bombing and the refugee issue, the government should have known earlier what was happening and should have acted quickly. It seems that it was more interested in Centrelink breaches than in security breaches. The fact is that the Howard government should have been more aware of the international issues that would result in an increase in the number of refugees arriving in Australia. The fact that the government failed to act means that people smugglers have been able to convince refugees to take this dangerous journey. If there is an allegation to be levelled about who is soft on people smugglers, the answer is clearly the Howard government during its first two terms in office.

The international issues the government should have been aware ofâand quite clearly they were not or they did not act on themâwere the closing of borders in European countries; the consolidation of the Taliban in much of Afghanistan, leading to the displacement of hundreds of thousands of Afghanis; the continued oppression in Iraq; and, most importantly, the growth of people-smuggling, with smugglers promoting Australia as a favourable destination. The facts are that the numbers of unauthorised arrivals that culminated in the Tampa incident had been because of the policy vacuum in the Howard government for the previous five years. Over this period, the Howard government should have secured agreement in our region to detect and destroy the people-smuggling rings and to deter forward transit by asylum seekers. How the doctrine of cooperation with our neighbours sits with the doctrine of pre-emptive strikes is yet to be determinedâ`We want your cooperation on boat people, but we will invade you if we perceive a terrorist threat.'

Australia did not secure any form of agreement on asylum seekers with Indonesia until it was too late. Indeed, Indonesia has still not made people-smuggling a criminal offence. The federal government's rather relaxed attitude to asylum seekers changed abruptly on 27 August 2001, when the polls showed that they were set to lose the election and when the Australian Search and Rescue broadcast a call to any merchant ship in the vicinity to render assistance to the stricken vessel, the KM Palapa 1. The Norwegian merchant vessel Tampa responded to the call, intercepted the sinking Palapa and took its passengers aboard. The master of the Tampa, Captain Arne Rinnan, had intended to take the people rescued to a port in Indonesia. The rescued asylum seekers demanded to go to Christmas Island, which proves that these people knew exactly where they were heading and justifies the ALP's position in retaining Christmas Island as a processing centre for boat people.

Due to the government's failure to respond adequately to the human suffering of people, particularly children, arriving in Australia unauthorised, the ALP has decided that any unaccompanied children under 14 will be placed in the care of foster families after health checks are completed. Unaccompanied young people between 14 and 18 will be released into appropriate community care arrangements following health checks. Concern has been expressed about the contradiction in the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs being the legal guardian of unaccompanied minors while at the same time being the minister for detention and processing claims. Under Labor's new asylum seeker policy, such children will not be detained and, to avoid any perceived conflict of interest, Labor will make its proposed children's commissioner the legal guardian of unaccompanied minors who arrive unauthorised in Australia.

This is one area of policy we must get right as a nation. We must balance the security of our borders with humane and decent treatment of asylum seekers. For too long the government has vilified and denigrated those who seek to come to our country, fleeing persecution, war, famine, drought and all kinds of misery. This is not the Australian way. The second verse of our national anthem says, `For those who come across the sea, we've boundless plains to share.' Obviously that means only if you are not poor and fleeing trouble. Maybe the government will be rewriting our national anthem soon.

The government's policy in this area, as in many others, is skewed towards punishment. In the stick and carrot approach, the government always seems to favour the stickâthere is no balance. The policy paper that was released last week by the member for Lalor, the shadow minister for population and immigration, seeks to restore the balance between deterrence and compassion. Government is not only about following popular opinion; it is about leading the debate and leading public opinion. There is a great deal of mistrust amongst asylum seekers. There is a great deal of misinformation in the general community. The government needs to respond to both. There are legitimate concerns that need to be addressed, but there also needs to be considerable debate based on fact, not on spin. The government has whipped up a fear and smear campaign on this issue, using half-truths and untruths. That must end. The `children overboard' disgrace is only one example of where the government has failed the people of Australia. It has failed to be honest in its dealings with the Australian people. It has failed in the most basic function of government and leadershipâthat is, trust.

Labor's policy is balanced, addressing the concerns of the community over issues such as border protectionâprotecting Australia. It also addresses the need for compassion when dealing with the misery of human existence far from our shores. That is the Australian way. The amendments moved by the shadow minister have forced the government to change its policy on children in detention. The minister has now issued guidelines. If he were truly interested in a compassionate and humane solution to this problem, he would support the amendments that would see unaccompanied minors taken out from behind the razor wire and treated with dignity.

Bipartisanship does not mean blind adherence. It does not mean accepting everything the government says without question. It means working together in a constructive manner to achieve common goals. This is an area where Labor has always sought bipartisanship, but it is also an area where the government has sought anything but. The government does not want cooperation on this issue because it wants to use it as a political tool to score political points. It is too important an issue for that, but that has not stopped the government from using asylum seekers as political footballs to kick around for the pleasure of spectators. Since the release of Labor's policy, I have watched in question time, with dorothy dixer after dorothy dixer, the minister's attempts to rubbish our policy.

Quite frankly, the minister has not been all that successful in his attempts to tear it down. He has not been able to put the hatchet through the policy because, deep down, I think he knows we have some good points. The more enthusiastic he gets about attacking our policy, the more convinced I am that we are actually on the right track. Quite frankly, you look pretty silly trying to rubbish a good idea, and the minister knows this. He has gone through the motions but he has not really laid a glove on the policy in the last week or so. Interest groups such as the Australians for Just Refugee Programs, the Refugee Council of Australia, the Catholic Commission for Justice, Development and Peace, the Coalition for the Reform of Refugee Policy, the Uniting Church and the Brotherhood of St Laurence have all given the Labor Party policy a tick of approval as a major step forward in policy development.

Protecting Australia and protecting the Australian wayâthat is what it is all about. While the government seems taken with the first part, it seems to care nothing about the second part. It is all about balance. Labor has found the balance: strength in border protection and compassion in dealing with our fellow human beings. This bill will not be opposed, but this government is on notice: it must amend its strategy and again find the balance that this issue requiresâthe balance it has lost in the darkness of political opportunismâor it will suffer the consequences.

talk.start.para: âI support the remarks tonight of my colleague the member for Greenway, in his contribution to the House in the debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. I know that the government has responded at long lastâand I am pleased to see that the minister is in the Houseâto the human rights subcommittee's report on detention centres. I must say that I am very pleased to have been a member of that subcommittee. We waited until the Joint Standing Committee on Migration did a review of detention centres, and it brought down a report recommending some structural changes to those centres. I am pleased to say that the Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade was the first committee of the parliament to actually speak to detainees without any departmental people or ACM people present, and in camera.

speech.para: In some ways, that has been a tragic mistakeâbut let me say why it was done. It was done because we wanted the detainees to be able to speak frankly to the committee without any fear associated with their contributions. A lot of what goes on in detention centres is hidden from the publicâon the false proposition that it protects the privacy of detaineesâwhen detainees really want to tell their story. The last thing they want is privacy. If we were doing the inquiry again, I would say that, beginning with our interviews with all the detainees at each of the detention centres, I would give them the choice: keep it totally in camera or, if you do not want it in camera, we will make it public. I can only speculate on what the response might be, but I am pretty sure that the detainees would want it on the public record.

It was a very powerful experience, and I would say that all, whether they were Labor, Liberal or Democrat, were affected deeply by what they saw and heard. It is a matter of record that Minister Ruddock viciously attacked principally the coalition members when they brought down the report for a lack of rigour in what they did. Let me say what we did do. We spoke to the department and we were briefed by the department in camera before we embarked on these visitsâthe same with ACM. At each detention centre, we were briefed again by the department and ACM and had interviews with the detainees in camera. When we came back, we had eight hours of hearings with both the department and ACM after those visits in camera, just to give them an opportunity to correct the record, to get it right, to set the record straight. In the minister's mind, this is a lack of process and a lack of rigour on behalf of the committee. I think the committee brought down a very good report. As I say, it was viciously attacked by the minister.
I want to address some of the minister's responses. Recommendation 8 states:

motion.para: That the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation develop an appropriate risk profile to assist the early release into the Australian community of asylum seekers.

speech.para: The government says it is `confident' about `the existing process'. That is fair enough, but you need to understand that the committee spoke to the Director-General of ASIO. I cannot put before the House the transcript of that discussionâin fact, it was an in camera discussion and only notetakers' notes were takenâbut, Minister, rest assured that the committee did not override the Director-General of ASIO in its recommendation. Can I be plainer than that? I guess ministers can override directors, but I would have thought one would do so very reluctantly when it is the head of ASIO. I find your response very dismissive of what was, I think, a very constructive proposal by the committee.

We supported the minister's trial at Woomera. The committee supported it and welcomed it, and it put that in its report. I think it is fair enough to say that there was considerable debate within the committee about whether we should go further than that trial. In the end, we wanted to give credit to the minister for conducting the trialâa very limited trial, I might say, of a number of mothers and their children in a security compound comprising a number of houses. We certainly considered going a lot further. In fact, it is only in recent times that the minister has indicated that he is going to extend this very limited trial. For example, we have built a completely new detention centre at Baxter, and there are no such facilities. The newest detention centre at Baxter does not provide for this trial.

There are a couple of other things I want to say. The committee recommended critically that we should use the 14 weeks as a benchmark, but let me explain that to the House, because, with great respect to the minister, I think he sometimes dissembles on this point. His departmentâthat is, DIMIAâis funded to process these applications within a time line. From memory, at that time it was 14 weeks. The committee never recommended that, if someone was in detention and that time line was exceeded, they be automatically taken out of the detention centre. That has been a fabrication. I want to be perhaps a bit more generous and say: if it is not a fabrication, it has been a gross misunderstanding of what the committee was talking about.

We also talked about negotiating with appropriate community groups to examine the feasibility of developing a sponsorship scheme for detainees who have not been processed within the time limit. Again, the minister uses the Joint Standing Committee on Migration report and an earlier report done in 1994 to bucket this recommendation. But this is the same committee that never spoke to detainees in detention centres on their own. They always had a representative group, departmental officials or ACM officials present.
I find the government's response to recommendation 13 staggering. This recommendation says:

motion.para: That, wherever possible, blocks within detention centres be designated for the exclusive use of families.

speech.para: The government's response was:

quote.para: The IDCs at Perth, Villawood and Maribyrnong all contain designated areas for women, children and family groups.

speech.para: Minister, you are at the table now. Tell me: when were the family group facilities provided at Perth? We were told by your department and the person you have now promoted to deputy secretary that Perth, because of its tight constraints, is very temporary. We were told that if women go there, they are moved out quickly. We were told that families are not kept at Perth. Perth is so small, Madam Deputy Speaker; I invite you to go and have a look at it. It is very constrained. I am sure the shadow minister would agree with me that the facilities there are very, very constricting.

I am surprised, in a way, that we are debating this bill and the shadow minister's amendments, which address the issue of children in detention centres, so close to one of the holiest of Christian holy days. Forgive me, I am not being born again, but I would like to read a quote from Matthew about the flight into Egypt and the massacre of the innocents:

quote.para: After they had left, the angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream and said, `Get up and take the child and his mother with you and escape into Egypt, and stay there until I tell you, because Herod intends to search for the child and do away with him.' So Joseph got up and, taking the child and his mother with him, left that night for Egypt, where he stayed until Herod was dead.

speech.para: In other words, the holy family were refugees. They were refugees from the massacre of all male Jewish children two years and younger in the vicinity of Bethlehem. If they had come to Australia rather than Egypt, the best we would have done at Woomera would have been to put Mary and Jesus in a secure compound and leave Joseph in a detention centre. If Jesus was unaccompaniedâthe minister, I know, has made some recent announcements about thisâand a tad older, I would suggest that the conditions would not be pleasant. I guess the Labor Party, to paraphrase Moses, is saying: let the children go. Let the children out of the detention centres.

I do not want to single out for condemnation a colleague, the member for Cook, who came along on the detention centres visit, but he was the one on the committeeânot unexpectedly, because he is a trained psychologistâwho was really concerned about the mental health impacts on kids of being in detention centres.

I know that at the end of the report there was all this lovely guff from the department. As the former member for Throsby would say, `These detention centres are like Butlins holiday camps in the desert'. Everyone is playing basketball or cricket or at a sewing machine or a computer. I can honestly tell you that, at every detention centre I visited, I did not see one person engaged in any game. You could say that maybe that was just bad luck, but how do you play soccer at Woomera on the broken ground?

The other issue that was of great concern to committee membersâand I pay tribute to Senator Harradine here too because it was a point that he pursued vigorouslyâwas the education of the kids in the detention centres. Those managing the centres said, `Yes, we follow a state curriculum.' Now if we say about a public school or a Catholic school that they follow a state curriculum, what does that mean? It means that there are certain hours by way of compulsory attendance, that a curriculum is followed and that progress is made and monitored. It is true that there are teachers at these detention centres, and even at Baxter. But the notion that somehow the children there are happily progressing along the South Australia curriculum is utterly fictitious. I do not know how the department can serve up such drivel.

I have another point to make. I accept that the Mayor of Port Augusta has not made life easy and I do not support her comments, but if you are opening the newest detention centre in Australia, would you not think that you would have a memorandum of understanding with the South Australia government so that these kids could go to a public school or a Catholic school and at least get out of the detention centre? How cruel it is to have some children who were in Curtin go to a public school there and then, when you send them to Baxter, not allow them out.

I want to say a couple of things about Baxter. Baxter is an utter contradiction, and it is a contradiction for these reasons. If you look at the facilities that detainees have, the ones at Baxter are a lot better without a doubt than those in other detention centres, and I would not want to quibble in that regard. But there is a certain cruelty that has been designed into Baxter. By the way, I might say that we had a new DIMIA manager when we were there. He was very helpful and very politeâI am not being criticalâbut he was only three days on the job when we were there, and the ACM manager was only a week on the job. I wonder why those two people were changed at about the time the Human Rights Subcommittee were to visit them. That is mere speculation, I want to say. I am merely speculating.

But why is Baxter designed in cruelty? At some of the other detention centres, detainees are able to mix. The people at Baxter have been in detention centres for many months and in some cases years. Where they were mixing at other detention centres, now they are at Baxter where there are nine compounds and they do not get to mix; at compound one, you know the people in compound one. Also, the compound is turned in on itself. Just in case they should wish to look at the Baxter mountain escarpmentâand there is that opportunityâthe government have installed frosted glass windows. These are not big windows. They areâhow would I describe them?ârelatively small rectangular things, but there is an opportunity to see out.

talk.start.para: âBathroom windows.
âWell, why is it that no-one can see out?
âBathroom windows aren't meant to let people look in either.

âBut why design a facility where you cannot see out of the compound? Go through the gates at Baxter. They are a double set of gates where one gate has to close before another can open. I take an interest in defence matters, and I think these gates would certainly stop a Bushranger, an ASLAV. I am not so sure about a tank, but I think the posts would give it a good work over. The compound is thoroughly depressing, Minister, and I think you are better than that. I think you can do a lot better than that.

speech.para: The minister says in his response that there is any amount of scrutiny of detention centres. He fails to understand that many of the problems and criticisms of detention centres come from a lack of scrutiny. We argued for an official visitor program; he rejects it. He says there is an ombudsman and HREOCâof course, the government have cut their fundingâand, yes, they are available to do it. I am pleased that in our new Labor policy we have an inspector-general of detention centres who can do his or her own motion inquiries, he can do an inquiry on behalf of the minister and he can respond to complaints. Yes, it is another level of scrutiny and another level of administration, but I think, in the end, it is worth while.

There are lots of things I would have liked to say about the policy associated with the Labor Party now and our shadow minister. I just want to say that, in relation to the green card, the minister has never prosecuted one employer for employing an illegal migrant. You have not prosecuted one in all the years. You will send the illegal worker back to their country of originâas you shouldâbut you let the one who profits most, the one who exploits these workers, walk free and hide, and our green card is going to fix that. Our green card will target the employers who exploit this labour, and it will ensure that they get their fair measure of justice for their illegal activity, as well as the illegal worker who you now send back. I support the policy enunciated by the Labor Party on these issues. (Time expired)

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: âin replyâFirstly, let me thank the members who have contributed to this debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. Obviously, I do not agree with all of the comments that have been made. I will not try to canvass them all, although I do acknowledge my friend the member for Chifley, and I will certainly try to clarify the issues in relation to Perth. It is the case that we have been endeavouring to provide accommodation for family groups separate to others. Perth has always been a challenge, not only because of the nature and size of the detention centre itself but also because of the states. Your state colleaguesâand you might like to talk to them about these mattersâare insisting that criminal deportees now be held in immigration detention. In Western Australia, they do not even acknowledge that there might be exceptional circumstances to be taken into account in whether that should happen.

speech.para: I must say that I find it strangeâI note that there is no press here, so I suppose this will not be reportedâthat premiers will sometimes write to me and they will even go to the press and argue very strongly that criminal deportation ought to be used in particular cases where there is a heinous crime. Yet perforce of the way in which detention centres have developed over a long periodâand I do not say critically that detention policy is easy, because when your colleagues were in office, only two new detention facilities were built, as I recall: one at Port Hedland, and that is a facility about which your committee has complained at least in part, and the other at Curtin, which was very much a makeshift detention facilityâgovernments have not planned over that long period and built purpose designed facilities. I might say that, when we seek to do that, as I have sought to do in Brisbane, I find I get fairly vocal opposition. The NIMBY set is very much alive, and nobody is terribly keen to have a detention centre in their district.

Forgive me, I am spending time on the member for Chifley because he was here and I am here. I heard most of his comments. I apologise to members whose comments I have not heard, but I will try to pick up some of the points that have been made during the debate. I really want to focus on thanking those who participated. I hope the bill will ultimately pass. I noticed the threat in the comments of the shadow ministerâa novel approach.

talk.start.para: âIt was a promise.
âIt was a threat.
âIt was a promise.

âPlease forgive me, but I see it as a threat. Quite frankly, in my view it is better to work to be elected than to think you are a government in exile. We were elected to make decisions, administer policy and maintain effective administration. Holding the Migration Act in this country hostage to a political tactic is I think quite an inappropriate approach to take.

speech.para: The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 does a number of important things. It clarifies the visa status of non-citizen children born in Australia. It clarifies that security can be taken before a visa is granted to ensure compliance with conditions. That is fairly important in many cases, otherwise they might not get the outcome they might be seeking. It enables the cancellation of a special purpose visa where it is undesirable for the holder to travel to or remain in Australia, with cancellation taking effect from the time of the minister's declaration. Special purpose visas are of a unique character; they are issued in extraordinary circumstances, and there ought to be a capacity to cancel them. The bill creates a deputy principal member position for the Migration Review Tribunal. Given the workload required for the proper management of the issues, this is also an important matter. The bill ensures that certain offence provisions operate as they did prior to the application of the Criminal Code. I foreshadowed that I would be moving amendments in the committee stage to give effect to recommendations of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee. I hope that the opposition will accede to those amendments, as they were party to them.

This debate has been designed to address one issue: whether the opposition, if it were in government, would be better able than the government to handle detention policy, particularly as it relates to family groups. I notice that the shadow minister wants to claim he originated some unique developments that have occurred in relation to detention policy in Australia. I have to say that the Leader of the Opposition's speech on Australia Day 2002 had nothing to do with the alternative detention model that was implemented in August 2001. The fact is that this government was thinking constructively about the way we deal with issues relating to women and children in detention. You probably know of the young man by the name of Mitchell, I think it was, from Hothamâ

talk.start.para: âHis name was Grant Mitchell.

âYes; Grant Mitchell, from the Hotham Mission. I give him credit because he raised, at a public meeting I addressed in Melbourne, issues in relation to the way detention is dealt with in Sweden. In cases where it was seen as appropriate to detain people there were arrangements for women and childrenânot whole family groups; women and childrenâto be detained in an alternative way. My view was that we should look at whether that would work in Australia. With the department, we developed the alternative detention model.

speech.para: The reason we did it in the way we did was quite clear: we wanted to ensure the detention policy was not undermined. You could release whole family groups, but there would be a greater likelihood of total family groups living in low-security facilities adjacent to the camp than there would be if one member of the family remained detained. That system has worked. The opposition thinks you can deduce from the fact that the trial has worked the view that releasing whole families would be equally effective. Whether it is or it is not, my greater concern is the impression that would be left with those likely to engage people smugglers. I think they see very vocal change in relation to important aspects of policy as an unwinding of policy in Australia, and see that as a signal that maybe their operations can be picked up and run again. So I am unwilling, for reasons I include in the letter to the Leader of the Opposition, to entertain the amendments proposed by the Labor Party.

The reason is very simple. It arises from the experience I have referred to before, when the opposition was in office and Gerry Hand was the minister. It related to setting arbitrary time limits for processing. The import of that was that, once you put in place provisions that impose certain obligations upon government that could be manipulated by detainees and their advisersâparticularly with the level of cooperation they might give to processingâpeople could simply wait out the time and then expect to be released. That is what happened in Western Australia. People waited out the time, there was some ambiguity about the time, they sued, and the Australian taxpayer was left to pay quite large damages claims for false imprisonment. So I regard an important aspect of the issue to be the introduction into the act of obligations expressed with so little room to move in appropriate circumstancesâin other words, they become mandatory in themselvesâthat you have the potential for litigation over the way they are applied.

In relation to implementing mandatory detention, the present legislation as drafted by the Labor Party provides very little scope for litigation over the circumstances in which people are held. The legislation was deliberate because of the nature of the litigation. You are proposing administrative complexities that would give rise to the prospect of increased litigation. Where do I think that might happen? When people come here without birth certificates, the only information you have as to their age is what they themselves tell you. Do you have scope for people wanting to dispute age? We have already had litigation over the methods by which you try to determine whether or not someone is cheating you, and in relation to people who have been prosecuted for smuggling and whether or not they are minors. We have had litigation over measuring their risk and whether the scientific techniques are sufficiently sound to enable very clear evidence to be given in relation to those matters.

There is a range of other issues that could arise. Reference has been made to an eight-year-old who was, for a time, in detention. The circumstances were that the child was initially in foster arrangements in Woomera, with families there. They were released on temporary protection visas, and assessments had to be made as to whether the child could be released with them. In the case of one of the families with whom the child had the prospect of being released, there was an adverse assessment of the proposed parent by the relevant state authority. It certainly took time for that issue to be addressed. I will not say it was an inordinately long time, but looking at the notes before me it took, I think, five months from the time that the child arrived at Woomera until the child was in fact released into foster care arranged by the South Australian authorities. Under the arrangements that we have in place, the eight-year-old was ultimately released and is now on a temporary protection visa. There was consultation with the relevant state authorities. I cannot imagine that that would have taken any longer than if people had litigated over those issuesâif they wanted to use the sort of statutory provision that you have in mind.

The basis proposed for releasing family groups does not have regard to the sorts of factors that were mentioned in the miscellaneous series of instructions that I have given to the department on the way this issue is to be dealt with. Certainly, health and security clearances are important, but there is a range of other issues that are also important in relation to the management of people. There is also the question of the availability of accommodation. It is interesting that comment has been made about the availability of accommodation at Baxter. I have certainly foreshadowed in discussions I have had with the state government from very early this year that at Baxter we wanted to have children in local schools, where appropriate, as well as an alternative detention model operating. The state government are sayingâand fairly late on the sceneâthat the only way in which they are going to be a party to these issues is with consultation.

However, when there had been very extensive consultation between the local school community and the school principals, when children were preparing to enrol in the local school, and I had told the mayor which school and when we were going to undertake their enrolmentâand had indicated to her that that was under way and there had been consultationsâwhat happened? The Premier of South Australia, the day he headed off on a three-week overseas trip, called off the participation of the children in the school. He has said that some other form of consultation now has to take place. Here is the Labor Party parading its virtues in this area, but the Labor Party is more than the Labor Party here; it is the Labor Party in all of its manifestations. All I can say is that the sort of cooperation I would have expectedâwith a reasonable amount of goodwillâhas not been forthcoming.

I have made it clear that I think you do need to have some capacity to make judgments about what is going to happen in an alternative detention system where there is minimum security. It is not a matter of having light beams and some detention officers living around the corner so you can say you have a high security facility, as the opposition seems to suggest would be appropriate; it is a matter of having regard to a whole range of issues. There are a lot of dynamics that you have to take into account with human beings, and some judgments have to be made. The instructions that I have given enable those judgments to be made in relation to women and children. They are quite precise but they recognise some of the administrative problems. The opposition is proposing a rigidity that would pay no regard to those sorts of factors. In that sense, we cannot accede to the amendments proposed, but I ask the opposition to see the importance of giving passage to the legislation and giving the measures that I have sought to implement an opportunity to operate and to make sensible judgments on them.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Billâby leaveâtaken as a whole.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move opposition amendments (1) and (2):

quote.para: (1) As soon as possible after the commencement of detention under section 189, a detained child must be accommodated with his or her family members in immigration detention conditions which meet the same amenity and security standards as are required by the Woomera Alternative Detention Arrangements for Women and Children operated by the Department from 7 August 2001.
