speech.para: The amendments to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002, which have been moved in my name, deal with the question of children in immigration detention. I want to briefly outline to the House the details of them. These amendments provide that for an unaccompanied detained childâa detained child who does not have a guardian with them, and we have used the definition of non-citizen child arising out of the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946âthe government would be compelled as a matter of law, as soon as possible after the commencement of detention, under section 189 of the Migration Act to release that unaccompanied detained child into the care of a foster family or other appropriate community based care arrangement, determined by an appropriately qualified child protection officer.

I want to clarify this point, because I have not had the opportunity to raise this with the ministerâand I understand that it might be causing some consternation. These amendments were revised arising from a contribution from you, Deputy Speaker Gambaro, when it became apparent that the referencing in the first section, which read `released in accordance with section 198', ought to have read `released in accordance with division 7B'âso that is the change in this version of the amendments. That change was required to make it clear that what we are talking about in these amendments is that unaccompanied children, when they arrive in Australia, would be put in immigration detention but, as soon as possible, an unaccompanied detained child must be released from that detention into the care of a foster family or into another appropriate community based care arrangement.

In moving this I ask the House to noteâand the minister has gone to the question of discretion and other thingsâthat we have made sure that there is a catch-all and we have specifically provided that nothing in the subsection which requires that release from detention requires the taking of any action which would cause a health or security risk to Australia. We are putting forward a scheme where a government would be compelled to release an unaccompanied detained child from detention as soon as possible into an appropriate foster or community based care arrangement, but we have been careful to make sure that no governmentâthis government, a future Labor government or any governmentâis required to take any action which would cause a health or security risk to Australia.

These amendments provide that a child with family members, if the child is to be detainedâand it is important to note that this is not a release from detention issue; this is a conditions of detention issueâneeds to be detained in certain settings. We have defined that setting as meeting the amenity and security standards of the Woomera alternative detention trial arrangements. As I explained in my contribution on the bill, we know that that is a secured facility. The minister can make light of light beams and the rest of it, but we know that this is a facility with fencing, with security on the perimeter, so if you break the light by trying to jump the fence you will sound an alarm. And there is 24-hour a day guard presence. We are talking about children and their families living in immigration detention in those kinds of conditions. Once again, the provision that we have moved has the catch-all in it that no governmentâthis government or a future Labor governmentâwould be required to take any action which would cause a health or security risk to Australia.

These amendments strike an appropriate balance between meeting the needs of children and meeting security needs. At the end of the day, the minister has talked about the diversity of human needs and, surely, the key human needs to be met here are the needs of children. We are saying we do not think it is appropriate for children, unaccompanied or children with family groups, to be held over the longer term in high-security detention compounds as we now know them in the form of Woomera, Baxter or Port Hedland. We have put before the House a better way of dealing with that and one which does not raise any security issues. It has a catch-allâin making sure that no government is required to take any step which would cause a security concern to Australia and in talking about immigration detention conditions for families which are secured. (Extension of time granted)

This will be my final contribution. I understand that my colleague the member for Gellibrand, the shadow minister for children and youth, would also like to make a contribution. This is a schema of arrangements that meets our needs to deal with people in an Australian way, to deal with people in a way that is guided by fairness and decency and most particularly to deal with children properly. It means that unaccompanied children would need to be released from detention and children with family groups would need to be accommodated in secure conditions, but conditions which are better for family groups than those currently occurring now. I do not accept, and I do not believe, it can be reasonably argued that this opens up any security issue. In that regard, members of the minister's own Immigration Detention Advisory Group have endorsed the concepts of unaccompanied children being released from immigration detention and children with family groups living in settings like the Woomera alternative detention trial. Shortly, this House will divide on these amendments and it is perhaps a pity that we are having this debate at this time of night. The reason we are having this debate is that we want to see who in this House is prepared to support a different style of arrangement for childrenâwho is concerned about children in immigration detention.

I have never claimed that the Leader of the Opposition's speech on Australia Day caused the alternative Woomera detention trial. Of course that is not right. But I do claim that this amendment caused last week's ministerial statement. It is on the public record that that ministerial statement was made because of the proposition that some Liberal moderates were going to cross the floor and vote for this amendment. In the time remaining to me, I say to those Liberal moderates who put pressure on the minister to make the ministerial statement last week: your help to ensure the best possible conditions for children in detention is still needed. Firstly, we need the certainty of a legislative arrangement. The Migration Series Instructions, coming as they doâand as the minister laudsâwith bucket loads of discretion, are not good enough as a guarantee of conditions for children in detention. We need this legislative scheme. Secondly, and even more importantly, I say to the Liberal moderates who were so motivated by this issue that they put pressure on the minister to make the ministerial statement last week: we need a scheme of arrangements that keeps families together. I would have thought that in this century, in this nation, of all nations, it would be an unarguable proposition that you do families harm by splitting them up. We as a nation know that probably more than any other nation on earth because we live with the legacy of the stolen generation. Let us not contemplate making any comparable error. Family groups should be together. Mothers, fathers, brothers and sistersâthese are families.

talk.start.para: âIsn't this about unaccompanied children?

âNo, it is not about unaccompanied children, Minister. Try reading the amendments. We know you are not very bright, but try reading them. We are talking about putting family groups in an alternative detention arrangement. My simple proposition to the Liberal moderates is: do you consider that a family includes a father and older brothers? If you accept that propositionâand it is a very simple oneâit seems to me that, as a matter of logic, as a matter of morals and as a matter of ethics, you have no option but to vote for these amendments.

âI am pleased to speak to Labor's amendments. I want to do this because, as the shadow minister for children and youth, I have had a particular interest in ensuring that we do everything that we can, even in opposition, to have the most compassionate detention system that it is possible to have even while this government is in place. In these amendments, as the shadow minister has already pointed out, we have proposed a number of things, including that unaccompanied children should be placed in foster services and that children who are with their families, both mothers and fathers, should be placed in alternative low-security detention, such as hostel type or other accommodation, as appropriate.

speech.para: This has been part of a year-long campaign by a number of people on our side of parliament. Others have spoken about the Leader of the Opposition's speech on Australia Day and the very detailed work done by the shadow minister for immigration. I have tried to play some part in making a submission to the HREOC inquiry on the conditions of children held in detention. I have done this for a number of reasons. We think it is the only fair thing to do to ensure that very young children or young adults are not held in a situation which might cause long-term damage to them and which might add to their trauma. These are children who have experienced pretty traumatic lifestyles before arriving in Australia. We do not want to be in the position of contributing to the trauma that they suffer. From visiting the Maribyrnong Detention Centre, in my electorate, I have seen the issues that children face there, such as a lack of education, a lack of safety when they share facilities with criminal deportees, and this nonsense that they have adequate family rooms. Often two parents and two or three childrenâas I have seen in one situationâare in one room together, but they share all facilities with the rest of the detainees. This is not an adequate circumstance. We do not want to be in a situation where children are having to live in these circumstances. No matter what people's views might be about asylum seekers generally, no-one argues that children who arrive here can possibly be a security risk or here through some fault of their own. It is not appropriate to hold children in detention with some argument that they should share the blame, even if people hold the view that their parents might have some responsibility for bringing them here.

I am pleased that these amendments make clear that fathers also are able to live in these alternative arrangements. This is very important because it is asking families, children and their mothers, to make an impossible choice by saying to them: `Your children can be out of detention. You have to choose some form of freedom for your children, but that will mean separating the family.' It is an impossible choice to make for people who have fled in very traumatic and difficult circumstances. Where there is no reason for a father to be held in high security, we cannot see why they should not be able to have some semblance of normal life. We are talking about a pretty moderate ambition here: to have some idea of proper family housing, some capacity to cook meals and perhaps some outdoor living. This is certainly not what families are getting, even in facilities where they are able to be held together.

I have been lobbied by many of my constituents who have urged me to support these amendments. I have been lobbied by local church groups in particular, by children's welfare groups and family associations, by CAFWA and the Australian Early Childhood Association. I might also mention the Australian Council for Children and Parentingâthe government's own advisory group on the wellbeing of children and their relationship with parents. I must ask here: where has the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs been during this debate? The government and the minister are very proud that he is the first ever minister for children, but there is not much point in having a minister for children if he is not prepared to speak out on issues that affect them.

I know, and the council have reported, that they have met with both the minister for immigration and the minister for children. They have given advice about what they think is good for children. That advice is not public, but I am fairly confident that the government is not yet acting on it. (Extension of time granted) We will take close note, when there is a vote on these amendments, of what the minister for children is doing. He has been lobbied extensively by the same groups who have been talking to us and talking to me as the shadow minister. If he is interested at all in pursuing the rights of children or their interests, and their parents' interests, he will be voting with us, on this side of the House, when we vote for these amendments.

The minister has made a statementâand I think the shadow minister has already covered this. Obviously the statement goes part way but not far enough towards dealing with the issues that we raise in these amendments. I found it extraordinary that when I came into the House and the minister was speaking he said that he was disappointed that we were using this political tactic. That is pretty extraordinary in a debate like this. The minister for immigration might not be awareâbut there are plenty of us on this side of the House that are awareâthat this very Minister for Children and Youth Affairs distributed, during the election campaign, some of the most despicable material that I have ever seen about what Labor's immigration policy would mean for people living in Tweed Heads. I would not deign to repeat even some of the contents of that statement in this House. To say that Labor, when we want to actually get children out of detention and to get families living in some sort of semblance of normal family life while maintaining the security that is appropriate in these circumstances, are engaging in a political tactic, when someone will stoop as low as the current minister for children will in the materials that he will distribute in his electorate, is well and truly beyond the pot calling the kettle black.

We care about whether children are going to be in detention or not. We care about their conditions, how they are being treated and whether they are with their mothers and fathers. We do not want to contribute more to the trauma that they have already suffered. We do not think that a government should activelyâperhaps permanentlyâdamage the wellbeing of a young person, whether they are going to live in Australia in their adulthood or anywhere else. We do not think that that is what a government should do. We will be watching closely not just where the minister for children is when we vote on this but where a number of members of parliament on the other side are, because they will have to live with this for a long time if they will not support our amendment and our proposals to help get children living in far more acceptable circumstances than they currently are.

talk.start.para: âThese are thoroughly decent amendments to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. They are amendments that recognise that children arrived here in Australia under all sorts of different circumstances, and we just want to give them a chance in life. That is the truth of it: we want to give children who arrive here some sort of chance in life. There is no doubt that children who arrive in this country as asylum seekers and who are put behind razor wire are in a very prejudiced and disadvantaged position. We are moving perfectly decent and humane amendments. I know that the minister, underneath it all, has good humanity about him. I do want to refer very briefly to the 1988 debate where the minister crossed the floor. That resolution where he crossed the floor said:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) acknowledges the historic action of the Holt Government, with bipartisan support from the Australian Labor Party, in initiating the dismantling of the White Australia Policy;

talk.start.para: (Mr Lindsay)â Member for Rankin, is this relevant to the amendments?

âYes, it is, because I am going to be calling upon members of the government on this occasion, as was done on that occasion, to cross the floor on these amendments. It is a question of humanity, as it was a question of humanity in 1988. The fact is that members who are now government members crossed the floor on that occasion, and I am asking them to do so on this occasion. The rest of the resolution was that the House:

quote.para: (2) recognises that since 1973, successive Labor and Liberal/National Party Governments have, with bipartisan support, pursued a racially non-discriminatory immigration policy to the overwhelming national, and international, benefit of Australia; and

(3) gives its unambiguous and unqualified commitment to the principle that, whatever criteria are applied by Australian Governments in exercising their sovereign right to determine the composition of the immigration intake, race or ethnic origin shall never, explicitly or implicitly, be among them.

speech.para: That was a noble resolution that was moved at that time. To the credit of the immigration minister, he crossed the floor, along with the member for Goldstein, Ian Macphee, Mr Steele Hall and Senator Peter Baumeâand Mr Ian Wilson abstained on that occasion. I think the minister will recognise that they are the basic truths of the situation.

I am saying tonight that there is a new opportunity for the government to cross the floor or at least, if that is regarded as too politically embarrassingâand I could understand thatâto acknowledge these amendments and to agree to the amendments on the voices. It would be a very sad indictment of this parliament if the government could not do that. At the end of a turbulent year, when young people have been among the most victimised in the globe, with very difficult times, with terrorism, we are simply moving amendments to say, `Come on, let's get the kids out from behind the razor wire. It's Christmas. Let's show a bit of good cheer and good spirit.'

I know the government, as a result of the amendments that were foreshadowed by the member for Lalor, have had a party room meeting where they realised that they had a problem. As a result of thatâagain to the credit of the immigration ministerâsome changes were made. My concern is that those changes were made in response to a political problem, not in response to the genuine merits of the motion that was put. The government have responded but only in a very small way. Here is an opportunity tonight, before Christmas, for the government to put their credibility on the line and say, `These are good, decent and humane amendments and we will agree to them on the voices.' Make the change, Philip, for the good of young people who are locked up behind razor wire. Do the right thing: join with Labor in passing these amendments.

talk.start.para: âI want to speak in support of the two proposed amendments to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 that involve children and families. Firstly, I wish to congratulate the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs for closing down the notorious Juliet block. Juliet block was where asylum seekers from other detention centres were sent for alleged misdemeanours or what have you. We heard evidence that it was also a block in which a father and his three-year-old son were incarcerated for 23 hours out of every 24 for two weeks. That is a very shameful thing. It is disappointing that the deputy secretary to the department, in giving evidence, could not give a straight answer on whether Juliet block was a punishment block not only for adults but also for children. I am happy that the notorious Juliet block has now closed.

speech.para: In relation to unaccompanied minors, I will never forget the donga for unaccompanied minors in Woomera that, had any half decent health and building inspector gone into it, would have been closed down for overcrowding. I totally support the proposition that we should not punish the children for what we perceive as a wrongdoing that may have been done by their parents, and we should not damage them in the process. This is what we are doing. I support the two shadow ministers in their contributions. I was very pleased to go through Maribyrnong with the shadow minister for children when the committee went there. We should not make any mistakes. These amendments will benefit children. We should not care whether those children are Jewish, Christian or Muslim or about whatever religion or colour they are. They are all God's children and we all have a responsibility to them, particularly when they are unaccompanied.

We do not have national protection laws for children, much to our shame. But we do have laws in this country that give rights to children with respect to contact and access to their parents. This is at the very heart of what the shadow minister is proposing in relation to families and family groups. The proposition that we are doing something for families by taking women and children out of detention centres and separating them from their partners and fathers has always offended me. I acknowledge that it was a positive first step, but it did not go far enough. The coalition cannot campaign on the basis of the strength of its commitment to the institution of family when it believes that, when put to the test on asylum seekers, it must have a role in compulsorily separating families so that mothers and children will not have access to the father of the family.

Christmas, as I have mentioned before, is one of the holiest days in the calendar. It is about the birth and the holy family, and the family consisted of the child, Jesus, and Mary and Joseph; not just Mary and Jesus, and not just Joseph and Jesus. We would be putting them all together as a family unit. I strongly support this. If I had a Christmas wish granted, it would be to take a TV camera into these detention centres and not to have an interviewer but to just let the women talk about their experiences of being in detention with their children and of the utter despair, dismay and depression that they suffer. Go and talk to the women in Baxter because, by and large, they have been there for a couple of years. They are utterly shattered women who are seeing their families disintegrate but are powerless to do anything about it. These amendments would do something about it. I would urge you in the generosity and compassion of Christmas to support these amendments. They will help some people and children.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: âI thank my colleagues for their contributions to the debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. Having sat here and watched people cross the floor at various times, I am still waiting to see somebody from your side of the House free enough to cross the floor on a matter of conscience. There are times in which some of your colleagues on matters of conscience have felt the desire but have never been free to do that.

speech.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI do not want to argue about it. All I can tell you is that it is not easily done, and I will make one other observation. When the government has acted as positively as it has to provide a range of options that can be reasonably implemented, even if people felt stronglyâas you believe they might about these sorts of issuesâa resolution of this sort, as flawed as it is, is unlikely to get any support. On the point made earlier by the member for Chifley in relation to the Perth detention centre, I am advised that the accommodation has been increased and improved in its overall quality and that, depending upon the composition of the detainee population, it can be used for family accommodation. As a general rule, they tell me that hotel and motel accommodation has been used for short-term stays. That is the advice I have.

speech.para: I will take up the point that was made first in relation to the amendments to paragraph 196. The shadow minister suggested that it had been further amended to take into account some observations I had made in the correspondence that we have had. Let me say the advice I have is that the amendment is still inconsistent with the overall framework of the act; that is, in the act it provides for release from detention only if a visa is granted or if there is removal. In this case, it still does not provide for the granting of a visa and it is inconsistent with section 198 of the act itself.

But let me deal with the other two issues which I think are more substantial. They are the issues in proposed section 197D and 197E. The proposed amendment to section 197D in relation to unaccompanied minors, of whom I am the guardian, would require me to release them from detention. I would have no discretion as to the appropriate welfare arrangements for these children. They would be barred from consideration for placement, for instance, in the Woomera Residential Housing Project arrangement, where a close female relative may have been caring for them. That discretion would not be possible. Such an amendment to section 197D is inconsistent with the overarching framework of the act introduced by Labor in 1994. The proposed amendment to section 197D does not indicate that unaccompanied minors are to be granted a visa, nor when such arrangements are to commence or cease. Within the current legislative framework, the government is able to undertake appropriate care arrangements for unaccompanied minors. The legislation in that sense is unnecessary but inflexible.

I wanted to talk briefly about the interpretation and litigation issues. The amendments will increase the likelihood of litigation by people seeking to establish that they are an unaccompanied minor to enable mandatory release from detention, especially in those circumstances where people arrive without documentation. There appears to be no mechanism for ensuring that the child agrees to placement or for ensuring that their best interests are considered. (Extension of time granted) The legal obligation to place in foster care without qualification could be inconsistent with the minister's obligations to certain unaccompanied minors under the arrangements for the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act. The minister could be held liable for any harm to the child released under section 197D. Litigation could arise over what constitutes a health or security risk. There is no clear authority under this proposed amendment to supervise the removal of a child from Australia so, if the decision is taken that the child should be removed, there is no clear authority for redetaining the child and making arrangements for removal.

In relation to the proposed amendment to section 197E, the proposed amendment would make it a requirement that all family members be accommodated with the child in conditions that apply to the residential housing project now. This would act considerably to reduce the flexibility under the current legislative framework to address specific needs of detainees. The government has used a variety of alternative detention arrangements tailored to the needs of the individual or family. The amendments would introduce rigidity and a `one size fits all' approach. The proposed amendment to section 197E would become a pull factor by encouraging adults to bring children with them when they unlawfully enter Australia. The proposed amendment assumes that the risks of absconding from low detention facility arrangements are the same as for all families, whatever their circumstances, including their different stages of processing and reviewâand, I might say, the different ages of the children because they can be up to 18 years of age.

It does not take into account the practical limitations and high costs of arrangements if they are required to be implemented in every Australian city, nor does it take into account that sufficient appropriate accommodation could be difficult to identify. There is no distinction between short-term compliance cases, many of which are in the cities, and those of longer term detainees. There are, of course, the variety of interpretation and litigation issues. It is not clear which family members, immediate or extended, would be included. This could give rise to litigation. Nor is it clear how the situation where families decided they did not wish to cohabit would be dealt with, and extensive litigation could arise over what constitutes a health or security risk, as in the previous section. Nor is it clear what constitutes the same amenity and security standards as apply at the Woomera Residential Housing Project. I mention those matters. I think the amendments were well intentioned but not well thought through. I think the arrangements that the government has implemented more than satisfactorily address these issues and enable us to ensure that unaccompanied minors, as they are at the moment, can be released into foster care arrangements. For those people who wish to participate, where women and children are living in alternative residential accommodation, those arrangements, where it is appropriate, can be facilitated. I think that more than responds to the sorts of issues that have been raised. I commend the bill to the House and oppose the amendments.

talk.start.para: âI thank the minister for his response. Clearly things have changed since I last saw it. Can I say in relation to children and education that I do not support the stand of the Premier in South Australia nor that of the mayor of Port Augusta, but I do not understand why negotiations could not have been advanced or in parallel with the Catholic education system, who I understand areâ
âThe question is whether or not you are putting people who have very different religions into the Catholic system if the secular system is available.

âYou did it at Port Hedland. The other point I would makeâand this was particularly said to me by teenagers in Baxterâis that there ought to be some consideration for TAFE programs where they are more appropriate than school programs. That currently has not been the situation, and I can understand that, but I hope the minister will take the issue on board when he is thinking of the educational needs of children.

speech.para: Question put:

motion.para: That the amendments (Ms Gillard's) be agreed to.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI present the supplementary explanatory memorandum to the bill and I move government amendments (1) and (2):

quote.para: (1) Schedule 5, item 7, page 9 (lines 14 to 21), omit the item.
(2) Schedule 6, item 2, page 10 (line 12), after âapplications for visas madeâ insert âin the migration zoneâ.

speech.para: These government amendments to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 are moved in response to recommendations made by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee. The amendments seek to omit the proposed subsection 241(3) from schedule 5 to the bill and to clarify that proposed section 48(3) applies only to visa applications made in the migration zone.

The proposed subsection 241(3) sought to apply strict liability to an element of the offence contained in section 241 of the Migration Act 1958. This complex provision was the subject of much confusion. Removing this item from the bill will allow an effective but less complex offence provision to be developed in consultation with the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions in the Attorney-General's Department.

The proposed subsection 48(3) ensures the section 48 bar on making further visa applications applies as originally intended to a non-citizen who leaves and re-enters Australia as a bridging visa holder. Unfortunately, this provision caused much confusion and led people to think that a non-citizen who travelled overseas would not be able to make a valid visa application outside of Australia. This is not the case. The amendment makes it clear that the bar on making further visa applications applies only to applications for a visa made by a non-citizen in the migration zone. I commend the amendments to the chamber.

talk.start.para: âI rise for the purpose of indicating, as I indicated earlier in this debate, that these amendments to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 moved by the government arise from recommendations made by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee. The opposition accept that they improve the bill. We specifically accept that the omission of subsection 241(3) at this stage is appropriate, and we understand the government will bring forth clarified provisions at a later point in time. The clarification in relation to the subsection 48(3) bar not preventing the lodging of a new claim offshore is, in our view, a sensible clarification. We understand the reason the amendments have been made. They arise out of a Senate committee process in which Labor fulsomely participated, and we support them.

talk.start.para: âTonight I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 2002. When this bill was originally circulated, it was a straightforward bill that dealt with three distinct issues. These issues were to introduce certain interest withholding tax exemptions, to exempt compensation payments in relation to the German Forced Labour Compensation Program from capital gains tax and to enable friendly society investment products to be included in their assessable income. It was a straightforward bill, and Labor supports the changes. However, yesterday we were informed that the government had decided to make changes to this bill, even though the bill was not listed to be debated in the House this week. We were advised that it would be brought on the next day, and there would be amendments.

speech.para: This would not normally have been a major issue. However, it is an issue in this case as the government's amendments relate to matters that were foreign to the original bill. Whilst the first amendment relates to the original bill, extending an interest withholding tax exemption on nostro accounts, the second amendment amends the operation of the transitional compulsory third party insurance's rule for certain compulsory third party policies. The government has tried to ram through these changes by the backdoor with less than 24 hours notice. The government has tried to make changes to the transitional rules relating to compulsory third party insurance. The arrogance of this government is without measure. As a result of this, Labor will support the bill, but it is taking the unusual step of denying this bill noncontroversial status in the Senate and also will not allow it to be exempt from the cut-off.

I would like to briefly discuss the new amendments. The first amendment extends the interest withholding tax exemption for interest paid on nostro accounts held by authorised deposit taking institutions, ADIs, to financial institutions which are not ADIs but which conduct banking business with the public. It seems that, after the original bill was introduced into parliament, the government was lobbied by merchant banks to extend the exemption to them. As is the usual case with the Howard government, they acquiesced to demands from the top end of town. The supplementary explanatory memorandum states that this amendment will have no impact on the forward estimates.

The amendments in relation to compulsory third party insurance are aimed at reducing the compliance burden on CTP insurers by simplifying the application of the special three-year transitional rule. The amendments relate to policies taken out between 1 July 2000 and 30 June 2003. The amendments will change the mechanism by which the transitional rule operates, such that it will be triggered by the date of commencement of the insurance policy rather than the date of payment of an insurance premium, as is the case at the moment. The intention is to smooth the phasing out of the transitional rule for CTP insurers by simplifying the identification of those policies that are subject to the transitional rule. The effect is that an entity is not entitled to claim an input tax credit for the acquisition of CTP insurance where the acquisition relates to a period of insurance that commences before 1 July 2003âthat is, input tax credits will be denied because of the commencement date of the CTP insurance rather than the payment date for the acquisition of the CTP insurance.

Contrary to public perception, the Howard government has raised taxes by almost two per cent of GDP since it came to office. With the budget in deficit last financial year, all that money is being spent, severely limiting the government's room to move on tax reform. In the last two federal budgets, taxes accounted for 24.9 per cent of GDP, including the GST. It was 23 per cent in 1995-96 under Labor.

Treasurer Costello tries to deny this. His budget papers show that tax accounts for only 21 per cent of GDP. The Treasurer wants to portray himself as the low-tax Treasurer; but he is actually the lack of truth Treasurer. In the budget papers, he talks about the Charter of Budget Honesty. The Commonwealth Charter of Budget Honesty Act 1998 requires that the budget be based on external reporting standards in accordance with the charter. The major external standards used in the budget are the Australia Bureau of Statistics accrual Government Finance Statistics framework and the Australian Accounting Standards, including Australian Accounting Standard No. 31, `Financial Reporting by Governments', AAS31.

The charter also requires that departures from applicable external reporting standards be identified. This is contained in appendix A to statement 2 and in note 1 to statement 12, which discloses departures from the external reporting standards. The departure relates, of course, to the treatment of GST. The clear policy intent, according to the Treasurer, of the intergovernmental agreement on Commonwealth-state financial arrangements is that the GST is collected by the Commonwealth as an agent for the states and territories and appropriated to the states. As such, it is not shown as Commonwealth revenue in other statements in this document.

The former Secretary to the Treasury and the former member for Fairfax in this place, Mr John Stone, took this issue up in the May edition of the Adelaide Review in the year 2000. He had been in some debate with the Commonwealth statistician about how the GST was going to be treated. John Stone won the argument and the statistician put out an information paper called Accruals based government finance statistics 2000. This was published on 13 March 2000. The statistician devoted a whole appendix to his proposed treatment of goods and services tax revenues in government finance statistics. Former Senator Stone said that the statistician considered five possible tests as to that treatment for which the core elements of his argument emerge as follows:

quote.para: 1. The Commonwealth has the ultimate role in the determination and distribution of GST revenue. The GST is imposed and collected by the Commonwealth under Commonwealth legislation. The Commonwealth government must endorse any changes to the GST rate and the rate change must be enacted into law by the Commonwealth parliament. The relativity factor determining the distribution of the net GST proceeds for each state and territory will be determined by the Commonwealth Treasurer. And the Commonwealth has the ultimate role in the determination and distribution of GST revenue. And, so, to the bottom line.

speech.para: He quotes the statistician as saying:

quote.para: The ABS will adopt the constitutional treatment for GST revenue and classify GST revenues as Commonwealth taxes in GFSâ

speech.para: that is, Government Finance Statisticsâand that:

quote.para: The distribution of GST revenue to state and territory governments will be treated as grants.

speech.para: Game, set and match. So the Treasurer is hiding from the taxpayers of Australia $30 billion of GST so that he can claim that his tax take is a low 21 per cent of GDP when it is actually 24.9 per cent. So Costello has worked out how much tax we pay but fails to include the GST. Costello's motive is his desire to be seen as the Treasurer who cuts taxes, but he cannot escape the fact that Labor did with 23 per cent of GDP exactly what the Commonwealth currently does with 24.9 per cent of GDPâthat is, make payments to the states and fulfil Commonwealth functions. Costello's accounting methods are at total odds with IMF guidelines and the ABS.
