talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: The government's position on this bill has always been made emphatically clear. We need this legislation to give our intelligence agencies vital tools to deter and prevent terrorism. We have not wavered from this position and we do not intend to do so now. The government are not being pig-headed about this; the government have bent over backwards to accommodate suggestions that strengthen and enhance the operation of the bill.

We significantly amended the bill following the reports of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD and the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, and we again proposed amendments following the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, some of which were passed in the Senate. But, as the government have repeatedly stated, we cannot and will not accept amendments that render the bill unworkable. That would do nothing to protect the community from terrorism. The community demands that our counter-terrorism laws are strong and certain. The opposition's amendments make this bill fail on both counts. The opposition's amendments make the bill, at best, unworkable and, at worst, unconstitutional.

The opposition's amendments go to matters of fundamental principle that we cannot accept. The government will not pretend to the community that what has come out of the Senate will provide the kind of protection against terrorism that we know we need. We will not do that when we know the opposition's package of amendments effectively renders the bill useless in the emergency situations it is designed to address, and open to challenge. That is why the government are rejecting the opposition and Democrat amendments that were passed in the Senate. In moving the government amendments in due course, I propose to outline just some of our reasons for fundamentally objecting to a number of the opposition amendments.

The government will be insisting on our proposals in relation to issuing and prescribed authorities. What we proposed was a workable, constitutionally sound regime. What the opposition has insisted upon is unworkable and unconstitutional. The government's unqualified legal advice is that there is a very significant risk that appointing sitting judges as prescribed authorities would be unconstitutional, regardless of whether they are state, territory or federal judges. Under the opposition's amendment, which was passed with the assistance of the minor parties, sitting state and territory judges would be performing functions under Commonwealth legislation that would give federal executive functions to state judges. Our advice is that there would be an unacceptable risk that this would be held to be incompatible with their judicial functions and hence to be unconstitutional. That risk is not just an arguable one but a very significant one. In the face of such a significant risk and on the basis of the advice available to it, the government cannot support the amendment in this form. The government will move amendments that will work and are constitutional to add former judges to the list of persons who can act in the capacity of issuing and prescribed authorities.

The government have always been emphatic that the ability to question and detain in strictly limited circumstances for the purposes of intelligence gathering to prevent and deter terrorist activity is fundamental to the bill. We have always been clear on that point. The opposition has offered a completely unworkable regime that will not give our intelligence agencies the capacity to get on with the job of protecting Australians and Australian interests against the threat of terrorism. This goes to the very heart of the bill. The opposition is fixated on a flawed notion of a law enforcement regime and does not appear to be able to grasp that this is an intelligence-gathering exercise where law enforcement concepts are not appropriate.

The bill deals with those circumstances where coercive questioning and detention, subject to strict controls, are necessary in the interests of public safety. For example, it may be necessary to detain a person to prevent them from informing others about ASIO's investigations, or to allow urgent intelligence investigations to continue unimpeded. In some situations the capacity to detain will be critical. As I have said before, it would be absurd to not have the power to detain a person for a limited period in a situation where not doing so might put public safety at risk. (Extension of time granted)

Those at the front line in meeting this threat tell us that, in order to protect the community from this kind of threat, they need the power to hold a person incommunicado, subject to strict safeguards, while questioning for the purpose of intelligence gathering. We accept this need, but the opposition does not. The government are rejecting the opposition's amendments that would limit questioning under a warrant to four hours, with a limited capacity to extend it to 12 hours. That proposal is an absurd, impractical proposition that does not allow sufficient flexibility to enable our intelligence agency to do its job. The government's amendment to reinstate the important provisions that allow coercive questioning and detention, subject to strict controls, is necessary in the interests of public safety.

The government will be insisting upon its proposals in relation to the protocols to cover the detention and questioning regime. The opposition amendments are yet another example of how the opposition have insisted on unworkable proposals. The government cannot accept that the protocols be disallowable instruments. Clearly, the opposition are trying to have further bites of the cherry. The opposition cannot be serious about passing the bill if they are going to insist on this extra layer of parliamentary scrutiny. The protocols will contain operational detail that is not appropriate for parliamentary scrutiny. It is vital that the protocols have sufficient flexibility. Entrenching them in a legislative instrument is not appropriate and is inconsistent with the way we treat comparable procedures that our law enforcement and security agencies are currently guided by. Having the procedures set in legislative concrete would render them unworkable. Having the protocols as disallowable instruments would not allow sufficient flexibility.

We have seen what the Senate has done to this bill. We cannot afford to waste time debating time and time again the minutiae that will be contained in the protocols. The government amendments cover the types of matters that the protocols must addressâand that is the type of provision the parliament should enact. The government cannot accept the opposition's amendment which will allow the subjects of warrants to have access to a lawyer of their own choice as a matter of right rather than an approved security cleared lawyer, as is proposed by the government. Again, the opposition's amendment is unworkable. The government's starting point is that all persons detained under a warrant should have access to a lawyer. The government proposes that lawyers be security cleared in advance to enable appropriate representation to be granted immediately. The costs of these lawyers will be met by the Commonwealth. We recognise that in extreme circumstances it may be vital to delay access to a lawyer. We have structured our provisions with tight safeguards and additional hurdles. The government is concerned about circumstances where there may be imminent danger to the community.

The government have repeatedly stated that a sunset clause is not appropriate. We are moving amendments to remove the sunset clause inserted by the opposition in the Senate. The international and domestic environment has changed forever. There is no way of saying for certain when, if ever, the provisions of the bill will be unnecessary. We have offered workable provisions for review of the legislation after one year and then again after three years. This will allow the legislation to be reviewed without subjecting it to arbitrary time pressures. We simply cannot say that these laws will no longer be required in two, three or four years. A review will allow for consideration of the bill and an appropriate level of scrutiny of the operation of the laws without the possibility that we will face a situation where we do not have these vital tools when we need them.

The government will also be insisting on our original provisions in relation to the questioning of 14- to 18-year-olds. We recognise that young people have special needs. That is why we have included additional requirements and special safeguards for 14- to 18-year-olds. We know that suicide attacks occur throughout the world. We know the devastation that they bring. We know that they can involve people as young as 16 or 17. Yet the opposition is seeking to deny our intelligence agency the capacity to gather intelligence in order to prevent suicide attacks. The Australian public would be appalled to think that we failed to prevent a 17-year-old terrorist bomber because ASIO was not allowed to ask him or her questions.

The key aim of this important legislation is to enable ASIO to question people in emergency terrorist situations in order to obtain the information we need to stop terrorist attacks before people are hurt or killed. We have always said that we recognise that this bill is extraordinary, but this bill is about intelligence gathering in extraordinary circumstances and is subject to significant safeguards. The opposition amendments go to the heart of the bill and fundamentally change the nature of what the government have proposed. The government have repeatedly said that we will not entertain proposals that will render the bill impotent or unworkable. That is why we have voted against the amendments moved by the opposition and the minor parties. If the opposition were serious about community safety, it would not entertain such a risk of unworkable and unconstitutional provisions. We cannot take the chance that our efforts to prevent an impending terrorist attack could be delayed and challenged on constitutional grounds. The opposition exposes itself as being hopelessly divided on this bill. The government have demonstrated time and time again our commitment to community safety, but we will not accept amendments that fundamentally change the nature of the bill. The government want this vital legislation passed before Christmas, but we will not try to pull the wool over the community's eyes by supporting a flawed and ineffective bill.

talk.start.para: âThe Labor Party disagree with the government disagreeing with the proposals that have come back from the Senate. Labor are committed to protecting Australia from terrorism, but we do not have to turn it into a police state to achieve it. The government's legislation is flawed because it does not provide sufficient protection for our citizens. The Attorney-General indicated that what he wanted was a capacity for intelligence gathering and questioning by ASIO. Now he is turning it into a detention regime. We have been prepared to support the means by which ASIO gets that additional questioning capacity in its ability to intelligence gather. But we are not going to create an environment in which people who are being questioned are treated worse than suspects. That is what you are suggesting.
âNo, it isn't.

âYes, you are. This is what your legislation effectively does. The bill that has come back from the Senate, following recommendations not only by Labor but also supported by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, gets the balance right. Yet the government will not accept it. Why? Because they want to play politics with this issue. That is the only reason we have, because the government have the capacity, through the bill before us now, to get the tougher regime that they argue for. Even members of their own party, the Senate committee and the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD accept it. Members of your party accept the amendments that Labor has been promoting and the Senate has voted on. You are ignoring even members of your own party who have looked at all of this evidence and who have had the opportunity to consider the information. There have been representations from the Law Council and from eminent jurists in this country, and you ignore them. If the government were serious about protecting the nation's security, there is a simple answer: pass this bill now. It can be through tonight and the legislation can be in place as soon as possible.

speech.para: This bill which has come back from the Senate gives unprecedented new powers to ASIO. It also ensures the necessary protection of our citizens. We were prepared to give our security services these new powers because of the new threat facing Australia from terrorism. But when you give an intelligence organisation like ASIO new powers you must have safeguards built in. No other similar agency in the Western world would have the powers that this bill delivers to ASIOâand the Attorney-General knows it. We have supported tough new powers to fight terrorism, but we also want protection for our citizens. It means getting the balance right.

I use the words `getting the balance right' because when the previous antiterrorism bills came before this House the government and the Prime Minister argued that our amendments were unworkable and unacceptable. We hear that language again tonight. Three months later, when the Prime Minister went before the National Press Club, he said that the antiterrorism bill had got the balance right. In other words, once the politics had moved out, he recognised and was prepared to publicly acknowledge the merit of the Labor initiatives. That is what you should be doing tonight. If you were honest with yourself, Attorney, if you were really serious about getting tougher new legislation in place expeditiously, you would be passing this bill that has come back tonight.

We have aimed to achieve four critical objectives, which the government oppose. The first is access to legal representation of choice. The second is protection of children under the age of 18. The third is a sunset clause to ensure further parliamentary scrutiny in three years time. This bill gives you three years in which to operate, and we will see how it functions. The fourth is a questioning regime, not a detention regime. (Extension of time granted)

talk.start.para: âOn the first area, access to legal representation, let us just understand that government members of the parliamentary joint committee and the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee agreed that people brought in for questioning should have the right to legal representation from a panel of judges. That is what you are refusing to accept. That is what the recommendation says, Attorney. That was a recommendation from the Senate committee, and you reject it. Even your own members proposed and accepted that position.

speech.para: The second area is protection for children under the age of 18. They also agreed. The government want to allow bringing in for questioning children as young as 14. It is inappropriate. They agreed to the three-year sunset clause, the third area, as well. In all of these areas, government backbenchers voted with us and against the Howard government's proposals. In his statement to the House, the chair of the parliamentary joint committee, David Jull, said:

quote.para: The proposed legislation, in its original form, would undermine key legal rights and erode the civil liberties that make Australia a leading democracy.

speech.para: That is from your own side of the parliament, yet you want to push this stuff through. You ignore members on your own side in this desperate bid to push the wedge. You are not looking for a solution; you are looking to play politics.

In the fourth areaâa questioning regime, not a detention regimeâthe Attorney-General himself told members of the opposition, in negotiations, that his real objective was a questioning regime. On advice given to me, the Attorney-General explicitly admitted to the negotiators on our side that what he wanted for ASIO was a questioning regime, not a detention regime. What have we been prepared to acknowledge? And you have misrepresented the position here in the chamber. We have been prepared to accept a position in which people can be questioned for up to 20 hoursâeight hours more than is the case under the Crimes Act, an extension of that.

What has the Crimes Act got to do with it? We are talking about circumstances in which this country has established mechanisms for questioning people. We are saying we are prepared today to go beyond that in these circumstances, and you say it is not enough.

talk.start.para: âIt isn't.

âDo not suggest to us seriously, Attorney-General, that with up to 20 hours of questioning you cannot establish the circumstances of the individual. I do not believe it and the Australian public will not believe it. You say 20 hours of questioningâeight hours more than under the Crimes Actâis not enough, and that is what you are going to the wire on here.

speech.para: Tonight, you told the media the opposite of what you were telling us in negotiations. You said you needed a detention regime. You never said that in the negotiations with us, apart from the fact that in the effort out there on the doorstop, you could not even remember what the issues were. It was a terribly inept performance, Attorney. You argued the point then and you said it again here in the chamber that what was being proposed by Labor was unconstitutional. This is a claim that has been rejected by the former Solicitor-General, Gavan Griffith QC. This is what he said in a statement issued tonight when your claim was heard. This is advice from Gavan Griffith QC. I will not read it in full. I will seek leave to table it, if that is appropriate. He says:

quote.para: I understand that constitutional reservations have been expressed about proposed clause 34B(2).
I see no difficulty.

speech.para: That is the former Solicitor-General. He then goes on to say:

quote.para: State judges commonly are vested with non-judicial power, and there is no difficulty about this even though they also may exercise federal judicial power.

speech.para: So he is rejecting your argument there. (Extension of time granted) He goes on to say:

quote.para: I see no basis for asserting that there may be a residual Kable point for a power vested personally rather than in the Court, and I do not see any other constitutional difficulty.

speech.para: He goes on to say further:

quote.para: ... if there were a constitutional difficulty (which I cannot see) that merely would make paragraph (2) invalid and it would be severed without affecting the operation of paragraph (1) and the fall back under paragraph (3).

speech.para: I seek leave to table that advice.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI challenge the Attorney-General to table his. You have been asserting in public that what Labor is proposing is unconstitutional. We have advice from an eminent QC, the former Solicitor-General, saying that you are wrong; that what we are proposing is constitutional. You should table your advice because I am prepared to table advice that we rely upon.

speech.para: We have a situation here where the minister has been arguing a different case to us in negotiation and publicly. He can get a bill tonight. He can get a bill that gives ASIO additional powers and will in fact toughen the regime in terms of the war against terror, the fight against terror. We need circumstances in which the interests of our citizens are protected. At this moment, when the nation's security requires strong bipartisan support, the only response from the Howard government is to play politics. Labor will not stand for it and the Australian people will not stand for it.

The bill that is before us, the bill that we say the government should accept, gets the balance right between protecting our security and protecting our citizens. It gets the balance right between protecting our children and protecting the wider population who could get caught up in the misuse of unprecedented powers. We have delivered, yet again, for the government a sensible, balanced and workable piece of legislation. Members of your own party who sat in the committees to exhaustively consider the detail agree with us. But the government cannot help itselfâit only wants to play politics. We need a workable solution; we have it and it can be passed tonight. The government has argued it is unworkable and unconstitutional; it is both workable and constitutional. Stop the deceit, stop the political games and pass the bill.

talk.start.para: âOn 20 November the government put Australia on high alert against terrorist threats. The government said this danger would extend over the Christmas holidays and into next year. If, as the government appears determined, Australia joins in a US-led war against Iraq, the terrorist threat to Australia and Australians overseas may well increase. The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 is about protecting Australians from terrorists. This amended bill will give ASIO new power to collect information from people who may know something about terrorists. The bill will empower ASIO, under warrant, to compel people to answer questions about terrorist activity. ASIO does not have this power at present. Even if dealing with an imminent terrorist threat, ASIO cannot compel people to provide information relating to that threat. This is a power ASIO needs now to deal with current threats.

speech.para: By passing this amended bill today, the parliament will enhance our security at a time of significant threat. This is a power that should be available to ASIO and should have been available many months ago. Unfortunately, the government's incompetent handling of this legislation has ensured that only today is the bill fit enough to be passed by this parliament. The original bill, introduced on 22 March, was very different from the amended legislation now before us. The bill, as introduced, would have allowed adults, and even children, to be detained and strip searched, and to be held in secret by ASIO for rolling two-day periods that could be extended indefinitelyâeven after the questioning had concluded. I repeat: `even after the questioning had concluded', Attorney-General. You were asked about that on two occasions and you answered in relation to that question.

The original bill was a proposal for indefinite detention incommunicado. The original bill breached fundamental legal and human rights principles. It was completely unacceptable. The bill was referred to both the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD and the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. The detailed examination undertaken by these committees has demonstrated the effectiveness of comprehensive committee consideration by the parliament. Following the bipartisan recommendationsâI repeat: `bipartisan recommendations'âof the joint committee and the Senate committee, Labor successfully moved in the Senate extensive amendments which have fundamentally transformed the bill. The government also successfully moved a number of amendments which cherry picked elements of the Senate committee report.

The amended bill has the following features and safeguards: applications for warrants to carry out questioning may be made by the Director-General of ASIO with the approval of the Attorney-General; warrants for questioning to be issued by a prescribed authority with appropriate high legal standing and independence; compulsory questioning by ASIO officers before a prescribed authority for strictly limited time periods; persons being questioned to have access to legal representation; any custody must be directly linked to the questioning and no detention for other purposes; protection for children under the age of 18; and provisions for comprehensive parliamentary scrutiny of the questioning system, including a three-year sunset clause. These are all reasonable propositions; all should be accepted by the government.

We now have a bill which gives ASIO a tool that it urgently needs: a compulsory questioning regime. We also have a bill with strong and appropriate safeguards that have been insisted on by the legal profession, many community groups and the thousands of ordinary Australians who have written to the committees and directly to MPs and senators. These safeguards are consistent with well-established standards which apply to police investigations and to questioning by bodies such as royal commissions, the new Australian Crime Commission, ASIC, ICAC and other state crime commissions. The amended bill gets the balance right between security and civil liberties. (Extension of time granted) The government now have a choice: to vote for the bill as amended or to reject those amendments. They can choose to accept the new power for ASIO, which the opposition are prepared to support, along with the protections we are insisting upon, or alternatively they can leave ASIO without the authority to compel answers.

The government can act in the national interest or in their own perceived political interest. The ball is in their court. The government have made much of the terrorist threat to Australia. They have emphasised that the threat is very real and very immediate in nature. This issue should be above political game playing. The opposition support the amended bill, and we urge the government to also do so without further delay. That sends the right messageâcross-party support for legislation. We did it with the first tranche of terrorist bills, and they worked. If the government spurns the compromise, as they have indicated they intend to do, if they try to play politics with this, then the opposition are ready to fight that fight. We are determined to protect the Australian people from terrorism and to protect the rights and freedoms that Australians cherish. That is what we are fighting forâvalues, our institutions, the rule of law. That is what these amendments ensure, and that is why it is an outrage that the government seek to spurn the amended bill from the Senate.

I would like to conclude my remarks by highlighting what has been a fundamental concern for meânamely, the proposed treatment of persons not suspected of any offence. The government appears committed to its proposal that people not suspected of any offence be detained in secret for up to seven days. In contrast, the Crimes Act allows murder suspects to be detained by police for a maximum of only 12 hours. They must then be charged or released. What the government proposes is a detention regime for suspects and non-suspects alike, and an extremely harsh one at that, of up to seven daysâwith the first two days potentially incommunicadoâwithout access to a lawyer. The government's continuing commitment to this detention regime has been made very clear today by the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice and Customs. The government has been very insistent that the power to detain persons not necessarily suspected of any offence is a core part of its scheme. This will be a fundamental departure from established legal and human rights principles, and the Attorney-General knows that. It is unacceptable. The government has utterly failed to justify this radical change.

Why should a person who is not suspected of any offence but is simply thought to be able to assist with information relevant to the investigation of a terrorism offence be treated worse than a murder suspect? Why should a non-suspect be treated worse than a suspect? The opposition remains very firmly of the view that this cannot be justified. This is not General Pinochet's Chile. This is Australia. For an Attorney-General, the first law officer of the country, to come into this parliament to argue for a secret detention regime for non-suspects is an utter disgrace. The Labor Party will never wear it; the Australian people will never wear it.

By rejecting the amended bill, the government are betraying the national interest. They are betraying the safety of the Australian people; they are betraying our democratic principles and they will be condemned for their betrayal. We will make sure of that. You do not defeat terrorists by detaining non-suspects incommunicado without lawyers. They are the values of our system. That is what differentiates us from the terrorists. That is why what the government is doing is inexcusable. It is inexcusable, and this Attorney is defending the indefensible. He knows it, and that is why today he found great difficulty in his press conference after that bill was amended in the Senate. We will maintain our position. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI join the Leader of the Opposition and my colleague the member for Banks in opposing the Attorney-General's motion. Today in an interview before the media, the Attorney-General emphasised that the government is about creating a detention regime. Indeed, as the member for Banks described it, it is not only a detention regime; it is a secret detention regime. It has been said, and it should be said again, when democracy conducts its business behind closed doors, democracy itself withers and dies. We should not forget that. We, in the opposition, have proposed a regime which is workable and is constitutionally valid because it is a questioning regime. We emphasise it is a questioning regime. Why? Because only a questioning regime will withstand constitutional challenge.

speech.para: It is the Attorney-General who is pulling the wool over the eyes of the Australian people in this context. It is well known to all members of the House that our system of government, based on the Westminster model, is based on a clear separation of powers between this parliament, the executiveâof which the Attorney-General is a minister of the Crown and a memberâand the judiciary, as set out in chapter III of the Constitution. It is the courts and the judiciary that have the power under our Constitution to detain people. If there is any authority required for that, let me point the Attorney-General to Lim's case, of which he would be aware. In the High Court, the majority judgment in that case said:

quote.para: It would, for example, be beyond the legislative power of the Parliament to invest the Executive with an arbitrary power to detain citizens in custody notwithstanding that the power was conferred in terms which sought to divorce such detention in custody from both punishment and criminal guilt.

speech.para: Which is what this proposed model does. It continues:

quote.para: The reason why that is so is that ... the involuntary detention of a citizen in custody by the State is penal or punitive in character and, under our system of government, exists only as an incident of the exclusively judicial function of adjudging and punishing criminal guilt.
Every citizen is âruled by the law, and by the law aloneâ and âmay with us be punished for a breach of law, but he can be punished for nothing elseâ.

speech.para: There are exceptions, and the Attorney-General would acknowledge those as described, for instance, in Kruger's case, where they said:

quote.para: The question whether a power to detain persons or to take them into custody is to be characterised as punitive in nature so as to attract the operation of Ch. III, depends upon whether those activities are reasonably capable of being seen as necessary for a legitimate non-punitive object.

speech.para: Look at the Attorney-General's interview and look at his speech today where he said that a purpose of the regime is to detain people to prevent them communicating. Indeed, incommunicado detention is for that very purpose, and he also mentioned the purpose of deterrence. Clearly, these are purposes of punishment; they are not reasonably incidental to obtaining intelligence for the purpose of preventing a terrorist attack.

The Attorney's model will be challenged and successfully challenged, I believe, because it is based on a model of detention for detention's sake, not for the purpose of questioning to obtain intelligence to prevent a terrorist attack. There is no point in this parliament passing such important legislation if it is only going to be struck down and allow terrorist attacks to occur because the legislation has been struck down. Look at what we are proposing, look at the authorities that we rely on and come up with a balanced package. The opposition are prepared to support the government in achieving that, but we will not respond to wedge purposes only to see legislation struck down and defeated and the whole purpose set asunder because the government has not been prepared to sit down, look rationally at the authorities and come up with a balanced model.

talk.start.para: âFor the last 15 months, and probably longer, the people in this country who are assigned the responsibility to define threats to Australian citizens have come to the conclusion that Australia lies within al-Qaeda's defined South-East Asian field of jihad. That means for the average Australian citizen that we are legitimate civilian and military targets. We may be killed at will for the political purposes of establishing the ideological and political structures that those who support various elements of the terrorist movement believe should be established. We may be killed here; we may be killed abroad.

speech.para: Their definition of our humanity has more in common with the fascist definitions of people with whom the fascist movements of the 1930s disagreed than it has with any known political characterisation which we would normally in political discourse in this country assign to each other. This is a serious problem. We are serious targets. Australians have already been killed. The intention to identify other Australians for killing has already been established.

Australians have been killed partly because we do not share a particular set of religious convictions. We have been killed partly because we are supporters of the United States, who are defined as one of the enemies. We are to be killed partly because we associate with moderate Muslim regimes which are themselves targets. We are to be killed partly because we supported the independence of East Timor. There are a whole variety of reasons why we are potentially to be killed. We are to be killed in our homes, we are to be killed in our clubs and we are to be killed in our public buildings.

These are serious issues for the Australian people and they are problems with which we must deal. Our intelligence services have advised us adequately on that; they make calculations from time to time. When this ideological and moral commitment and intention on the part of al-Qaeda and its affiliated organisations are capable of being transmitted into some sort of meaningful action, we are given warning about when that might take place. Nobody in the intelligence community is confident that they will be able to pick up any particular one of these threats with any degree of accuracy sufficient to prevent it, but they are getting better at it. There have been many incidentsâobviously the most recent one affecting our people is the incident in Baliâand there have also been many frustrations. There is an active intelligence operation now against al-Qaeda and it has some chance of containing the levels of threat that are there to members of our community.

If the bill passed by the Senate were accepted by the government, it would substantially increase the protection of the ordinary Australian citizen. The bill, as passed by the Senate, permitsâunprecedented in the history of this countryâintelligence authorities to take a person and question them for 20 hours. The Attorney-General would know well that those 20 hours, of course, are not 20 hours from go to whoa, from the time when the person is picked up; they are 20 hours of questioning. Any reasonable human being knows that 20 hours of questioning probably means, in practical terms, detention for two to three days, whether you choose to define this as a questioning regime or a detention regime. We define it as questioning regime. But the practical effect of it will be to hold people for two to three days.

In addition, while legal protections are extended to the persons so picked up for questioning, if the lawyersâand there are emergency provisions associated with this, so it is not necessarily a lawyer of their own choosingâdivulge the activities in which those people have been involved, they will go to jail. If those who are detained for the purposes of questioning lie to their questioners, they will go to jail. It is as simple as that. This is a powerful tool which will be available, if you pass the legislation, to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. That tool is not available to the FBI; it will never be available to the FBI and it is not conceivable that it will ever be available to the FBI, except if the FBI is dealing with aliens in the United States. They cannot do it with a US citizen, but we will be able to do it with an Australian citizenâor, for that matter, a US citizen in Australia. It is a powerful tool. (Extension of time granted) If you permit it to be put in place, there are checks and balances contained within itâand you will have an opportunity to review whether those checks and balances are effective or too constrainingâbut it is worth a go.

You are concerned that some of these matters may be disallowable instruments. The Labor Party is supporting this because we believe it ought to be put in place. We are not opposing it because we think that the civil liberties questions necessarily override the importance of the protection of the state and the citizens within it. We are not in the business of finding ways of knocking off regulations that you establish under these proposals. We are not in that business. We are in the business of ensuring an effective regime. At the end of the day, that is our bottom line.

Attorney-General, I have served on one of the committees that has examined the matters that the government has placed before us, and others of my colleagues have served on other committees. I have taken a great deal of interest in the way in which this has been handled. I know and you know that there is great disquiet on your back bench about these matters. Many of the things to which you objected that are entailed in this legislation were in fact positions arrived at by some of your own members serving on those committees. You know as well as I do that this is not opposed or questioned by a group of ratbags in the community who wish us ill. The people who have taken stands against this in the general public include the Law Council and the Press Council. As I said, they are not ratbags; they are people who take seriously the issues and concerns about civil liberty in relation to the Australian people.

These people know precisely how much the powers of the state are extended by this legislation. Their view was that the attitude of the Labor Party ought to be to not permit this legislation, which would never see the light of day in the United States, to see the light of day here. We choose not to take this view, because we think that we are threatened. We think our society is threatened. We think we have to protect our society. We think this bill will help us protect our society. That is the basis on which we approach itâthe same basis on which we approach the terrorist legislation. But this legislation means 20 hours of questioningâeffectively two or three days. If there is any information that that person will voluntarily divulge, they will divulge it in those 20 hours.

You are worried about age limits. You talked about whether or not a 17-year-old might go out, as some 17-year-olds have, with a bomb strapped to them and destroy the lives of Australians. Frankly, the person you described, Minister, is a person to be dealt with under other legislation, not this one. If the person that you have in custody is a person that you have reason to believe could be a suicide bomber, that comes under the criminal elements associated with the terrorist laws, and that is how you would deal with that particular individual. In any event, this is an enormous enhancement of your power, but it is an enhancement you need right now. This is very late in the day and very late in the sittings.

My advice to you, Attorney-General, is to take what has been offered to you by the Senate. We are about to enter what many of us like to describe as `the silly season'. We also know that there are authoritative reports globally that al-Qaeda and its affiliates intend to turn this season into something quite different. It is possible, not likely, that the United States will engage in military action in Iraq over the course of the next few months prior to the parliament's next sitting. I do not think they will, but they might. If they do, it is unquestionably the case that Australians abroad and here will find themselves a target for heightened activity by al-Qaeda and its supporters. We need the information. There is a chance that, if you pass the bill in the form in which it has come back from the Senate, you will get that information. You would not be able to live with yourself, Attorney-General, if, in rejecting what you had to handâwhether or not you think it is a work of perfectionâan event about which we might have had information took place. You would not forgive yourself. There is no need for you to place yourself in that situation. There has been strong support on your side of the House and, I might say, on your side of political affairsâthere are not too many Labor supporters in the law councils or for that matter on the Press Council. Your side of political affairs wanted much less; in fact, they wanted nothing at all to pass this place. We want something that is good, workable and effective. Give it a go. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI wish to comment briefly on the amended Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 as returned from the Senate, and I also oppose the Attorney's motion. I accept the honourable member for Brand's assessment of the regional terrorist scenario, but as I said in the second reading debate the bill as first presented to this House allowed fear to prevail. It lessened our freedoms and, instead of encouraging vigilance and caution, emphasised unfounded proaction, secrecy, unfounded suspicion and a climate quite antithetic to that which should prevail in Australia of all places.

speech.para: The price of freedom is eternal vigilance, but not at the price of putting freedom second in line to denying freedom. The amendments subsequently approved by the Senate significantly improve this bill in line with the recommendations of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. The government has chosen to reject these amendments and, in the case of the judges required to be issuing authorities, argues constitutional difficulties. The amended prescribed authority provisions propose that in the first instance it be made up of retired judges. If there are insufficient numbers of retired judges, then serving state or territory judges can be called upon and, if there are still insufficient numbers, senior members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

I also read a copy of the opinion of former Commonwealth Solicitor-General Gavan Griffith QC; as has been made clear, he sees no constitutional difficulties. Again I challenge the Attorney-General to further explain his legal advice as to why the government believes this judicial arrangement, so vital for the independence of, and public confidence in, the prescribed authority, is unconstitutional and why it contradicts Gavan Griffith QC.

I remind the House of the Law Council's statement to the Senate inquiry that the powers proposed to be granted to ASIO are so far-reaching that the issuing of warrants should only be capable of being authorised by a chapter III judge. I humbly suggest the former Commonwealth Solicitor-General has not only confirmed the constitutionality of the judicial arrangement in the Senate amendments but has also confirmed the constitutionality of the exercise of a warrant by such a panel in that it is not inconsistent with the exercise of judicial power.

As the Senate committee report statedâand it was a majority bipartisan report with three individual dissenting reports, as I recallâASIO is an intelligence-gathering agency, not a law enforcement body. Unless we embody that basic concept in this legislation, we sacrifice a large slab of our hard-won freedom by handing over policing to faceless secret officers. They need to be faceless and secretâthe public and the nation support thatâto inquire, but only under the strict supervision of an independent prescribed authority with every protection of common law rights and human rights.

We have here what is most likely the first major proactive law that I can recall, as opposed to the normal law making in parliaments around this country which traditionally has been concerned with reactive lawânamely, dealing with law-breakers after the event. Here we are dealing with action before the event, dealing not only with suspects but with nonsuspects. That is why we need the exceptional safeguards to protect rights that to this point have left us rightfully boasting that we are the freest nation on earth. That is a big call perhaps, but I will continue to argue it if this legislation is passed as amended by the Senate. I could not do that should this legislation come into law without those amendments. It is important to remind the House of the words this week of the Chairman of the Press Council, Professor Ken McKinnon. He said:

quote.para: There are so many differences between this and the kinds of freedom our society has fought so hard to achieve.

speech.para: Professor George Williams told the Senate inquiry that he thought it would be difficult if not impossible for ASIO to be sufficiently secretive to adequately fulfil its primary mission as well as to be sufficiently open to scrutiny to exercise the powers set out in the ASIO bill. That is the nub of the argument here, and that is why the government's legislation is deficient without the amendments passed by the Senate and in particular the totally independent and separated power of the prescribed authority and the three-year sunset clause. As with native title, if a ramping up of security concerns is being used as a double dissolution trigger, the cost will be our freedoms and not our security, which is well protected by the bill as it stands, amended by the Senate via the bipartisan recommendation of the Senate committee. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMight I make a couple of practical observations. I recall being involved in debates and discussions when, for the first time, the Commonwealth parliament introduced time limits and videotaping of interviews of suspects involved in allegations of breaches of federal offences. I remember at that time that there were people of considerable experience who believed that by providing such time limits the police would be handicapped in their work and that by videotaping those materials there would be difficulties. In truth, in practice we discovered that it was probably the most important advance in the efficiency of law enforcement, that disputed confessions were no longer the subject of long litigation and that the system worked very well. We also discovered that all the necessary questioning of suspects could be undertaken within a time frame substantially less than that now proposed to be the maximum period for the interrogation of nonsuspects under this legislation.

speech.para: The opposition knows that we need to provide a framework which is more open to the security agencies to seek information and to compel answers from those who are not suspected of crimes. This is a framework which allows that. What I find very puzzling is why the government will not accept a framework that the goodwill of this parliament will allow to pass. If it believes that there ought to be sterner or different measures and wants to put that to the political test, let it bring back further measures and let us have a debate in future. But why, for God's sake, when we accept that we face as a community the real risk that somewhere someone may be seeking to attack our society and the individuals in it, would we not at least agree on those elements that both sides of this parliament and the Independents and others can agree on and then have our debates and disputes? Nobody is saying that the Labor Partyâand those who see this as the furthest reach to which those who believe in civil liberties and a decent set of arrangements to protect the rights of individuals are prepared to travelâwish to expose Australia to terrorism; surely they do not see that their fellow Australians and parliamentarians and many in the community are treasonous or acting against the nature of the interests of the Australian society.

Why not pass what has been offered that gives the opportunity to question people, to compel their testimony, to hold them for a very extended period, to do all that the government has said is necessary? Pass the legislation and then have any further disputes that the government may wish to have for political reasonsâto persuade the community that there are issues that it wishes to litigate further for double dissolution purposes, for whatever political gain.

If the circumstance does arise when, as a result of a deadlock between the houses, we do not have legislation in place, then we will have one of the most disgraceful political arguments possibleâthat is, who is to blame? What a disgrace it will be for this parliament, this country and this community. Accept what is on offer on the goodwill of both sides of this House, then fight your fights. Don't put the Australian community at risk by this stubbornness and disgraceful unwillingness to accept the good faith of your fellow parliamentarians.

talk.start.para: âI was not proposing to engage in an extensive reply, but there are two things I want to say about the comments that have been made by members opposite. The first is in relation to this difference between a questioning regime and a detention regime. I want to absolutely repudiate any suggestion that the government bill has sought at any time in its present proposed form to introduce detention for detention's sake. That is absolutely not part of the scheme. The proposal is only for detention being possibleânot in all casesâfor the purposes of questioning people to obtain information to prevent a terrorist attack.

speech.para: The second point I want to make is in relation to the legal advice. The Leader of the Opposition tabled advice from Dr Griffith, the former Solicitor-General. What he appears not to be aware of, or at least has not acknowledged, is that I provided a letter to Senator Faulkner this evening in which I set out the full basis of the government's legal advice, which contradicts the advice Dr Griffith has given.

That the reasons be adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Mr SLIPPER (FisherâParliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration) (1.12 a.m.)âI move:

motion.para: That the amendments be disagreed to.

subdebate.1.para: These amendments make a number of variations to a bill which was drafted to implement a commitment of the Commonwealth at the ministerial meeting on public liability insurance on 30 May this year. At that meeting the Commonwealth agreed to legislate to allow self-assumption of risk for people who choose to participate in inherently risky activities such as adventure tourism and sports. The bill is designed to underpin state and territory reforms to the law of negligence by removing incentives to sue for breach of contract by relying on a term implied by section 74 of the Trade Practices Act. At the COAG meeting on Friday, 6 December COAG noted the Commonwealth's commitment to amend the Trade Practices Act to ensure that state and territory legislation will not be compromised. Acceptance of the amendments would impose fetters on the capacity of parties to rely on the bill and hence would compromise the effectiveness of state and territory reforms. The government cannot accept these amendments as they are contrary to the commitment made to all state and territory premiers and chief ministers to ensure that the Trade Practices Act does not undermine state and territory law reform.

talk.start.para: âSection 74 of the Trade Practices Act implies into every contract for a service that the service will be rendered with due care and skill and that any material supplied in connection with those services will be reasonably fit for its intended purpose. The Trade Practices Amendment (Liability for Recreational Services) Bill 2002 amends the TPA to allow contractual exclusion, an exclusion clause or waiver for liability for death or personal injury by the providers of recreational services from the implied warranties in section 74 of the TPA.

speech.para: The bill went to the Senate economics committee, and from the evidence obtained by the committee it is now apparent that the minister's press release inaccurately represented the government's position on the bill. It is now clear that the government did not intend to move any amendments to the bill even though the bill appears to allow people to agree to unlimited waivers releasing service providers from all liability for death or personal injury, including in those cases involving gross negligence.

There is significant opposition to the bill in its current form from those who made submissions to the Senate committee. However, the expert panel on the review of the law of negligence did support the bill, subject only to amending the definitions of recreational services and personal injury. It should be noted that the Insurance Council declined to make a submission, on the basis that they wanted to see the whole package of reforms in relation to the Trade Practices Act before commenting. The objective of this bill now, according to evidence from Treasury to the committee, is to meet the commitment made by the Commonwealth at the ministerial meeting on public liability insurance in May 2002. The communique from that summit states that the Commonwealth will:

quote.para: Legislate to allow self-assumption of risk for people who choose to participate in inherently risky activities such as adventure tourism and sports, subject to preserving adequate protection for consumers under the Trade Practices Act 1974.

speech.para: The states are committed to introducing mirror legislation where required. The popular appeal of this bill, as was represented by the minister's press release when the bill was introduced, was that it allowed people to voluntarily assume the risks involved in risky recreational activities. This was seen as addressing the need by tourism operators and sports providers for enforceable waivers so that they were not liable for accidents which arose from the inherent risks of participating in such activities. Providers are seeking to avoid liability and ensuing litigation for injury resulting from obvious or inherent risks in recreational activities, as this was threatening the continued availability of affordable insurance cover. The bill also hoped to reduce pressure on insurance premiums.

At the time of its introduction in June, the bill was strongly supported by pony clubs, and operators of adventure tourism and other high-risk activities. However, that support now appears to be qualified. The Australian Consumers Association have also indicated that, without amendments, they would be forced to issue a consumer warning to participants in recreational activities. This bill goes further than just potentially removing liability for accidents or obvious or inherent risks from participating in recreational activities. If so agreed, a waiver could also waive liability for negligence, however arising. The likelihood of this occurring, however, will depend on people agreeing to such a waiver, service providers requiring such waivers and courts not adopting a conservative interpretation of a waiver and so reading down the extent of the liability waived. Evidence to the committee indicates that, if the bill proceeds, lawyers will actively seek to have courts read down waivers or will assert that waivers were not understood or disclosed, and so not effective. This is probably also the view of the Ipp report, which stated:

quote.para: In summary, the Bill removes the obstacle presented by s 68 to the exclusion of the warranties implied by s 74. It does not, by itself, exclude, restrict or modify the liability of providers of recreational services. The ordinary law of contract presents various significant obstacles to the achievement of that end.

speech.para: The obstacles the panel refers to include the following. The exclusion of implied warranties will be subject to the ordinary rules of contract law, which are stringent. The exclusion must be effectively incorporated into the contract and, in cases where there is doubt about whether the rules about incorporation have been met, the doubt will be resolved in favour of the consumer. In order to be effective the words of the exclusion clause must be clear and unambiguous; again, any doubts about the precise meaning of the clause will be resolved in favour of the consumer. A contractual exclusion, if effective, will only be effective against the other party to the contract. Thus, if one person enters a contract for the supply of services to a group the other members of the group may not be bound by the terms of the contract. (Extension of time granted) Also, the Ipp report asserts that many people who participate in recreational services do not do so pursuant to contracts.

Thus, the bill appears to address the needs of tourism operators but in many cases will mainly just alter what is litigated. On the other hand, there is legitimate concern that this bill may remove the incentive for businesses to ensure that they provide safe services. Evidence to the committee suggests that the government is aware of these problems. It claims that it is concerned to be consistent with state reforms in the area of self-assumption of risk in recreational activities; however, there is some variation between jurisdictions at this stage.

According to the communique at the ministerial meeting on public liability insurance in October, every state and territory has made some commitment in relation to the provision of waivers to allow people to accept risk. Of those states which have announced or implemented the details of their commitments, New South Wales has passed legislation which limits liability for damages for personal injury arising from recreational activities in the following way: there is no liability for harm as a result of the materialisation of an obvious risk of a dangerous recreational activity; there is no liability arising from a risk of an activity in respect of which a risk warning has been given; and, a participant in a recreational activity is able to waive the requirement that services be provided with due care and skill.

South Australia has passed legislation establishing a system of registered codes governing the provision of recreational services. Where a service provider has registered and undertaken to comply with the registered code, the service provider can enter into a contract with a consumer modifying the duty of care owed to the consumer. The service provider is then liable in damages only if the consumer establishes that a failure to comply with the code caused or contributed to the injury. Victoria has passed legislation which is similar to this bill but makes provision for prescribing the form of the waiver and what particulars must be included in the waiver. It requires that the waiver is signed by the consumer, that no false or misleading statements are made in relation to the waiver and that the waiver is ineffective for an act or omission causing injury which was done with reckless disregard. The details of the commitments of the other states and territories is much vaguer. Thus, it is not clear whether there will be uniformity among the states and territories in any event.

A number of amendments to this bill were suggested to the Senate Economics Committee. A number of submissions, including the Law Council and sporting industry bodies, recommended that a code of practice or an accreditation system be introduced. This raises issues, though, of who develops such codes, and it still allows for litigation for the interpretations of the standards in the codes. The Plaintiff Lawyers Association wanted waivers limited to waiving liability only for inherent risks. Such an amendment attempts to remove liability for accidents, but it is difficult to define and likely to result in significant litigation as to what is an inherent risk in sport. For example, is a neck injury to a hooker in a rugby scrum the result of the risks involved in scrums generally, the referee not properly supervising the formation of that scrum or the rules of the game at the time being inadequate in relation to the formation of scrums? These are all areas that a plaintiff lawyer would want to see litigated and tested in the courts.

Finally, a number of submissions and the Ipp report suggested amending the definition of recreational services to narrow the range of activities to which this bill applies. However, the definition suggested by the Ipp report is made in relation to another amendment in the Ipp report, which is more significant than what is contemplated in the bill, and appear to be made just for consistency. The definition adopted in the bill is the same as that used in the South Australian and Victorian legislation.

The opposition moved an amendment in the Senate so that the bill operates in a manner similar to the Victorian legislation. The intention of the amendment was to allow the originally stated objectives of the bill to be met. The amendment would introduce some balance by also at least retaining liability in cases where an act was done or an omission was made with reckless disregard. This will create some incentive for businesses to provide safe services. Prescribing the terms of waivers may also limit litigation and remove the worst kinds of waivers. The requirement for each waiver to be signed will not, however, be supported by everyone. For example, the Australian Amusement, Leisure and Recreation Association have indicated that it is inappropriate that waivers should have to be signed for large-scale recreation parks, such as people attending theme parks and agricultural shows.

talk.start.para: âThe question is that the amendments be disagreed to.

interjection.para: Question agreed to.
Mr SLIPPER (FisherâParliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration) (1.24 a.m.)â I present the reasons for the House disagreeing to the Senate amendments. I move:

motion.para: That the reasons be adopted.

interjection.para: Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: âFor the Treasurer to ignore this $30 billion of revenue is just so much chutzpah from the man who enacted the charter of budget honesty. With the federal budget in deficit last financial year, we know that after 11 years of almost continuous economic growth, all that additional revenue is being spent. That makes Peter Costello not just a big taxer but also a big spender. It is an odd achievement from someone who aspires to be a conservative Prime Minister.

speech.para: After seven budgets, the pattern is clear: the Liberal government's response to every bump in the political or economic road is to loosen fiscal policy. It happens on a small scale and it happens on a large scale. At the moment, the Senate is dealing with the Inspector-General of Taxation legislation which has a $2 million bill attached to it, that is simply $2 million to validate a press release that was put out during the election campaign. It happens on a large scale. Last month, the Treasurer revealed that the first home owner scheme has cost the Commonwealth $2.9 billion since July 2000. This government has been a net spender for almost the entire period that it has been in office. In 1996, it is true that it made cuts to the budget. In fact, the cuts that it announced to the budget saved more than $21 billion over four years. After the 1997 budget, when the Treasurer declared victory over the budget deficit, the government immediately began to spend, slightly at first. In that year, the net loosening of all fiscal policy decisions, revenue and expenditure was $296 million. The next year was of course an election year and we saw a net loosening over the budget year and for the next three out years of more than $20 billion. The year 1999 was not an election year but the year after one, when you would have expected the government to be tightening its belt. But no, we saw $11.7 billion of net fiscal loosening over the budget year and the three out years. In 2000, again we saw another net loosening of $7.3 billion over that period. The year 2001, of course, was an election year and one which the government started in a state of absolute political desperation. We saw a net loosening over the budget year and the three out years of $23.9 billion. This year, again, was not an election year, but one when you would have thought that a government that had spent a cool almost $24 billion the year before might have tightened its belt. Yet, with the mid-year economic and fiscal outlook which came outâ(Quorum formed)
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table setting out the net impact of fiscal policy decisions between 1996 and 2002.

talk.start.para: âThe problem with all this munificence is that it has to be paid for and this puts a hard floor under the level of taxes. The big increase in taxation that resulted from the introduction of the GST has meant that politically inspired spending has had a permanent effect lifting the base level of federal taxation and spending in Australia.

speech.para: In summary, the government is taxing more and spending more. This has serious implications for the future and will put a lead weight on future reform. Major reforms such as those outlined by the Board of Taxation in their report on the options to improve Australia's international tax competitiveness and the IMF's call to reduce Australia's high marginal tax rates have serious revenue implications. Had Peter Costello exercised some real fiscal restraint over the last seven years instead of spending an increase in tax of around two per cent of GDP, he would have more room to move on the big issues that influence Australia's economic performance.

Prime Minister Howard has recently suggested that his government will hand back to taxpayers some of the budget surplus in the form of tax cuts. In fact, when he did this, he said, `I am just stating the principle that, if you have a bit left over, the automatic assumption should not be âOh, whacko, we will spend it.â' Unfortunately the Prime Minister already has. The value of the GST income tax cuts of 1 July 2000 have been seriously eroded. The government no longer has the capacity to restore them without either breaking one of its key pledgesâto keep the budget in surplusâor making hard decisions to find extra money somewhere else. The only thing holding the budget surplus together now is the extra tax collected by stealth. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table setting out the budget balance and fiscal drag.
Leave granted.
