debateinfo.title: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT (SMALL BUSINESS PROTECTION) BILL 2002 [NO. 2]

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 26 September, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2]. The bill proposes to amend section 87 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 enabling the ACCC to bring representative actions in respect of breaches of section 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. Members will be well aware of the content of this bill. It is the same bill that Labor set aside on 19 August 2002. The Liberal government has an unflattering history of continually trying to slip into the Trade Practices Act powers that would enable the ACCC to become involved in what are really industrial relations matters. These are matters best heard and resolved through the industrial relations tribunal system.

speech.para: The only analytical evidence supporting this billâevidence that the government appears to be totally reliant uponâis a report by the Australian Law Reform Commission produced in May 1994. Those recommendations are not only eight years old but, importantly, referred to a completely different legal situation to that which exists today. More recently, in August 1999, the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector reported on widening the powers of the ACCC to undertake representative actions. However, that report made no reference to small businesses being disadvantaged as a result of secondary boycotts.

Labor holds firmly to the position that on matters other than industrial relations issues it supports the provision for the ACCC to conduct representative actions under the act. This is particularly in the circumstances where the costs of litigation and the associated legal complexity are beyond the ability of small business to seek legal redress. Therefore, Labor supports the ACCC undertaking representative action on behalf of small businesses for a breach of the Trade Practices Act under the areas where the ACCC currently has an enforcement power and which are properly matters of trade practices law.

However, Labor opposes this bill on the principle that secondary boycotts need to be considered and managed only as matters of industrial relations law. The simple consequences of operating industrial relations matters through the trade practices law would promote an aggressive and less conciliatory approach to the management of industrial disputation. Thus Labor opposes this bill. It does not serve small business well. What this bill really shows is that the Liberal government long ago ran out of good policy ideas on how to improve small business policy. Over the years, the Howard government has consistently and persistently ignored the issues and interests of small business. When it has taken action, it has unfairly added a relentless level of taxation compliance and a corresponding level of business red tape that has transformed one million small businesses into unpaid tax collectors and tax bookkeepers for the government.

The Institute of Chartered Accountants have expressed concerns about inconsistent or incorrect advice from the ATO, an avalanche of unnecessary paperwork and ridiculous compliance requirements under threat of penalties, duplication of demands due to lack of integration of ATO systems and hours wasted on hold on the ATO help line hoping for a response. This has consequences for small business: they are either paying higher fees to their accountants or are themselves facing the same difficulties. In addition, the Howard government has unleashed hundreds of tax auditors on small businesses to check their compliance with the complex GST. The budget included an extra $804.3 million for the ATO over the next four years to enhance GST administration. Of that, some $190 million has been allocated to small business GST field services to raise an additional $130 million in GST revenue each year. The tax office hopes to raise an additional $3 in revenue for each extra dollar spent on tax administration. That will be a lot of additional GST audits.

The Yellow PagesÂ®Business Indexâ Small and Medium Enterprises released last week shows that small businesses second most important criticism of the federal government was the GST and its associated paperwork. Labor, unlike the Liberal government, wants to assist small business, not hinder it. Labor has introduced into the House a private member's bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment (A Simpler Business Activity Statement) Bill 2002, which will enable a simpler method for small businesses to calculate their GST remittance. Under Labor's simpler BAS option, each registered business using the ratio method would be given a GST ratio based on its own trading circumstances. The GST liability would be calculated by multiplying business turnover by this ratio.

The simpler BAS option also provides a safe harbour from the potential costs arising from any tax audit. Currently, businesses being audited may have to justify every separate input tax credit claim and account for every separate taxable sale. That is what this self-proclaimed pro-small business government has done to small businessâit has driven it to its knees, accounting for every transaction. But under the ratio method, all small business has to do is show that all turnover has been disclosed. This is an example of a simple change which would benefit small business enormously.

Another Labor private member's bill introduced into the parliament will ensure that insurance companies pass on to small business the savings achieved as a result of changes to public liability insurance arrangements instead of using them to boost their own profits. The crisis in public liability insurance has impacted most severely on small business. Small businesses are struggling to obtain public liability insurance at affordable prices, but the Howard government has consistently failed to act to protect small business, despite its clear constitutional responsibility. Most recently, copies of a draft private member's bill aiming to crack down on late payment by big business and government to their small business suppliers was circulated for consultation. Late payment continues to be a severe problem for the cash flow of small businesses. A Yellow Pages survey found that small business considered cash flow to be their second top business concern. This was second only to lack of work or sales. But the Howard government has rejected Labor's call to support this bill, calling the issue of late payments esoteric.

Small business also has other issues that the Howard government is failing to address. Those issues include the availability of skilled staff, access to business skills training and tenancy laws. The government's priorities are clearly wrong. This is proven by the same Yellow Pages survey released last week that found small businesses biggest criticism of the Howard government's policies was that they were too concerned with big business.

The issues I have identified today are real issues facing small business. The Liberal government should be devoting resources to address these issues instead of playing wedge politics, as shown by this bill. The Howard government is planning to force more red tape on small business with its plan for so-called superannuation choice. Labor proposes to exempt small business from the choice regime to reduce an already overweight compliance burden. (Quorum formed)

If the government really wanted to take some action on trade practices, it would join with Labor in supporting the reforms to introduce criminal sanctions for the most extreme abuses of market power. Instead, the Liberal government prefers to attack the ACCC and Professor Fels. The ACCC is there to ensure strong competition and to protect consumers and small business. It should be supported in performing this function, not attacked and undermined by the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and other ministers.

Further, if the government were genuinely interested in helping small business, it would address the difficulties that small business encounters when dealing with big business. Instead, the Inside Canberra newsletter has reported that Mr Hockey told a meeting of the National Small Business Forum on 20 September 2002 that his department had agreed not to put in a submission to the Dawson inquiry at the urging of many small business groups. But in Senate estimates, in response to Senator Conroy's question, Mr Hockey's department admitted that not one small business group had contacted them to urge them not to respond to the Dawson inquiry.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I am listening attentively to this speech, because I have been called in here so frequently for quorums. I am trying to find a bill called the Joe Hockey bill on the Notice Paper, and I cannot find one. I wonder whether you could direct the member to address the bill, whatever it may be, so that those listening might know what on earth he is talking about.

âThe member for Mackellar would make a more powerful point of order if she were aware of what the bill happens to be. The member for Kingston has the call. The bill is the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2].
âI am applying the same standardsâ
âSame standards as whom?

âI won't go there. In February 2002, the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce released its local business and regional affairs survey. The results revealed that in regional New South Wales 61 per cent thought that large firms misused their market power and 67 per cent thought that the ACCC should have more power to halt anticompetitive conduct. However, the government remained silent on these findings.

speech.para: As this bill clearly shows, the Howard government has lost touch with the concerns of small business. It has also been woefully recalcitrant in dealing with problems of tax administration, public liability insurance and late payment by big business, issues which go to the heart of running a small business. Labor are opposed to this bill and, when the time comes, we will be voting against it here and in the other place.

talk.start.para: âI am thrilled to rise to speak on the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2] because this bill deals with an issue of fundamental importance. It deals with an issue that cuts to the morality of what we are, who we are and how we live in our society because it addresses one of the great evils. That evil is not simply about trade practices; it is about the notion of bullying. Bullying is the use of force by a stronger actor against a weaker actor to intimidate for personal gain. This bill is about overcoming a problem of bullying within our society. It is about the abuse of power against the defenceless. In this particular case it is about overcoming the problem of secondary boycotts by collective labour against small businesses, which are often run by individuals or a small number of people who have no capacity to protect and defend themselves.
âName one!

âIn my electorate of Flinders there are 6,000 fine small businesses. (Quorum formed) As I said, this bill is about overcoming the effects of pernicious acts of bullyingâbullying that is rife within our industrial relations system. It is rife because collective labour is abusing its position. The member for Kingston asked me a challenging question. He asked me to identify a secondary boycott within my electorate. Let me start with one of the more prominent ones in the last few months. We had a major strike at BHP Steel. BHP Steel was subject to actions by the ETU, the CFMEU and a number of other unions. A series of small businesses and small to medium enterprises within the electorate are in the supply and support area for BHP Steel, and almost all of them went close to the wall. If this bill had been in place and they had been able to receive support from the ACCC, they would have been in a much stronger position and they would have been protected. So go ahead: ask me more questions; I could not be more delighted, my friend.
âThe member for Flinders will address his remarks through the chair.
âI was referring to the chair when I said, `My friend.'
âThe member for Flinders may continue.

âIn continuation, this bill operates by providing the ACCC with the capacity to act as a protector and defender of small businesses which would otherwise not be capable of mustering the economic, legal or general administrative resources to take on a major national organisation.

speech.para: I want to deal with three things in addressing the bill: the background, its importance and the core provisions. In looking at the background, we find that small business accounts for 95 per cent of all business in Australia's economy and that those 95 per cent collectively employ approximately 50 per cent of Australia's labour force. But that 50 per cent is largely un-unionised and largely subject to the dictates of the collective national organisations if they subsequently become victims of secondary boycotts. Small businesses in particular suffer substantially from restrictive trade practices. The reason is that most are self-funded and rely on narrow profit margins: they cannot afford costly legal disputes and disruptions to trade. Unnecessary union disruptions have adverse effects on producers and consumers and lead to inefficient outcomes.

talk.start.para: âWhat about people, you dope?
âI respect the fundamental right of people to give or to withhold their labour. That is absolutely a core right within our society.
âWhat about talking to them?
âThe member for Lilley! I expected courtesy to be extended to the member for Kingston, and I maintain that the same courtesy will be extended to the member for Flinders.

âIt is not a right to take your dispute between one party and another and make a third party the intended or the unintentional victim. That is not the way we operate, that is not what we believe is acceptable and that is not something which we should be upholding or defending. The purpose of the bill, very simply, is to amend section 87 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 by allowing the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to take representative action against the losses incurred by small businesses through secondary boycotts.

speech.para: What is the importance of the bill? The bill achieves a number of objectives. It will ultimately provide increased protection to small businesses against disruptive and potentially harmful union action. It does this by allowing the ACCC to take representative actions against contraventions of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. Small businesses using this process can claim compensation for union disruptions aimed at causing significant lossesâso there is a notion of intention. Small businesses can also claim compensation against union agreements with workers which affect the supply of goods and services. What could be simpler and fairer than to say that a party which is not directly engaged in a dispute should be protected from the harmful consequences of that dispute? That is unless we say that there is a new principle afoot hereâthat what we allow is an intended victimisation of third parties to achieve a political end. Is that the sort of collateral damage which is encouraged? We have had experience of that in this country over the last yearâthe notion that collateral damage is not an acceptable approach and not a way to carry out actions.

Very simply, I believe that this is a bill of great importance. Essentially, its provisions are as follows. Item 1 of schedule 1 enables the ACCC to claim damages against union activities that contravene sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. This increases the power of the ACCC to support small businesses. Item 2 of schedule 1 outlines the appropriate procedures the ACCC must satisfy prior to any representative action. The effect of this change is to allow the ACCC to initiate proceedings against any breaches under the relevant provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

Ultimately, this bill is about three things: supporting the small business sector; increasing the competitiveness and resilience of the small business sector; and, above all else, placing a stake in the ground and saying that there are certain fundamental principles about bullying which cannot stand. You cannot allow a position where a large national organisation intentionally takes action in order to achieve a particular end, whereby it will claim collateral damage and a victim along the way. If that is not their approach, if that is not their intention, then they have nothing to worry about. But this legislation provides protection for those who would otherwise not be able to protect themselves. There is nothing more fundamentally Australian than fighting against bullying, standing up for those who need protection and standing up for the rights of small businessesâpeople who go out there and do it for themselves, and work, struggle and sweat to build this country. I commend this bill with all my belief.

talk.start.para: âThat was a rather repetitive contribution from the member for Flinders. I note that he had 20 minutes allocated to him to make a contribution to this bill. He took just 10, which I thinkâ
âIt's quality, not quantity.

âAre you serious? The member for Boothby cannot be serious. The member for Flinders had 20 minutes allocated to him and he took just 10, but he feigned commitment to the small business sector. I did not have the opportunity to do the calculation, but I suggest that he repeated at least one line 6,000 times. I give the member for Flinders some latitude as he has not been in this place for very long and he certainly was not here when the so-called Baird committee deliberated on these issues as they relate to the Trade Practices Act.

speech.para: The member for Flinders gave the impression that he might have worked for Peter Reith in the past. I thought he had worked for the current minister for foreign affairs, but one could form the view, based on his contribution tonight, that he might have worked for one Peter Reith, because he has this ideological obsession with the trade union movement. However, the point is that he has ignored all the facts.

It should be no surprise that I should rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 2002, because I am a former shadow minister for small business and have a very deep-seated interest in the small business community in this country. I acknowledge the contribution that the small business sector makes to the Australian economy. It is a growing contribution. We all acknowledge the changing nature of the Australian economy. Our workplaces are growing much smaller. We are working with much smaller business units in the modern economy. The Fordist regime is behind us. The small business sector will play an increasingly important role in the Australian economy.

However, the member for Flinders misses the point in all of this. The key point is that this is a non-event; this is a red herring. I sat on the Baird committee, as did the member for Eden-Monaro, and this issue was not raised with the committee. The member for Scullin is in the House this morning and he also sat on the committee. This is an issue that was not raised with the Baird committee. I remind the House that the impetus for the establishment of the Baird committee was a Labor Party commitment prior to the 1998 election to hold an inquiry into market concentration in the retail sector. It was the Labor Party which first acknowledged that that market concentration was causing problems for the small business sector. They were having difficulty competing with the Woolworths and the Coles of this world.

It was Labor who first committed to addressing those problems and, reluctantly, the Howard government was dragged screaming to match that commitment prior to the 1998 election. I remember it very well. I was surprised at the end of the day that they had committed themselves to doing so because, as we all know, the Howard government is not about markets; it is about big business. It is not about small business. It relies on big business for its patronage and for its political donations. So I was surprised but pleased that the Howard government matched Labor's commitment to hold an inquiry into market concentration in the retail sector.

We got through the 1998 election and, unfortunately, the Labor Party lostâI can acknowledge that. The Howard government then had to turn its mind as it did. I note that the minister for small business is entering the chamber now. What an opportunity for him to make a contribution to this debate. Following the election, the Howard government had to make good on its commitment to hold this inquiry. Of course, there was a lot of jostling going on on the other side of the House at that point about positions on the front bench. The member for Cook was one of those lobbying hard for a guernsey but, alas, he missed out so he was given second prizeâhe was made the Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector.

But the member for Cook did not realise at the time that he was being handed the poisoned chalice, because he was given a brief that the Howard government did not support. He was told to hold an inquiry but was told quite clearly not to expect to make any recommendations that would be supported by the government. In other words: `Go and do the inquiry, member for Cook, but don't go in too hard. Don't do too much for the small business sector. Don't make any effective recommendations to the government because, at the end of the day, the Howard government is for the big end of town. We feign interest in the small business sector, but at the end of the day we know where our bread is butteredâit is the big end of town. So don't expect to come back to us with recommendations that are going to help the small business sector at the expense of the big end of town.'

The member for Cook accepted the brief and away he went, and we held a fairly extensive inquiry. It was an informative inquiry. We heard all sorts of evidence about the impact of market concentration in the retail sector and the impact it had on the small business sector and its ability to compete in the marketplace. We heard some very sad stories about the misuse of that market power on behalf of the big end of town and the impact of that on the small business sector.

It was also effective in the sense that there was a bipartisan spiritâI know the member for Scullin will agreeâand a bipartisan approach to the recommendations of that committee. We all agreed that part IV of the Trade Practices Act had to be strengthened because there were fines for misuse of market power of up to $10 million, if I remember correctly, but they were not of any assistance to the small business person who had been affected by the misuse of market power. So we agreed unanimously that part IV of the Trade Practices Act should be strengthened so that not only big business could be fined for misuse of market power but also, while the ACCC has the big end of town in the commission, they could also seek compensation for the small business that has been affected by that misuse of market power.

We all agreed on that, but we had a minor disagreement on one pointâthat is, sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. The Labor Party do not believe that 45D and 45E should be in the Trade Practices Act. We think they are best enshrined in industrial relations law, so why would the Labor Party seek to extend the representative action powers of the ACCC to 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act? It makes no sense. Yet what did the government do? The government held the opposition and the small business sector to ransom. Rather than accept there was no point in insisting that the additional representative action powers of the ACCC go to 45D and 45E, rather than just allow that to be carved out and got on with, the government dug in. Months went past, a period in which small business could have had access to these new provisions. But the government was not concerned about the small business sector; it was concerned about the politics of it because, at the end of the day, it is always about the trade union movement. We saw the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations earlier in the week waxing lyrical about New South Wales legislation which enshrined the role of the mine workers union in New South Wales to play its part in safety issues in the coalmining industry.

talk.start.para: âAt least you stood up for them.

âI did stick up for them. That is a practice that has been going on for decades. It has been enshrined in regulation for decades. All the New South Wales government was seeking to do was take that a step further and enshrine it in the legislation itself, but Minister Abbott had a problem with that. Why? Because he saw another opportunity to give the trade union movement a whack and, at the same time, give the Labor Party a whack by virtue of the close association between the trade union movement and the Australian Labor Party. This is just silly. This is a government that is not driven by an interest in the small business sector; it is driven by an ideological obsession with the trade union movement.

âThe member for Hunter will understand that I have for the last five minutes or so been waiting for him to come back to the point he was making about the bill on small business protection. I am not denying him the call, I am inviting him to return to the bill.

âI am making a point about the bill, Mr Speaker. The point I am trying to make is that the government waxes lyrical about the need to extend the ACCC's power to take representative action under 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act, yet the member for Flinders, when challenged to give an example of where small businessâ
âI did give an example.

âYou mentioned the BHP case. If I remember correctly, that was a case about market power and nothing to do with 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. So the member for Flinders might want to go and check that, and the member for Eden-Monaro might want to as well. He was very confident about the proposition put forward by the member for Flinders but I do not hear him challenging me at the moment. The member for Flinders might want to check his facts about the BHP case. My memory is that it was not a case about secondary boycotts.

speech.para: The member for Flinders has still failed to give us an example of where the small business sector has been disadvantaged by a secondary boycott. I thought former minister Reith up at the dispatch box day in and day out throughout the course of the MUA dispute would have been giving us examples of small businesses that had been affected by secondary boycotts throughout the course of that dispute. I do not remember him giving one example. I remember with very great clarity that, throughout the course of the Baird inquiry, not once did we receive a submission claiming that the small business sector needed an extension of the ACCC's power to take action under 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. Nor at any point did we ever hear of a case where small business had been affected by a secondary boycott contrary to 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. This is simply a non-event.

If the government were serious, they would have said, `Well, we accept that there were numerous submissions to the Baird inquiry that suggested that, under section 46 of the Trade Practices Act, misuse of market power, it is time to give the ACCC additional powers to take action for compensation for small business,' and forgot about 45D and E because it was not an issue. Rather than do thatâand this is the point and why I transgressed a littleâthe government put their ideological obsession with the trade union movement ahead of the interests of small business. That is what it was all about.

talk.start.para: âI am happy to return to the bill. The bill is about extending powers to the ACCC to take representative action on behalf of small business. The Labor Party and the government agree wholeheartedly that under section 46, covering all those misuses of market power provisions, when the ACCC is in the court prosecuting the big end of town for doing the wrong thing, at the same time it should be able to take action to gain compensation for the small business that has been affected. But 45D and E are not an issue. When the Labor Party moved amendments in this place to carve out 45D and E, I would have been happy for the government to stick to their view on those sections. They should have said, `Look, we would prefer 45D and E to remain in the provisions. If we can't have that, for goodness sake, let's make sure the ACCC picks up these extra powers under section 46 of the Trade Practices Act.'

speech.para: That would have been an eminently sensible thing for the government to do. But the government are not interested in small business. It is a bit like the ASIO bills. They feign concern about national security issues, but at the end of the day it is all about the wedgeânot small business and not national security. They say, `Let's bring legislation in here that we know is unacceptable to the Labor Party and drive the wedge in. Let's hold national security to ransom; let's hold the small business sector to ransom. It doesn't matter whether the small business sector is going to be disadvantaged in the interim.' We had the Baird committee report a long time agoâthe member for Scullin might assist me; he waves it around; I was confident he would have all his information before himâand we are still arguing the case. The ACCC still does not have additional powers to take representative action.

talk.start.para: âI am sure it is not lack of information that prevents the member for Scullin from assisting but, I suspect, his understanding of the standing orders.

âThe ACCC should have these additional powers now, but, no, the government just drive the wedge in all the time, feigning concern for the small business sector and feigning concern on national security. But at the end of the day it is just about the wedge.

âThe member for Indi interjects. I have always got a great interest in the interjections of the member for Indi. She claims to represent the interests of the small business sector. I never hear her putting forward any sound propositions to assist the small business sector. I heard her very loud support for the GST. Isn't it funny? The Treasurer stands at the dispatch box each day in question time waxing lyrical about the GST, having us all believe that the transition has been just marvellous for the small business sector. He has closed his ears. Of course the small business sector is still struggling with the introduction of the GST. Of course it has increased their compliance costs burden. Yet all the government are interested in doing is driving the wedge in. We saw another example in the House yesterday during question time, by virtue of the contribution of the member for Werriwa, where a builder had given services to the ministerâ
âThat's Bob the Builder!
âBob the Builder; I will get to him in a minute. The Minister for Revenue owed $40,000.
âI can pass my folder across to him.
âThe Minister for Small Business and Tourism does not have the call.
âI was hoping Bob the Builder would come inâ
âThe member for Hunter will return to the bill.
âbecause it seems the only interest the coalition has in small business in recent days is in ensuring that Bob the Builder in Port Stephens gets an opportunity toâ(Time expired)

âAs I indicated to you, Mr Speaker, this could be a heroic contribution to this debate. I will try, because I want to make one point about this debateâand I am pleased that there are at least a number of people in the chamber. This bill is a double dissolution trigger, a section 57 trigger. If those in the chamber look at the blue, they will see that the title of the bill is the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2]. The square brackets mean that it is a section 57 trigger bill, and here we are at 3.45 a.m. on the last sitting day of this session discussing this bill.

speech.para: When the honourable member for Flinders gets on his feet and says he is thrilled to debate this bill, I just wonder why he does not have other colleagues supporting him on this bill. The minister knows that this bill was down for debate last week, and one of the reasons that he put it off is because he knows that he has difficulty getting it through the Senate. This is just a stuntâan absolute stunt. It is being set up for ideological reasons, and the honourable member for Hunter went through those. talk.start.para: âI am pleased that a number of members of the class of 2001 want to talk about action. They suggest that, in talking about a report from 1997, we are living in the past. speech.para: I would particularly like to address a point that was raised by the opposition about whether it is an industrial relations issue or whether it is a restrictive trade practices issue. Far too often, it is the union movement that resorts to thuggery to achieve an outcomeâas has been demonstrated when they have blockaded wharves and this government stood up to them, when they blockaded other businesses or when they charged in and destroyed premises, as was demonstrated by the royal commission into building practices. Far too often, the consequences of this thuggery is that it is small businesses, the mums and dads, the people who work 60- or 70-hour weeks to generate and operate a profitable small business, who are adversely affected by those who are quite happy to skim off the union fees that are paid, not having to actually be accountable for their wages. For those people to make the decision, `Let's go and blockade this wharf and, if the consequences of that are that many small businesses go bankrupt, so be it'â

âI will certainly be publicising in my electorate the way the Labor Party treats the operation of this House, even if it is 4.20 in the morning. âI hardly think I could be outside the standing orders if I am reading the provisions of the bill. Paragraph 87(1A)(b) says:

speech.para: This is not just a question of relevance. This is what you do not get from ministers answering questions: contextual relevance. Item 2 is paragraph 87(1B)(a):

speech.para: That is relatively simple, you would think, but there is actually no more to the bill. So we could finish there, but I am sorry to say that we will not. There is a little bit more to this in terms of its design and intent. There have been very few speakers on this bill on the coalition side. Perhaps they were not drawn to it, because of the flimsy nature of this bill and the fact that it had been through the House. I was delighted by the superb speech made by the member for Scullinârather than the member for ScullionâDeputy Speaker Jenkins, who is now in the chair. Not only was he on fire but he put the arguments very well and dealt with the Baird committee report that dealt with the trade practices matters relevant to this bill today and with the Reid report. I remember Bruce Reid and his report into shopping centres, I think it was: the operation of shopping centres, market power and the fact that Woolworths and Coles dominate the market.

As the member for Hunter pointed out, these reports were generated by the concerns of the Labor government before they lost government in 1996. The core of what the current government has arguedânot particularly well, I would advertâis that, while the Labor Party does not really understand what they are about here, in making these changes to the Trade Practices Act 1974, they are about looking after small business. They have that concern at the very core of what they deal with in all of their government practices, and that is the one key thing they have been committed to. Well, if you believe that line you are readily taken in. The argument they put was that Labor does not understandâspeaking contextually relevantly to the billâthat, when they say this was in the industrial relations area and that this is the area it should be in, they are mixing things up.

That is part of the key to our reaction to this bill. This is not about secondary boycotts, but that is all that the government members can talk about. Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act are an utter obsession and an utter fixation for this coalition. That has been the case for the Prime Minister since 1974 when he walked out of a suburban solicitors' practice and into parliament. It is an obsession that the coalition cannot get away from, and one that totally fixates and transfixes them. I am sorry; the argument just does not wash. Secondary boycotts are illegal under this coalition government. That is not news. What may be news to the government, and certainly to the members who have spoken in this debate, is that secondary boycotts were illegal under the Keating and Hawke Labor governments. The core point of the coalition's argument has no foundation in fact. This is not about secondary boycotts. What we have argued is simply that the illegality of the prohibition of secondary boycotts lies in the industrial relations area.

If this legislation is passed in the House tonight, despite what I have said and will say, despite what the distinguished Deputy Speaker Jenkins argued so cogentlyâand, indeed, at 3.45 in the morning, coherentlyâand despite what the member for Hunter argued, it will be a half step away from becoming a trigger for a double dissolution. That will be sometime next year, if the government get around to putting it up to the Senate and if it gets knocked over again. The core point is: knowing that secondary boycotts are illegal and were prohibited not only by them but by us, why have the government taken a certain range of actions to stop us talking about this bill? The minister at the table is seeking advice on doing that now. The reason is that there has been a bit of contracting out and a bit of consultation. We know that there have been a few consultants to this government. We know that the former minister for industrial relations, former member for Flinders Peter Reith, hired a consultant to look at this areaâto look at what the problems were and at how to make a transition from the Industrial Relations Commission. We know that the Industrial Relations Commission was founded in 1904 and I think the Harvester decision was its most significant early decision in 1905. Although industrial relations have worked so successfully in this country, the government wanted to obliterate the Industrial Relations Commission. When former Minister Reith got Des Moore to take up an appointment as a consultant to look into this area, he knew that secondary boycotts were illegal. But the brief to Des Moore was: `Get us out of the industrial relations area and take us into trade practices. Tell us how we can move from one area to the other. Tell us how we can give power to the ACCC'âas the government are attempting to do with this billâ`to unleash their investigative dogs onto single unions, in pursuit of denying them their right to organise within workplaces.' We have seen it on the waterfront, with the MUA. We have seen the attempt, time and time again, to unleash those forces against individual unions.

Let me go to a particular point. Having established that secondary boycotts are not illegal and, therefore, that they should be kept within the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Act and the industrial relations powers, let us look at one of those key areas. I have already alluded to part 1 of this flimsy bill, which deals with the kind of action that can be taken take under the Trade Practices Act, and what might be permitted. I will simply state the case in terms of what the Bills Digest has said about ACCC representative action. It says:

quote.para: Section 87 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (TPA) permits the ACCC to bring a representative action seeking compensation and other remedies on behalf of people who have suffered, or are likely to suffer loss or damage as a result of another person's contravention of specified provisions of the TPA.

speech.para: Normally when we are dealing with the Trade Practices Act we expect that we are dealing with people involved in a particular industry in a competitive situation and that we are attempting to ensure that non-competitive activity does not occur. It can happen that very large and substantial companies today were once small businesses. It is possible to argueâand I think there are a number of cases in which it can be substantiatedâthat very large companies can sometimes have practices that are extremely uncompetitive. It could be the case that when they were generated and started out they might have had uncompetitive practices as well. Even given the effluxion of time, there may be action that could be taken by the ACCC in relation to competitors.

It just so happens that I know a bit about this. Although I told the House about my mother's family small business background, I have not talked about the most significant small business background in my family history, and that is H. Hatton and Sons of Bankstown. In 1921, when the Torch opened, they were greengrocers and confectioners, but as Bankstown changed and grew my grandfather built a business in construction. Because of the nature of Bankstown, his business covered the whole range of activitiesâthey carted sand and wheat, delivered coal to people throughout the Bankstown area and also advised people on how to build concrete steps, houses, housing extensions and so on. They were renowned in the area and, in Greenacre, which is part of my electorate and the City of Bankstown, they had an ice run. As you would expect with any small company in those days, which my grandfather's company wasâbased in Allum Street in Bankstownâan ice run was pretty hard work. They bought large blocks of ice from the Punchbowl ice company, paid good money for them and then delivered them to people's doorsteps.

talk.start.para: âIt is 25 minutes to five in the morning. I implore the member for Blaxland not to talk about ice runs and to the keep the House going. If there is a way in which this debate can be shortened, it would be appreciated because there are a number of divisions to come.

âThere is a point of utter and complete contextual relevance in this story. It is not just relevant to the Trade Practices Act but also to the very point that the ACCC is being asked to intervene on in relation to this bill. Normally, you would run up and down the street, get people their ice with the tongs, whack it on their doorsteps and take their money. One day, my grandfather and one of my uncles, who were doing the work, went from one end of the street to the other and there was no money at all, yet those people paid for the services they received. They did the next street and the next street and when they found the perpetratorsâthe people who had broken competitive practice and had knocked off the money in the first, second and third streetsâmy grandfather pulled the bloke out of the truck, advised him that it would not be sensible in future to be anticompetitive. He advised him to stop stealing the money that had been left there and to go about his business in another way.

speech.para: I suppose if you are going to be honest about the way you run your business at the startâand that leads to what the company is going to be laterâmaybe you will not actually do as well as other people. My family and my father's family did not succeed, did not become multimillionaires and did not build national companies, but the Fox family certainly did. The Fox family, which started in Bankstown and knocked off the money from my grandfather's ice run, ended up running one of the most significant transport companies in this country; but the basis of it, the building of it, started right in Bankstown, in Greenacre, knocking off a competitor's money. So I am wondering whether, if the provisions of this bill which this minister wants to see go through this House were operative, I or members of my family wouldn't have a claim against the Fox group for the uncompetitive behaviour that they undertook. I am wondering whether, even given the effluxion of time, I wouldn't be able to say to the ACCC, `This should be taken into account, you should be pressing this, rather than being the government's lapdog in terms of secondary boycott action and attempting to belt the daylights out of what the government see as the big problem: the unions.' It might also be the fact that, while the government are saying that they are standing up for small business, they have battered the daylights out of business in Blaxland and they have belted them with the BASâthe Australia card for Australian business. The effect that they have had on the business people in Blaxlandâ

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It is getting even later: 23 minutes to five in the morning. I ask the member for Blaxland to come back to the subject of this bill. The BAS, the new tax system and the economic performance of businesses in Blaxland are not directly related to the content of this bill.
(Mr Jenkins)âThe honourable member for Blaxland will relate his remarks to the bill.

âI am delighted that the minister, the member for North Sydney, has no imagination whatsoever so that he cannot see that what the government has done to small business in my electorate is directly related to what it has put on the table in this parliament. It was this government that brought in the GST. It was this government that brought in the BAS. This is about this government and its rhetoric in relation to the ACCC and what it wants to achieve in this trade practices bill to bring secondary boycott measures and enforcement out of the industrial relations area and into trade practices. It is this government that needs to take responsibility for what has happened to small business and for the position they are in.

speech.para: The government also needs to take account of its own backbenchers. When the Baird committee looked into thisâand we have had an attestation to this from two people from our side who were on the committee: the member for Hunter and the member for Scullin, who is in the chair at the momentânot only our members but also the government members on that committee heard a range of concerns from small business, yet there was no government action to redress those concerns. Fundamentally what they heard was that there was very little concern in relation to sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. No calls were heard from small business in Blaxland or North Sydney or anywhere else for this change in the act to empower the ACCC to take action that they have never been able to take beforeâthat is, to become the government's chief tracker of its key targets: the unions that it sees as being responsible from time to time for secondary boycotts.

I reiterate the point: if you want a double dissolution out of this, go ahead and try and get it. We will see you when you have it, either on this or anything else, and we will deal with the core issues that are presented to the electorate at that timeâwhenever it is. The latest time you have got is around October 2004, Joeâjust to let you know. What we are doing tonight in refusing to accept this bill we have done before. This is not about the Industrial Relations Commission, except for this: that the other key fixation of this government, the one that they cannot simply get over, is that the Industrial Relations Commission has existed, going back almost to the foundation of the Commonwealthâit is only three years shy of itâand it has successfully arbitrated and conciliated industrial disputes. They want to smash it to smithereens, to fragment it to its elemental condition and in fact wipe it off the table. That is what this bill would seek to do. That is the government's agenda with this; that is what they hope to achieve.

This bill may pass here shortly when we vote on it but I do not expect that it will pass the Senate. Its flimsiness cannot cover up the fact that the government's position is not only ideological but driven and fanatical in this regard. To those who before pressed it, like the former Minister for Industrial Relations, the former member for Flinders and the Prime Minister, so fixated and obsessed, and indeed other members of this government, I say that you cannot run industrial relations by whacking the ACCC on your individual unions. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Hockey) adjourned.

speech.para: While I would like to be as brief as I canâand perhaps it gives an opportunity for the opposition to have their say a bit laterâI would reject some of these amendments from the Senate. The government will be moving our own amendments. The disagreement now with this AWT legislation is predominantly with regard to the breaching regime. We believe it is important that that breaching regime is maintained. Indeed, when you compare it to the breaching regime when Labor was last in governmentâif you look at the dollar equivalents in 2002 compared to, let us say, the early ninetiesâthe actual level of breach is substantially higher. In the interests of brevity, I might come back to that subject. I commend these amendments so far to the House.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr ANTHONY
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: âI move:

âThis bill was introduced in May 2002. Seven months later, at almost 5 a.m. on 13 December, we are here dealing with it. That is pretty tragic when you consider the importance of the bill, but it is also pretty tragic when you consider where this bill commenced, which was with former Minister Newman in 1999. That is pretty tragic when you consider we had the McClure report in 2000. I think it says something about the priority that this government has for welfare reform, which is virtually nil. Every time something comes forward, we virtually go backwards. I want to deal with that at some length now.

speech.para: Until five minutes ago, I was led to believe by this government that there was some acceptance of some of the amendments that we successfully moved in the Senateâamendments to do with protecting parents and amendments to do with the mature age unemployed. We had a raft of amendments moved in the Senate. They were accepted in the Senate. We had been led to believe privately by this government that it was going to accept them. Yet we have just arrived here with the minister and have suddenly found out that it is not accepting those amendments; it has moved a whole raft of new amendments which we have not even had the privilege of examining. That is real dirty pool at five in the morning on 13 Decemberâ

talk.start.para: âFriday the 13th!

âThat is right: Friday the 13th. It is real dirty pool to get those sorts of dirty tricks at this hour of the morning. We had been led to believe by this government that it was accepting those amendments and it has come in here with its own amendments. We have not had the opportunity to compare them to our amendments and to make a considered judgment in this important area of public policy affecting parents and affecting the mature age unemployed. All I can say is that I am just completely disgusted by the behaviour of the ministers. This is in an area where we thought we had some agreement. God knows what will happen in the areas where we do not have agreement. This area is pretty important. This is the government that says it believes in family values. How can it have possibly disagreed with the amendments that we moved when it came to sole parents, amendments which said that the new requirements of reciprocal obligation should not conflict with their parenting responsibilities, and other amendments that we have moved in relation to the mature age unemployed? Parents are the best judge of their parenting responsibilities, not governments. We are certainly satisfied with our amendments, but we now do not know what the government is proposing and have not had an opportunity to study what the government has said.

speech.para: The minister is right in one respect: there is a battleground out there, in that Labor has moved a comprehensive set of amendments advocating fairness in the penalty system right across the social security system. We have; we have made no secret of itâwe have campaigned on this issue for years. We have been disgusted by the attitude of Senator Vanstone, who has had a `shoot first, ask questions later' breaching policy. Lots of people out there have been hurt. Huge financial penalties have hit them. They have suffered. The agencies that are at the front line and have had to deal with the consequences of this can testify to how immense the impact of that has beenâtoo many Australians have been unfairly penalised and they have paid a very high price. They have suffered, and they have suffered severe financial disadvantage.

Our amendments in this area are fair and are based on the independent report of the Pearce committee. We think we have put forward in this area of the penalty system across the social security system a balanced package, a package that enhances compliance and increases participation. These amendments ensure good behaviour is rewarded while retaining significant penalties for those who do not play by the rules. We on this side of the House have no time for those who want to rort the system, none at all, but we have a lot of time for those who need the system and we believe in the integrity of the system. This government has no choice but to accept that some change is required and, if need be, we will debate this at length and we will debate it as long as the government wants toâunder any circumstances. (Time expired)

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr ANTHONY
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: âI would like to give some clarification which might be of benefit to the Manager of Opposition Business. I have just been informed by the Clerk that there might be some confusion in that the agreement, from my understanding, that was reached with the opposition was that these amendments that have come back had to come back to the House, had to be rejected and reaccepted because they had to come from the House of Representatives to make them valid constitutionally. So I suspect that a lot of the debate tonight may be unnecessary because on those areas we have agreed. Of course, there are some areas on which we will continue to disagree, and I am sure they will be the subject of a division shortly. That may assist the Manager of Opposition Business. While he briefs himself, I further clarify that the government is very keen to continue with Australians Working Together. It was the next phase following the McClure report. Today the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations launched the second phase of AWT. We believe that the measures that we are putting forward are worth while. Perhaps I will now give the member for Lilley the chance to continue the debate with this newfound knowledge.

âIt is not newfound knowledge; it is knowledge delivered at an hour which is simply unacceptable, in a way which is unacceptable, in a procedure which is unacceptable, in circumstances which are unacceptable. But I am delighted to hear unequivocally that you have accepted our amendments in the area of sole parents and mature age unemployed, because you should have and I am pleased you have. That brings us to the area which is of contention, the battleground, as you described. I guess that battleground comes down to really four areas or possibly five, and I want to talk about them briefly.

speech.para: The first one is the area of the reduction in breach penalty periods from a maximum of 26 weeks to eight weeks. The second one relates to that as well, because we have to balance the reduction in breach penalty periods, with an increase in penalties that would apply each fortnight: from 16 per cent to 20 per cent for a administrative breaches, from 18 per cent to 20 per cent for a first activity breach and from 24 to 25 per cent for a second breach.

The third area relates to restoration of payments on complianceâthat is, when they remedy their error their payments are restored. This measure is particularly important. This is a measure which encourages participation and rewards people who do the right thing. The fourth area relates to the reduction of the accumulation period, where breach penalties may compound, from two years to one year.

We have put forward what we regard as a fair and balanced package. It has its origins in the independent report by Professor Pearce. It is a package of changes that are certainly more than affordable in a $50 billion welfare system. They are changes that encourage participation, they are changes that encourage compliance and they are changes that in many ways, along with the working credit, reward work over welfare. It should not be forgotten that involved in this bill is the working credit, already delayed by this government by nine monthsâa measure which Labor had as its policy when it was in government and which was abolished by this government seven years ago. It is absolutely essential to encouraging people to move from welfare to work by rewarding that effort, in contrast to the situation at the moment where unemployed people who work part time, casually, are taxed 80c in every additional dollar earned over the threshold. If that was the tax rate applying at the top end of town or in middle Australia there would be a riot. Six years ago the government put that in place. I will not go into the detail of thatâwe have debated it on many occasions. But all of these measures need to be set in that context.

We are pretty keen to pursue the amendments that I have outlined in those four areas. But, having said that, Labor is mindful of the need for progress on this bill. We do not want to see a situation where this bill is stalled or there is a deadlock. So, in the Senate, Labor will not necessarily be insisting on every single amendment that we have moved. We do have a core package which will deliver fairness to the people who really deserve it: those who are being unfairly penalised, breached and punished by this government. We will not be party to insisting upon Democrat amendments relating to Austudy, numbered 44, 46, 48, 51, 53 and 55, as these amendments are not consistent with the package which Labor is pursuing. Labor will not pursue amendments relating to the accumulation period. (Extension of time granted) This leaves the remainder of the amendments which, unless there is a breakthrough, we will insist upon in the Senate when the bill returns to that place shortly. They seek to have a reduction in the breach period from 26 weeks to eight weeks, coupled with an increase in the breach rate from 16 per cent to 20 per cent, 18 per cent to 20 per cent and 24 per cent to 25 per cent for those various periods that I described before. The other key group of amendments relate to the waiver of the remaining portion of the breach periods when a job seeker remedies their error.

In summary, the amendments we will be insisting upon are (22), (24), (39), (40), (63), (64), (18), (43), (61), (65), (75), (77), (74), (76), (37) and (42). We believe that these measures are essentialâessential to encourage participation, essential to reward work over welfare, essential to integrity and essential to protect people who should not be unnecessarily punished in this system which is meant to be a safety net. Unfortunately, the safety net for too many people has had huge holes cut in it in recent times. We are keen for the government to keep this bill alive, to see whether we can reach agreement on some component of the Pearce amendments and to progress the working credit. The ball is now in the government's court.
Question put:

motion.para: That the Senate amendments be disagreed to.

debateinfo.title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT (PREGNANCY AND WORK) BILL 2002

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 14 February, on motion by Ms Worth:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âOn the basis of the information communicated by the Leader of the House, I should indicate that I will be most content indeed if my speech on the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002 is interrupted for the purpose of considering the message from Senate. This bill amends the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to partially implement recommendations made by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in its August 2000 report called Pregnant and productive: it's a right not a privilege to work while pregnant. Yesterdayâin fact, it is two days ago nowâthe Prime Minister confirmed just how little interest he has in work and family issues. There was a deafening silence from the Prime Minister's office in response to the release of report of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Pru Goward, on paid maternity leave. In case we needed it, this bill is further evidence of the government's abysmal track record on work and family issues. It is long overdue and it goes only part way to addressing the matters raised in the report to which I have referred. The bill shows just how limited and belated the government's work and family approach is.

speech.para: Over two years ago, in March 2000, the member for Jagajaga introduced into this House a private member's bill with the same title as this bill. That private member's bill amended the Sex Discrimination Act and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act to make sure that pregnant, potentially pregnant and breastfeeding women are not discriminated against in the workplace.

The bill was in response to a clear need for legislative changes, highlighted in the Pregnant and productive report. That report was presented to the Attorney-General in June 1999âover three years ago. The bill before us today implements only some of those recommendations. It has taken three years for the government to introduce a legislative response to that report. Not only is the bill abysmally overdue; it is also totally inadequate. It implements only three out of the 12 recommendations in the report calling for amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act.

Non-discrimination in the workplace is, in fact, like being pregnant. There is no halfway: you cannot be a little bit pregnant and you cannot have only a bit of non-discrimination. A workplace is either free of discrimination or it is not. There is no point settling for half measures. This bill shows that the government is willing to do exactly that: settle for half measures by implementing, three years late, only three recommendations from the pregnancy report for amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act.

When the report was publicly released, Susan Halliday said that the report had uncovered horror stories such as women miscarrying because they were not allowed to sit down at work, men being sacked for attending the births of their babies and women being harassed about their appearance and removed from the front desk where they were visible to the public. In one case documented by the commissioner, a woman working in a car factory was denied a chair, despite bleeding and severe pain. She collapsed at work when seven months pregnant and her baby was born prematurely with an undeveloped heart. Ms Halliday said:

quote.para: Something has to be done. It is fair to say that there are lives at stake here.

speech.para: In the face of such truly shocking stories, it is appalling that it has taken the government so long to implement any of the commission's recommendations. It is willing to settle for only half measures, in fact, only quarter measures, considering three out of the 12 recommendations. For 3Â½ yearsâthat is more than four pregnanciesâhow many pregnant women or new mothers have had to combat a form of discrimination because of the government's inaction?

Whilst discrimination and harassment on the grounds of pregnancy and potential pregnancy are grounds for complaint under the Sex Discrimination Act, the Pregnant and productive report found that workplace discrimination and harassment on these grounds remain real issues for many women, and that clarification of the act is needed in a number of areas. The commission reported that some employees concealed their pregnancy for as long as possible because they feared pregnancy discrimination and that some senior professional women took accrued annual leave, long service leave and the like so that they would not have to reveal and have recorded on their employment records the fact that they had taken maternity leave.

Amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act were overdue three years ago and now the government has introduced a bill of half measures and only half measures. The bill in its current form just does not go far enough. The bill only covers the three areas of the act identified in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report that relate to, firstly, whether discrimination against breastfeeding women is grounds for sex discrimination; secondly, the asking of questions about pregnancy or potential pregnancy during job interviews; and, thirdly, the use of information obtained in medical examinations. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission recommended that the act be amended to make the law in these areas clearer for the benefit of employers and employees, in particular. The report found:

quote.para: Erroneous tactics and exploitative practices are, to this day, being utilised to remove pregnant women from the workplace or deny pregnant, and potentially pregnant women, equal employment opportunity.

speech.para: The bill we are debating redrafts the part of the act that prohibits requests for information that are connected to acts of unlawful discrimination and provides clarification by adding an example of a prohibited question. The bill also adds an explanatory note to make it clear that the exception that allows requests for pregnancy related medical information to be made does not override those provisions of the act which prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex or pregnancy. The operation of the act is expanded by the amendments but they eliminate confusion identified in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report about the meaning and operation of the act regarding pregnancy and pregnancy related issues.

Unfortunately, the bill does not address a number of other legislative changes recommended in the HREOC report. These changes are significant and worthy of noting specifically, and they include: empowering HREOC to publish enforceable standards in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy; allowing referrals by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner to the Industrial Relations Commission of discriminatory awards or agreements without the need for receipt of a written complaint; enabling the award of punitive damages as well as compensatory damages; removing the exemption for educational institutions established for religious purposes in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy; ensuring coverage of unpaid workers; and removing the exemption of employment by an instrumentality of a state.

The amendments the Labor Party propose, in contrast, address 10 of the Pregnant and productive report's 46 recommendations. Our proposals will enhance the rights of pregnant and potentially pregnant women by empowering the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to publish enforceable standards in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy; ensuring unpaid workers are covered by the Sex Discrimination Act; removing the exemption for employment by an instrumentality of a state from the Sex Discrimination Act; removing the exemption for educational institutions established for religious purposes in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy; allowing punitive damages to be awarded, specifically including breastfeeding as grounds for unlawful discrimination; allowing the Sex Discrimination Commissioner to refer discriminatory awards or agreements to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission without the requirement to receive a written complaint; clarifying that a complaint about a discriminatory advertisement may be made by any person; clarifying that the asking of questions to elicit information about whether and when a woman intends to become pregnant and/or her intentions in relation to meeting her current or pending family responsibilities is unlawful; and, finally, clarifying that it is unlawful to discriminate in medical examinations of pregnant women during the recruitment process. They also extend the antidiscrimination provisions to employees who are in the process of adopting a child.

Improving the protections for pregnant women is important, but it is just the tip of the iceberg. A lot more in terms of policy change is needed. Australia needs a sea change in policies and attitudes that are hindering the capacity of women to take on and survive the complex responsibilities of work on the one hand and family commitments on the other. It is time women, particularly women who are thinking about starting a family and women who have young families, are supported by policies that will make a difference to their lives and assist them to balance those competing responsibilities. I am not referring to how women who are corporate high-flyers with nannies, housekeepers and the like cope with the challenges they confront but to the millions of Australian mothers whose jobs are the safety net for their family's economic survival. They literally work to pay bills; they work to support their families. With the dramatic increase in real estate prices and dramatic increase in credit card indebtedness, it is becoming more the norm for families to require two incomes to surviveâand certainly to survive in the capital cities in Australia, where most families reside.

But the Howard government refuses to recognise that most families just cannot afford to have one parent at home full-time for five years and that most women who leave work to have a baby return to work at some stage after the birth. The proof is in the statistics. Well over 60 per cent of Australian women spend their baby's first year out of the paid work force, but more than half of new mothers in two-parent families are back at work before their babies are two years old. By the time their children have turned three, nearly 70 per cent of mothers these days are back in the work force, usually, as I indicated, as a result of those economic pressures. Mothers understand the importance of staying attached to the work force during these early child-rearing years. Their preference is for part-time work. Among parents of dependent children, in June 2000 57 per cent of employed partnered mothers and five per cent of employed partnered fathers worked part time.

What the statistics do not show are the difficulties, the pressures and the anxieties experienced by parents as they negotiate the demands of their double lives. Research is increasingly showing the anxieties and pressures and the effect of those pressures faced by children in circumstances where their parents are trying to balance the challenges of both work and family responsibilities. Now it seems many young women think it is all too hard and are in fact deciding not to have children. The evidence is indisputable. Australian women are having fewer babies. The birthrate fell dramatically from 3.5 babies per woman in the early 1960s to just 1.7 in 2001. That is the lowest rate on record. It is down from 1.75 children on average in the year 2000 and much worse than the previous lows of 1.86 and 1.94 recorded in 1991 and 1981, when those figures were last taken. We are in very real danger of becoming a baby-free society, a place where children are a private responsibility that must never impinge on a parent's working life. If that culture becomes our culture, we will see that birthrate declining even more rapidly.

The Prime Minister's policies are creating this baby-free society. The Prime Minister's ideological preference is a world where men are breadwinners, women are full-time homemakers and children are at home with their mothers until they start school. The government's tax and welfare policies clearly favour single-income families. For example, the government's family tax benefit B is only available to single-income families. The election conceived baby bonus offends all notions of equity. It provides the greatest financial help to those who need it least and it is quickly eroded if the stay-at-home parent earns any part-time money. The everyday reality is that it just does not work according to the Prime Minister's view of life. The Howard government's policies reflect a narrow, conservative ideology, not the reality of most families, where both parents work because of the financial pressures that they face these days. That is why Labor is pushing for a sea change in policy and attitude and why it is committed to catching up with the rest of the world and introducing a system of paid maternity leave.

The difference between the government and the opposition is clear on this critical issue. The day before yesterday, when the Sex Discrimination Commissioner released her paid maternity leave report, the opposition were crystal clear about our position: we are committed to introducing paid maternity leave. There is absolutely no ambiguity about where we stand. We had a barbecue to welcome the report because where the Prime Minister says that work and family issues are barbecue stoppers, we think they should be a barbecue starter. We believe that a good barbecue must have two ingredients. Firstly, it needs a family and, secondly, it needs some time for people to get together. Without work and family policies like paid maternity leave, people will be less willing to start families and will have less time for activities such as barbecues and simply spending time with the kids. As I said before, not only is that a stress and a strain for parents; it is detrimental to the interests of children.

The fact that the government does not support work and family provisions like paid maternity leave makes them, literally, a barbecue stopper. Australia is just one of the two developed countries that does not yet have a paid maternity leave scheme. Countries we are lagging behind include Japan, Canada, Austria, Italy, the United Kingdom, Norway, the Slovak Republic and New Zealand. Countries which have suitable family friendly policies have a higher birthrate where assistance is provided to families to have children. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

âI very much regret to have to inform members of further disruptions to our late night and early morning. My understanding is that, in order to try to facilitate the passage of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002, it is now the plan of the Attorney-General to accept some amendments which the Senate has proposed but reject others. This means that the bill will have to go from here back to the Senate for further consideration. If the Senate accepts the bill as it leaves this House then we will be able to go home. âWhat is the time frame for the return of the bill?
âI believe it is not far off.
âI recognise the question by the member for Fraser. I think members would like a time frame, if possible. It would be very helpful.

âI cannot give a definite time frame but I was told, about 20 minutes ago, that it was not far off. Let us hope that by the time the member for Barton has finished his typically excellent presentation on this bill we are able to get on to the ASIO bill. We will not, I fear, be able to count on those early morning planes that I thought we would be able to just half an hour ago.

âMr Speaker, I have a question to you on indulgence. I am told that when we used to sit through the night in the Old Parliament House breakfast facilities were provided for members and, more importantly, for the staff who had worked all night. I was just wondering if there were any facilities available, particularly for staff who have worked all night? As members would know, the cafeteria does not open till 8 a.m.

âIt might have been more opportune had the Chief Government Whip put this proposal to me last night before staff had returned. Given the kitchenette catering facilities in each office, members will be forced to make toast and coffee. If, as has been indicated, the conclusion of the member for Barton's speech may mark the introduction of the ASIO bill, I would suggest that the clock would be set at about one minute. But I do not think that would be fair to the member for Barton, who I now recognise.
