He said that was a matter of conjecture: perhaps it was for sustenance and perhaps it was to relieve some inebriation.

debateinfo.title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT (PREGNANCY AND WORK) BILL 2002

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: âAustralia is just one of two developed countries that does not yet have a maternity leave scheme. As I indicated, a number of countriesâJapan, Canada, Austria, Italy, the United Kingdom, Norway, the Slovak Republic and New Zealandâhave maternity leave schemes. The Howard government is determined to fight Australia's progress on the issue. I understand that the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations is reported to have said that the government would never introduce a paid maternity leave scheme. I think his words were to the effect of `over this government's dead body'.
âYou want to read the fine print.

âWe will have a look at the totality of the wording, but they were certainly the sentiments as I recall them. I believe the Minister for Finance and Administration, the Minister for Small Business and Tourism and the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer have expressed similar sentiments. They all say that they do not support paid maternity leave for all working women. They prefer a system where only middle-class professionals who work for large organisations have access to paid maternity leave and women in low-income jobs and small businesses do not.

speech.para: The day before yesterday the government's response to the Goward report consisted of a terse, five-line statement from the Minister for Family and Community Services thanking the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and still refusing to commit to introducing statutory paid maternity leave. A more detailed response came from the chief executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr Peter Hendy, who was the education minister's chief of staff as well as a senior advisor to former defence minister Peter Reith. Mr Hendy's response was unequivocal: he did not support a system of paid maternity leave for all working women even if the government funded it. We find it difficult to accept that ACCI would not accept a system of paid maternity leave even if the government funded it.

It is clear that the Howard government will not introduce paid maternity leave. What is more, if the length of time the government has taken to introduce the bill we are now debating is an indication, it will be many long years before we get even some response to the Goward report. But a Crean government will introduce paid maternity leave in a form that does not burden small business, because we believe it is a fundamental part of Labor's strategy for working families. Paid maternity leave means that mothers who work will be financially able to take time out of the work force to recover from childbirth. It provides relief and respite while ensuring that women do not lose connection with the workplace and that, in the meantime, bills can be paid and mortgage commitments can be satisfied.

The aim of paid maternity leave is to make a contribution towards the income a woman forgoes when she leaves work to have a baby, and during the subsequent necessary period of leave needed for the health and welfare of both the mother and the newborn baby. But paid maternity leave is not the beginning and end of work and family issues. We understand and fully appreciate that. Paid maternity leave is a fundamental part of the work and family balance, but in itself it is not sufficient to help families meet the challenges and joys that a new child brings. Families confronting that life-changing event need one thing above all else: more options to suit their particular circumstancesâmore options for striking the balance between work, family and other activities, such as study, that best suit their needs and those of their children.

There is no `one size fits all' solution for families because no two families are alike; no two families need the same solution. Parents need a range of possible options so that they develop a solution that suits their needs. Parents want the flexibility to choose different solutions at different stages of their lives. Some parents may want to stay at home with their children, others will return to full-time work as soon as possible, others may want to return to part-time work. We need to support and encourage this diversity between families by giving parents a range of viable alternativesâat least for the first five years of a child's life, when clearly children are heavily dependent on the support and nurturing of their parents. Parents need to be able to construct their own long-term parenting plan from a number of options. Discrimination against pregnant women in the workplace must become a thing of the past. That is what a genuinely family friendly environment, we believe, looks like. I urge the government to accept the opposition's amendment to the bill to help realise that environment. I move the following second reading amendment:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

âwhilst supporting the particular amendments proposed in the bill, the House calls on the Government to support all the legislative amendments and other actions necessary to give effect to the recommendations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in its report Pregnant and productive: It's a right not a privilege to work while pregnantâ.

talk.start.para: âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second that amendment and reserve my right to speak.

âThe original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Barton has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

âI rise to speak to the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002. I am honoured today to stand in this parliament and to be a part of the coalition team. The coalition government during the last six years of leadership have worked tirelessly for the rights of women. Through this parliament we have successfully passed many pieces of legislation that have sought to improve the working conditions and the working environment for women and to reduce discrimination against us. Today we are implementing legislation that will provide greater clarity and address evolving attitudes towards women in the workplace. The implementation of the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Act 1999 heralded better equal opportunity outcomes for women by allowing employers to focus on actions and achievements. In conjunction with the Workplace Relations Act 1996, which contained provisions relating to equal remuneration for work of equal value amongst men and women, the economic status of working women improved and is continuing to improve.

speech.para: One of the principal objectives of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 is to assist employees to balance their work and family responsibilities. Under this act, we as the government have taken action to remove arbitrary restrictions on part-time employment and to also encourage increased award provisions for part-time employment. In addition, there has been an overall increase in the number of family friendly provisions in collective agreements, with approximately 76 per cent of agreements in 1999 containing at least one family friendly measure, including flexible hours provisions. There is no doubt that there has been a huge increase in the participation rate of women in the work force. At the moment that participation rate is at 55 per cent. That is one of the highest in history. It is important that we note that it is striking a balance between work and familyâand work and family issues are more important than ever before.

The participation rate, which I am sure my colleagues opposite would welcome, is a result of a number of factors, including very strong economic conditions, greater flexibility in the work force, and a child-care sector that is flexible and enables more women to combine work and family. There are over four million women in the Australian paid work force at the moment. As a single mother in the past who has had to raise children, I know all too well the difficulties of balancing family and work life. I see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister is sitting at the table. I know that she has an interesting time, as do many mothers on the opposite side of the chamber and on our side of the House. Also, being a small business owner operator, I understand the issues we face and the need to have effective government policy to coordinate our involvement in the work force and our commitment to family life.

More women today are doing well in the business and the public sector. In fact, women hold 27 per cent of private sector senior managerial positions, which is an increase of just under 10 per cent since 1990. More women are going into small business. I saw some statistics recently that said that three times as many women go into small business these days. The greater involvement of women in business, particularly in small to medium type enterprises, is interesting to see. It is largely because they can combine family life and have the flexibility which perhaps would not have been available to them had they been working in a more rigid work environment. This government is committed to policies that help women achieve a balance between maintaining a positive work and family life.

Australian women have access to record levels of child care, including more flexible child care for families in shiftwork, particularly when children are ill. This government has been a very strong proponent of those sorts of policies and has provided much greater flexibility in the child-care sector and greater choice for Australian families. Those choices include the extension of in-home and sick care and also the entry of other operators, including private operators and family day care schemes and after school care.

The coalition government has also been encouraging the debate on paid maternity leave. Those on the other side would have us believe that a decision has already been made. It is important that we look at the pros and cons of this particular issue. We do not want nor should we encourage paid maternity leave to take women back to the dark days of restrictive work practices. That is something I would be totally against. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission issues paper `Valuing parenthood: options for paid maternity leave' made two interesting points. Firstly, the forward of the interim paper states:

quote.para: It should be emphasised that most of those consulted in the preparation of this paper were concerned that an individual employer funded scheme would prove disadvantageous to women in employment and to commercial competitiveness generally.

speech.para: Later in the report, it states:

quote.para: For those companies, in particular small businesses, with a high component of operating costs tied up in wages and operating on narrow profit margins, employer-provided paid maternity leave may disproportionately affect wage costs and in some cases be unaffordable. Organisations unable to afford paid maternity leave will be more likely to have women resign or not return to work following maternity leave. It may also make it more difficult for them to recruit women.

speech.para: Speakers opposite have indicated their preference for maternity leave. I think it is not just maternity leave that we need to consider, but flexibility in the workplace. I have said before on many occasions that, while it is good to give women 12 weeks maternity leave, it is no good if they have to go back to a workplace environment that is just as restrictive. There is a place for maternity leave to be balanced with more flexible work practices in the market. It is important that we look at all those factors when we consider balancing work and family life.

The maternity leave debate has been very emotional so far, and it will continue to be so. Providing a policy that will work for women and not against them is something that we need to look at. As I stated in my introduction, the coalition government has made some significant inroads towards improving workplace environments for women. Many years ago at one of my first job interviews, I was asked if, as a young woman, I was currently taking the pill. It was one of the most shocking moments of my employment history. Those were certainly the dark days when employees had to front up and speak to an employer who asked, as one of their first questions, whether a person was taking a contraceptive pill or whether the employee would get pregnant. It was a harrowing experience, and not just for meâa lot of women went through this. I was quite young at the time, and I recall being absolutely astonished that such a personal remark would be made.

I also remember going back to work when I had young children, and the problem then was: who was going to look after my baby? What child-care arrangements was I going to have made? It is a despondent time when you are trying to go back to work, and in those days there was incredible discrimination, particularly against women who had small children or women who were newly married or did not have children. It was a terrible period that I hope we will never see repeated. This legislation we have here today is commendable in ensuring that there is transparency in rules regarding questions that can be put to possible employees regarding pregnancy and potential pregnancy. I know that I am not alone in this experience; there are many women in Australia who have experienced this in the past. I am sure that many women in the past experienced much worse treatment than this.

Yesterday in the Courier Mail there was an article that said that in the past year nearly 50 Queensland women claimed that after they had become pregnant, employers or work colleagues had discriminated against them. The article, on page 10, also said that 59 women claimed that they had suffered from discrimination because of their marital status and another four had experienced discrimination because they were breastfeeding. It is absolutely amazing. One of the provisions of this legislation clarifies that a question regarding pregnancy or potential pregnancy should not be put unless it falls within the category of a general question that is asked of everyone. The Courier Mail article also gave some examples of sexual harassment in the workplace and I will quote one of them in particular:

quote.para: A WOMAN complained to her employer a colleague had sexually harassed her by making inappropriate comments and touching her shoulders. The company subsequently transferred her out of the section but left the alleged harasser in his position. She complained that her new position meant she was unable to claim overtime and requested to be transferred back. She was told this could not happen until she withdrew her complaint. The Anti-Discrimination Commissioner intervened, resolving the complaint and the woman was transferred back to her original job.

speech.para: That is an appalling example of the sort of discrimination that occurs out there in the workplace.

It is important that we look at the provisions in this legislation. We need to have caution here and also when we implement clarification. I would like to support the insertion of new subsection 27(1) to provide the necessary clarity. By that, it is important that it is not discrimination if an employer seeks a response on a question about a potential employee's future plans. I would regard this as pretty much a standard question in any job interview to assess the motivation and the future career aspirations of a candidate. I have been asked on many occasions, when I have undertaken an interview, what my future plans were in terms of career aspirations and motivational factors, so I think that that is fairly in order. If the interviewee willingly provides information on future family plans, then that is not discrimination. It becomes discrimination, however, if the employer directly makes reference to the pregnancy plans or uses that sort of information when determining who to give the job to. The message for employers and potential employees is to use caution when asking such questions.

I know that, from running my own small business, it was always in the back of my mind when I framed questions to potential employees. I was always very conscious of the fact that I did not create the wrong impression and that I did not cause some sort of indirect discrimination or discomfort to people that I was employing. I was always very conscious, during the interview stage, that I did not repeat the terrible mistakes that my earlier potential employer made when asking me about my future plans regarding starting a family. It is not discriminatory when an employer or a potential employer asks a question about a person's medical condition or pregnancy in a legitimate way. That is exactly the sort of clarification that we are needing in subsection 27(2).

It is really important that employers and employees do use discretion. I understand that many people want to maintain confidentiality, particularly in areas of medical and pregnancy issues, and that is their right. As Australians, we all have the need to respect this right. I would argue that, in fact, a good management practice is for the employer to act with sensitivity and discretion, particularly when discussing with individual employees their medical condition or their pregnancy, so that that can be safely handled in the workplace. I must say that I have also worked in very large and small corporations that have been very sensitive at the time that I wanted to start a family. In terms of re-rostering work, rescheduling, providing safety strategies or dealing with occupational health issues, I think it is very important that employers have that information so that they can assist employees and provide a suitable work environment. Everyone wins from that situation. It is a win-win situation for both the employees and the employers, and it does encourage women to return to the workplace. There are many companies in Queensland that have implemented strong family-friendly policies, and they are to be commended. It is also necessary for employers to ask about someone's medical or pregnancy status in a manner that distinguishes between the sexes, because it may also assist in the enforcement of appropriate precautionary measures.

This bill before us today makes sure that there is clarity to both employers and employees in the area of sex discrimination. The coalition has had an excellent report card in advancing women in the workplace and ensuring equality for all women. This bill that we are discussing here is another chapter in what is already a well-regarded volume. I would like to say that those past measures that we have implemented have been very good measures. The 2002 budget demonstrates the government's strong and continuing commitment to women in this special year, the Centenary of Australian Women's Suffrage. It has been 100 years since the Commonwealth Franchise Act 1902 came into effect, allowing most Australian women the right to vote and to stand for federal election.

The coalition government fosters a partnership approach to social policy, delivered in partnership with businesses, communities and individuals. The social coalition aims to develop opportunities for families and communities over and above those delivered by economic growth. We need to ensure that those opportunities continue in the workplace, particularly that women have safe and non-discriminatory workplaces that give them flexibility. The opportunities that I mentioned, particularly government support services, mean that women more than ever have those choicesâwhether they decide to be full-time parents or carers, whether they want to participate in the paid work force, or whether they wish to combine paid work with parenting or caring. I think that what is really important in this debate is that women have the opportunity to participate in whatever level of work arrangements they wish.

I supposed you could compare a working life to a product's life cycle. Women in the early stages of child rearing may want to work part time; as their children get older, they may then venture into the full-time work force; consequently, when their families have moved on, they may decide that they want to return to part-time work. We need to encourage that flexibility and ensure that we have non-discriminatory policies that will allow women to achieve their full potential. It is good to see that more and more women are going into managerial positions and that more businesses out there have family friendly workplace practices. I will comment on one particular business, Tamawood, which is a building company in Queensland that has provided exceptional working conditions for women, such as on-site child-care arrangements. They are to be commended. I commend the bill to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is a pleasure to follow the member for Petrie in speaking on the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002. I think I share most of her comments. Obviously, many of us have sought employment in different ways and experienced some odd reactions to seeking that employment, which means that we share an understanding of how important this debate is.

speech.para: The fact that we are moving some amendments and would like to see some of the other options that are put forward in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report adopted does not mean that we are not supportive of the steps that are being taken. I think there has been quite a change, even in the four years that I have been here, when I see how much more often we debate issues that affect working women in particular but also the balance between work and family, whether it is for men or women. Some of us would like some of these issues to move a bit faster.

I think that there is room for us to also try to have a debateâperhaps not always in this Houseâabout the way that all these different areas overlap and interact. We cannot really talk about discrimination in the workplace and not talk about the sorts of family payments that the member for Petrie was talking about. We cannot ignore child care or paid maternity leaveâall of these issues are ones that, increasingly, the public wants us to tie together. We need to look at how we can provide proper options for women who choose to work or go in and out of the work force at the same time as having and caring for young children. It is a pleasure to see that there is so much agreement about the range of issues that need to be covered.

I think a number of us on both sides of the House have been in circumstances where pretty terrible acts of discrimination have occurred. One of the things that surprises me most in the pregnancy discrimination area is just how absolutely unnecessary the reactions of employers often are. Mr Speaker, when you take the opportunity to read the reportâI do not know if you have had the opportunityâthat was prepared by the Human Rights Commission, Pregnant and productive, which was the basis for the legislation before us today, you will see it contains a lot of information. The most common theme of the report is how little information people had about their own rights and how unaware many women, particularly young women, were that they did not have to put up with the sort of treatment they received. The changes that the government has adopted are really to clarify what could have already been covered by the act. There were many challenges and many instances that the report found had been ignored because the act was not as clear as it could be.

We would have liked to have gone a step further and to have instigated or adopted some new heads of discrimination as were recommended in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report, such as prohibiting discrimination on the grounds of breastfeeding and others. These have been picked up in the terms of the debate. I think everybody understands that we are moving in the right direction. At some point, it may be necessary for us to look at a way to introduce that into the legislation. I guess that will be tested through the sorts of actions that employers take and, if necessary, through some test cases as well.

This bill has been listed a number of times without coming on for debate. Several months ago when the bill was listed, and I thought we were about to speak on it, I had been at a local nursing mothers' group. A couple of the mothers talked to me about their experiences in the workplace when they sought to return to work having, in most instances, been treated very well during their pregnancies. They were quite happy with their various maternity leave arrangements. A number of them had had paid maternity leave and certainly that was a hot topic for discussion and it has turned out to be a topic in the week that this has come before the House.

One woman's example really stuck in my mind. She worked as a relatively middle-ranking clerical officer. She had her own office in a building with many other employees. She worked quite long hours and was paid a salary. She did not have to be there at particular hours; she could make up time at either end of the day if she chose or if the employer wanted her to. She asked her employer if she would be able to get a lock for the door of her office so that, when she needed to express milk, she could ensure that no-one would walk in on her during that time. She ended up having an all-out brawl with her employer who thought that it was an outrageous request to have a lock on the door. There could be many awkward situations in trying to accommodate the needs of breastfeeding mothers. If we have a situation where it is very easy to accommodate those needs but we have employers arguing against it, we have a long way to go to educate the community. People might need to think more flexibly. This would not have started some dreadful trend in the business. It was suggested that everyone would suddenly have locks on the doors and you would not be able to go in and talk to the various staff. Obviously, that was not what was being proposed. These examples abound in the workplace and we all need to work towards to change.

In debating this bill, we need to make a fairly basic point: working women are still fighting for fairness in the workplace. Equality has not yet been achieved in all aspects. Getting the right balance between work and family is very difficult, particularly at the time of pregnancy. If it is a first pregnancy, it should be a time of great excitement for the family. A lot of change goes on in people's lives. More and more we see examples of that happy time being spoilt by very difficult negotiations or reactions in workplaces. This bill will help move that forward. It helps clarify what is appropriate and what is inappropriate. I hope employers will take note. We will be moving some amendments in the consideration in detail stage to take that a little further and to make clear what we believe employers should and should not be able to do in this situation.

I might briefly give an example, because I am probably sounding as though I am being very prescriptive about what employers should do. There are guidelines suggested either in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report or in other bookletsâand I notice one has recently been produced by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations about pregnancy in the workplace and the sorts of discussions that should be had between employer and employee. Mostly they are pretty straightforward, sensible proposals, but it seems that we need to work a little more on the education side of things so that employees are confident they can raise these issues and employers are capable and confident of having the discussions as well.

I am keeping an eye out for a hopeful intervention of some news from the other place, but it seems that that is not going to happen quite yet. So I will read briefly from a booklet called Balancing Breastfeeding and Work, which is prepared jointly by the Department of Health and Aged Care at the Commonwealth level, the University of Adelaide and the South Australian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry. As well as explaining a whole lot of circumstances that might be of assistance to both women in the work force and employers, there is a section which sets out some guidelines to employers and workplaces and what they can do to support breastfeeding. Some of the things are very practical: making sure there is access somewhere in the workplace to a clean and private room, that there is some storage area, that there is a chair for the woman to use if they need to sit down while expressing or breastfeeding, washing facilities, and even things as basic as having access to a power point to be able to use an electric breast pump.

It seems to me that all of this moves the debate forward a little bit about whether or not this is something that is practical in a workplaceâin many it will not be. The changes that are being proposed and being introduced into the legislation do not seek to put an unreasonable burden on employers. Obviously each workplace is different, and sensible negotiations need to be had. But we need to be able to encourage women that they can have a proper balance and that they can make choices about how they want to continue to care for their children. This is a very important change, particularly in circumstances where they may need to return to work in a short time.

As I said, it is quite an interesting week for us to be discussing this bill because the Sex Discrimination Commissioner has released her next big report. This one from several years ago was a very important report at its time. Unfortunately, it has taken this length of time to now turn into legislation. The Labor Party, in supporting paid maternity leave, would be very keen to see that the current report that has been tabled this week will not be acted upon so slowly by the government. But, given comments made by other speakers already and what is well known on the public record, there seems to be no agreement at all on the government side about whether or not they even support paid maternity leave as an idea. So there is a lot of debate we still have to have in that area. I hope that we will be able to move forward because it is a vast jigsaw puzzle and it seems to me we are only putting a few pieces together pretty slowly. We need to eventually get them to all fit together so that families do have the options that we all want them to be able to have.

I hope that the government will take those recommendations and that report seriously. The full detail of the human rights commission's Pregnant and productive report from 1999 has not been adopted by this legislation that is before us. There is a lot more that should be looked at and should be done. The clarification of what falls within or constitutes sex discrimination is certainly going to be useful; it will help both employers and employees to know what their rights are, but it does not quite take up the recommendations and the points made by the commissioner's report. People need to be clear what their rights are, and employers need to be encouraged to make sure they can introduce those sorts of standards within the workplace and that that would make a significant difference to preparedness to stay at work.

I commend the bill to the House. I flag my support, of course, for the amendment moved by the member for Barton and that I seconded. We do need to make sure that we are actually going to balance this sort of legislation with a proper paid maternity leave package with accessible child care and with a whole range of other family-friendly provisions which need to be put in place in the workplace relations system. I trust that we will be able to debate all of those issues in the coming year.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I seek your indulgence. I again apologise to members who are being detained far beyond any reasonable time span and, indeed, to all the parliamentary staff and others who are still here. After being on the job for almost 24 hours, I hate to think what occupational health and safety provisions we might be at risk of infringing. The latest advice I have is that the paperwork necessary to deal with the Senate's message on the ASIO bill is between 10 and 25 minutes away. I am told that we should be able to deal with it in this place reasonably quickly and get it back up to the Senate to be looked at again. I am told that should be a reasonably expeditious process. So there is still some hope that we might get out by about 8.30 a.m. but I would not want people to bank on it. That is the latest information that I have.

debateinfo.title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT (PREGNANCY AND WORK) BILL 2002

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to rise to speak on the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002. In particular, I am delighted to follow my colleague the member for Gellibrand whom I have known for many years and who I know has had a longstanding commitment and interest in this area. I am also delighted that my friend and colleague the member for Berowra is in the chamber specifically to hear this discussion take place.

speech.para: This debate occurs at the end of an interesting century, a century of movement and change, and evolution in the rights of women. It occurs at the end of a century which has seen the evolution of those rights across political, economic and social fronts. This bill represents an additional step along that path towards true and genuine equality. One hundred years ago, the Commonwealth Franchise Act 1902 came into effect. It allowed most Australian women the right to vote and to stand for federal election. Over time, through the success of Dame Enid Lyons and others, women have developed a political voice in the country. Similarly, they have developed a social voice through a range of authors, contributors, activistsâ many people on different frontsâand, significantly and perhaps of most importance, they have developed an independent economic freedom. One of the key reasons why we have seen a significant and continuing increase in the participation rate of women in this country over a period of decades is their increasing involvement in the workplace. That is where this bill fits in.

That process of evolution and of ever greater involvement of women in the workplace has meant a number of things. One, it has meant an increase in their participation; two, it has meant a gradual equalisation of the pay scalesâthere is more to be done, but there has been significant and quite dramatic progress over the course of the last century; and threeâand this is specifically where this bill fallsâit addresses some of the rights, conditions and terms of women within the workplace.

I wish to address three particular things in relation to the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002. First, the background; second, the provisions of the bill; and third, its importance within the context of today. Looking at the background, in 1998 the Attorney-General requested the first investigation into matters relating to pregnancy and work. The report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, entitled Pregnant and Productive: it is a right not a privilege to work while pregnant, which subsequently flowed, recommended the need for clarification in relation to three matters in particular. They were, firstly, the asking of questions about pregnancy or potential pregnancy; secondly, the use of pregnancy related medical information; and, thirdly, whether breastfeeding constituted legitimate grounds for discrimination or whether discrimination on the grounds of breastfeeding was improper, inappropriate and unfair. That represents the background.

The provisions of this bill amend the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 in accordance with recommendations 36, 37 and 43 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report. The bill was prepared in consultation with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and groups that represent employees whether at the organised level or at the social level.

Significantly, the amendments clarify three things. Firstly, questions regarding pregnancy or potential pregnancy may not be asked during the recruitment process. Secondly, medical information collected from pregnant women may only be used for legitimate health and safety reasons. In effect, that means that medical information gathered for one purposeâsuch as for determining and protecting the health of a woman or a mother or a potential motherâcannot be used in the workplace for work related purposes. Thirdly, the bill clarifies that discrimination against women on the basis of breastfeeding is illegal. It is an important social step forward. What it says is that, as a matter of law, a woman has a right to breastfeed within the workplace.

What is at the third level? The importance of the bill. The bill has no financial impact, but it does ensure that the original act is clear. In very simple terms, it is illegal to discriminate against women on the basis of pregnancy, potential pregnancy or because they are breastfeeding. In order to implement this, the government will compile a pamphlet on pregnancy and work in order to increase awareness of this issue amongst employers and employees. Indeed, this bill is just one part of a broader social framework that shows a commitment in relation to the status of women.

The government's achievements and initiatives include, firstly, workplace equality. Since 1996 there has been a 14 per cent increase in the number of women in employment. That is an extraordinary advance in terms of the proportion of women in employment in a six-year period. Secondly, 52 per cent of the over one million jobs created since 1996âit has increased from 971,800 jobsâwhen I first prepared these notes, have been filled by women. Thirdly, the Workplace Relations Act includes a provision for equal remuneration for men and women when they have undertaken work of equal valueâa simple, clear, absolute and fundamental principle. That is the question about workplace equality.

The second principal area of achievement is in balancing family and workâand this is a process which is in evolution. Significantly, the government introduced a $24.2 million return to work program that assists people re-entering the work force after a two-year or more break as carers or parents. In addition, under the category of balancing family and work, the government has committed $8 billion to child care in the four years up to 2004-05, counting the full range of child support and child-care benefits.

Very briefly, there are more challenges. This bill is a step along the path which has progressed over 100 years and which has gradually led not to a perfect situation but to a significant improvement in the economic, political and social fields. In particular, the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002 addresses the economic capacity of women by ensuring that they are protected when carrying out those duties associated with the normal practice of their lives, which comes from facing motherhood in and during their working lives. It is an important step and I am delighted to commend this legislation to the House.

talk.start.para: âGood morning, Mr Speaker. The Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002 is probably the best example of a Clayton's amendment that this House has ever seen. It is the amendment you have when you are not having an amendment. The bill is the government's response to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission report Pregnant and productive: it is a right not a privilege to work while pregnant. The report was commissioned by the Attorney-General in August 1998 and the report was required nine months later, in June 1999. As it was, the report was overdue and was finally delivered in August 1999. After a pregnant pause of nearly three years, mother and baby are not doing well.

speech.para: The report made a total of 46 recommendations, and 11 of those called on the Attorney-General to amend the Sex Discrimination Act in various ways. Out of the 11 recommendations only three are covered by this bill, and those three changes are largely cosmetic. They are only intended to make the act clearer to employers and employees. You might say that they are like the cream to hide the stretch marks, rather than dealing with the health and wellbeing of mother and baby. I should add that the three areas addressed in this bill are ones where there is a great deal of misunderstanding. Any attempt to clarify these issues is welcome. But the remaining eight recommendations that the Attorney-General has chosen to ignore cover issues which actually extend the rights of pregnant women and adoptive parents. I will come back to those issues later.

Firstly, looking at the recommendations addressed by this bill, I should begin by saying that many cases of discrimination arise out of well-intentioned acts of employers and service providers. They may have acted in what they thought would be in the best interests of the motherâand that in itself would appear to be the cause of many examples of misunderstanding of the act. Making provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act crystal clear to employers and service providers is a welcome and much needed measure.

In the report of the national pregnancy and work inquiry, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission exposed some alarming figures for employer awareness of equity and discrimination issues. It found in a survey of private sector employers in the Perth area that, while 81.2 per cent of employers of large businesses knew that discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy was unlawful, only 62 per cent of small business employers were aware of that; and in the retail sectorâthe largest employer of womenâonly 59.4 per cent of employers were aware. It is quite alarming to think that at the time that survey was conducted in 1998 only three out of five employers were aware that discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy is unlawful. Some 14 years after the Sex Discrimination Act was passed, only three out of five employers were aware of their responsibilities under the act. And the report also indicates that while those three out of five were aware of the overall requirements, there was considerable misunderstanding of how they should be applied.

The report suggests a total of 41 guidelines in plain English and with case studies in order to allow better understanding of the act as it applies to pregnancy. You should not have to be a lawyer to have a basic understanding of how to avoid discriminatory practices in your workplace, but I do not want to suggest that, if it is all too hard, then let us do away with it altogetherâlet us not throw the baby out with the bath water. Rather, it is better to clarify the act to ensure that it is more likely to be complied with. An understanding on the part of employees is essential if they are to exercise their rights.

Looking at the changes proposed in this bill, item 1 in schedule 1 of the bill changes the definition of sex discrimination to include breastfeeding and the act of expressing milk. This change is in response to recommendation 43 of the report, which calls on the Attorney-General to make sure that breastfeeding is a ground of unlawful discrimination. I would have thought that this was covered in the original act, but now it is clearly stated and leaves no doubt that matters relating to breastfeeding are included as unlawful discrimination. This is an important provision of the act and an issue which over time has seen community attitudes evolve from recognition to acceptance. The development of practices and facilities to allow nursing mothers to enjoy the full range of employment and social activities is a welcome change. The days when nursing mothers were sent off to the ladies toilet to feed an infant are thankfully rare now. But that does not apply everywhere. I have always thought it strange that people who thought you should feed a baby in a toilet would never consider eating their lunch in one. I realise that there is much more to the issue of discrimination when it comes to breastfeeding and that smaller employers and service providers face challenges when meeting their responsibilities in this area. But with the benefit of a clearer understanding of their responsibilities, I believe that a commonsense approach can satisfy all parties.
The second area covered in this bill again seeks to provide a clearer statement of the requirements of the act. Recommendation 36 of the report of the National Pregnancy and Work Inquiry recommends:

motion.para: That the Attorney-General clarify section 27 of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (Cth) by the insertion of a specific provision that prohibits the asking of questions (whether orally or in writing) which might reasonably be understood as intended to elicit information about whether or when a women intends to become pregnant and/or her intentions in relation to meeting her current or pending family responsibilities.

speech.para: The explanatory memorandum to the bill points out that this is most commonly applicable in employment recruitment situations. However, it is not limited to employment. The examples given in the explanatory memorandum describe situations of applying to lease rental property and an applicant for a bank loan. With the changes, it should be crystal clear that anyone responsible for recruitment, letting property or handling loan applicationsâand I would think many other similar transactionsâis prohibited from asking questions that may be used to discriminate against a person on the basis of their sex, pregnancy or potential pregnancy or marital status. There are no ifs or buts; asking the question breaches the act. It is not a matter of saying, `I wasn't going to use the information.' Why would you ask in the first place if you were not going to use the information?

I hope that this amending legislation makes it crystal clearâand, short of drawing a picture, it could hardly be made clearerâthat this part of the Sex Discrimination Act needs to be widely understood and enforced. But, before I go on to the third change, it is worth going back to the figures I mentioned earlier in relation to the awareness of the requirements of the Sex Discrimination Act. When two out of five employers do not even have a basic understanding of the act and for those who have a basic understanding it is necessary to clarify many issues, you have to ask whether greater effort needs to be put into getting across to businesses their responsibilities under the act. Clarifying parts of the act is one thing, but getting the message through to all parties is even more important.

The third change is to subsection 27(2) of the act. There is in the act an exception to the prohibition on requesting information that allows the provision of medical information concerning pregnancy. This is included for occupational health and safety reasons. I have noted that under the recommended guidelines No. 26 in the report states:

quote.para: ... while it is appropriate to ask a pregnant job applicant to undergo a medical examination, any such medical examination should be undertaken with a view to addressing occupational health and safety concerns and should not in itself lead to, or exacerbate, discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy.

speech.para: It occurred to me that perhaps an additional guideline might be to restrict access to the results of medical testing where the result has no bearing on any occupational health and safety issue that may otherwise influence the employment decision. This would ensure that the employer did not discriminate against the applicant, as the decision to inform the employer of the condition would be made by the medical practitioner on the basis of occupational health and safety concerns. I would also point out that in the explanatory memorandum, in paragraph 4 of page 4, the example refers to a pregnant employer, which I take it should be a pregnant employee.

So much for what is in the bill. As I said earlier, out of 46 recommendations of the report, only three are acted upon by way of this amendment and they are Clayton's changes: they do not change the act, they only clarify sections of it. Referring only to the 11 recommendations which are the responsibility of the Attorney-General, where is the amendment to empower the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to publish enforceable standards in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy as stated in recommendation 1? Where is the amendment to extend the coverage of the act to federal statutory employees, judicial office holders and members of parliament? Where is the amendment to ensure coverage of unpaid workers? Where is the amendment to remove the exemption of employment by an instrumentality of a state? Where is the amendment to remove the exemption contained in section 38 for educational institutions established for religious purposes in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy? I am happy to see the Attorney-General in the chamber now. I ask the Attorney-General: where is the amendment to the provisions in relation to the award of compensatory damages to enable the award of punitive damages?

All of these recommended amendments referring to the Attorney-General are still in limbo, sitting in the too-hard basket, waiting for another year or another Attorney-General. While we are dealing with a bill whose purpose is to clarify rather than change the act, why is it that recommendation 35 was not taken on board? In that recommendation, the report of the inquiry asked:

motion.para: That Attorney-General amend the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 ... to make clear that a complaint about a discriminatory advertisement may be made under section 14(1)(a) of the Act notwithstanding that the complainant is not a person directly affected by the advertisement.

speech.para: While we are in the process of making amendments to clarify the act, why was that left out? This is a Clayton's amendmentâit is the amendment you have when you are not having an amendment. When you need to be seen to be doing something, this is the very least you can do. Out of 46 recommendations of the report of the National Pregnancy and Work Inquiry, the Attorney-General takes action on only three. By contrast, Labor is moving amendments to this bill which will address 10 of the recommendations which fall within the responsibility of the Attorney-General. That seems to indicate that the Attorney-General has absolutely no idea of the extent of the problem of discrimination against pregnant and potentially pregnant women.

As a crude measure of the issue we should note that in 1998 there were 249,000 live births in Australia. In that year, there were 3.73 million women in the work force. When you compare these figures with those of five years earlier in 1993, a clear picture emerges of the relationship between pregnancy and work. In 1993 there were 260,000 live birthsâthat is 11,000 more than in 1998âbut there were 3.26 million women in the work forceâthat is half a million less than in 1998. Today women make up more than 44 per cent of the work force. The images of the male as the breadwinner and the female as the homemaker have long since passed their use-by date. The average age at which a woman has her first child has increased from 26.3 years in 1985 to 28.6 years in 1995. Clearly something is happening to fertility rates and to the make-up of the work force and the two are related. The report of the National Pregnancy and Work inquiry quotes the Australian demographer Professor McDonald as saying:

quote.para: ... if women are provided with opportunities near to equivalent to those of men in education and market employment, but these opportunities are severely curtailed by having children, then, on average, women will restrict the number of children that they have to an extent which leaves fertility at a precariously low long-term level.

speech.para: The report concluded that:

quote.para: The low fertility rate indicates a growing trend by women actually making a choice between work and family rather than seeking both.

speech.para: The report also quoted from a comparison of male and female managers, finding that in high technology companies two-thirds of female managers did not have children while two-thirds of male managers did. While I have drawn on this example, it is worth noting that workers in manufacturing, retail and personal services can expect the least family-friendly working conditions. All this paints a dismal background for pregnant and potentially pregnant women in the workplace. Women are showing their concern by choosing work ahead of family in increasing numbers.

I would have thought that one important thing that could be done would be to assist women to choose both family and work. One of the more obvious steps would be to address the widespread discrimination against pregnant women. For many women the answer to discrimination is: don't get pregnant. That is their choice, but it need not be. It is not by accident that Scandinavian countries have higher fertility rates than other developed nations. It takes more than the baby bonuses paid to parents who stay at homeâit takes a change of attitude in the workplace. When women are protected from discrimination they are free to choose both family and work. It will take the enforcement of standards of conduct and the education of employers and employees as well as service providers to end discrimination. This bill goes just a very short part of the way towards achieving that. Only with the adoption of the remaining recommendations of the report of the National Pregnancy and Work inquiry will we come close to achieving fairness for pregnant and potentially pregnant women. Only then can we expect the issue of declining birth rates to be addressed. Only when women can confidently plan for both a family and a career will we have reached the level of equality that women for such a long time have fought so hard to achieve.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Moylan) adjourned.

Again, I am sorry about this, but when you have got two houses of parliament these are the indignities that you experience in the cause of democracy.

subdebate.1.para: Mr WILLIAMS (TangneyâAttorney-General) (6.56 a.m.)âI move:
