talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the amendments Nos 1, 5 and 7 insisted on by the Senate be agreed to.

speech.para: There have been some pretty extraordinary claims made by the opposition in this place about the government's position on this bill. Over the course of this year, while the government has been focusing on getting the bill passed, the opposition has shifted and changed its position and engaged in an exercise of rewriting history which has been second to none. In contrast to that of the opposition, the government's position on this bill has always been clear and consistent. We introduced this legislation because we believe and have always firmly believed that we need this legislation to give our intelligence agencies vital tools to deter and prevent terrorism. We have not wavered from this position and we continue to stand by it.

By contrast, the opposition has had as many different positions on the bill as there are days of the week. First they would not support the powers in the bill, despite the extensive amendments made by the government at the behest of the parliamentary joint committee, which included senior members from their own ranks. Then they sought to defer the debate on the bill to avoid taking a position, because there were significant divisions within their ranks. But, worse still, they then decided the power should be given to the police, despite the fact that the bill has nothing to do with law enforcement and everything to do with collecting intelligence. Then, sensing no doubt that the public had little time for their attempts to frustrate essential functions of the bill, they conceded that these powers should go to ASIO.

But what they propose to give ASIO is powers in a form that we say make them completely unworkable. Not only did all this toing-and-froing put the community at risk by delaying the passage of the bill but the opposition continued to seek to turn the bill into something that would not deliver the protection it was designed to achieve. I am patient, but even I reach a point at which I have to say enough is enough. For me, that point is where the bill no longer does what we have undertaken to the public that it will do, where it can no longer deliver on the promise of clearer powers to our intelligence services to gather intelligence to stop terrorist acts in circumstances where there is no acceptable alternative and where community safety is at risk.

The members opposite have preached long and hard about the things that the Labor Party will not wear. Apparently, they will not wear a system that would permit intelligence agencies to hold and question a person believed to have information about potential terrorist acts. They will not wear such intelligence gathering under a warrant issued by the Attorney-General, who is accountable to the people and the parliament and whose actions may be challenged in the courts. They will not wear a system where that warrant is approved by a federal judge or a retired judge and where the person is questioned in the presence of a senior member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or a retired judge. They will not wear a system where the person questioned has the right to a security-cleared lawyer, paid for by the Commonwealth. They will not wear a system where the person can complain to the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, who can sit in on the questioning. And more extraordinary still, they will not wear a coercive questioning regime with detention in the strictly controlled circumstances that we propose. Yet the parliamentary joint committee had no problems with that and the member for Brand, Mr Beazley, and Senator Ray appeared to accept our position. They quite eloquently made out the case for the government's regime last night and this morning.

Let us not forget another level of inconsistency: the Labor Party's New South Wales counterparts have given the New South Wales Police the power to strip-search children between the age of 10 and 18 without a warrant where there is the threat of a terrorist act. The New South Wales Police will be able to search a person's premises and vehicles without a warrantâI repeat, no warrant. There is also no judicial oversight as exists in the government's legislation, just the authorisation of the police minister. Federal Labor has been willing to wear this without a murmur. The government can wear the bill but not the opposition's amendments.

The opposition's amendments go to matters of fundamental principle that we cannot accept. The government will not pretend to the community that what has come out of the Senate will provide the kind of protection against terrorism that we know we need. We will not do that when we know the opposition's package of amendments effectively renders it useless in the emergency situations it is designed to address and open to challenge. The opposition has exposed itself as being hopelessly divided on this bill. The government has demonstrated time and time again our commitment to community safety, but we will not accept amendments that fundamentally change the nature of the bill. However, the government wants this vital legislation passed before Christmas. In the interests of getting the legislation through and giving the community the benefit of this protection now, we are prepared to accept two of the opposition's amendments. We do not do so lightly. The opposition has made much of the need for the inclusion of state judges as prescribed authorities. Legal advice on this point differs. However, on the basis that the opposition's advice maintains that, in the event the provision with regard to state judges is found to be unconstitutional, it would be excisable and thus would not render the entire bill unconstitutional, we are prepared to accept that provision. (Extension of time granted)

In addition, while we are firmly of the belief that the security environment we are living in is unlikely to change in the foreseeable future and that these powers will be needed for some time to come, we are prepared to accept the opposition's sunset clause on the bill. This will enable this parliament to give the community the protection it needs in the current heightened security environment, secure in the knowledge that these extraordinary powers will necessarily be revisited by the parliament in three years. These are concessions which we are prepared to make because we are committed to getting this legislation passed. We have demonstrated that commitment since the legislation was introduced. We have never wavered from that commitment. Now is the opportunity for the opposition to display a commitment to the security of the Australian people, to accept the government's offer and to support the bill.

talk.start.para: âIt was appropriate that the last time the Attorney spoke in the House on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 the lights went off, we went into darkness and the House had to adjourn for a short while. And I think it is indicative of the attitude in terms of some of the discussions that have taken place between this side and the governmentâthey seem not to get what we are saying; they seem to still be in the dark. It is good to see that, as the new light is dawning on this day, the government has moved some way, but they have to move a lot more. But talk about rewriting history: last night, the opposition, through the Leader of the Opposition, tabled legal advice from Dr Gavan Griffith QC, the former Solicitor-General, which showed that the amendments we proposed in relation to prescribed authority were constitutional. The government was running around saying, `We can't accept this amendment on a prescribed authority because of the danger of the constitutional problems.'

speech.para: We are still waiting to see the advice of Mr Orr. We saw a letter that was sent to Senator Faulkner, after Senator Faulkner contacted the Attorney's office and not at the time it was said to have been received, and the Attorney has a letter from Senator Faulkner, whose advice, and he said so in the Senate, was that that correspondence only arrived at approximately 1 p.m. after a phone call was made. There might have been some miscommunication, but, notwithstanding that, a letter went to the Attorney which said, `Show us the advice.' We still have not seen Mr Orr's advice, but at least the government has done the right thing and capitulated. Why has it capitulated? Because we have tabled the advice of Mr Gavan Griffith QC, and it is impeccable advice.

All the way through, with the terrorism bills and these bills, the opposition have acted responsibly. We have sought proper advice. We have a sound basis and sound principles for what we are putting to the government. What we are putting to the government, if it is accepted, will see cross-party support for these bills, as there should be. So do not talk about rewriting history. In relation to the sunset clause, the position was made very clear by the Joint Standing Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD, which unanimously recommended a sunset clause, and the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. So the government has bowed to the inevitable on that. I will talk about the other amendments when we deal with them shortly.

The government continues to go on with this nonsense. It is the government that is jeopardising the national interest. We say on this side that a workable bill has come out of the Senate. The government has come some way, but it has to keep walking. There is a long way for it to go yet before this side of the House will support an amended bill. It is absurd to suggest that the government has not known our position from day one. I have been involved in confidential discussions, and for the Attorney to say that there has been a shift in position is disingenuous. We have shown that the Senate process and the joint committee process have worked. We have involved lawyers and we have kept an open mind on this.

What we have sought to doâand so has the government, in some instances, but only in a minor wayâis to put submissions and, in the light of evidence from experts that came before the Senate committee, to move forward in our position in relation to a number of things, and the government has picked them up. I note that, in the Senate, the government has picked up a number of amendments arising out of the Senate. You cannot say that is technical and a bit of a maze, as the Attorney seeks to do in some of his press conferences and speeches, and that we are being nit-picking and pedantic. If that is the case, Michelle Grattan fingered you; you should be accepting all of the amendments. But in relation to detention as against a questioning regime, that is fundamental. I will deal with that in the next round of amendments.

We welcome the government's capitulation on these two matters. The reason we expanded the prescribed authority was that the government said it did not have enough retired judges. We were not going to have a situation where, in relation to that, the government could say that there were not enough people to serve on the prescribed authority. So we welcome the government caving in on these amendmentsâso it should. We would welcome that in relation to the other amendments, because it will give you a workable bill that has broad support across the parliament. You know it. (Extension of time granted) In relation to this set of amendments, we have great pleasure in supporting this position. It has been our position for some time, and the Attorney knows that.

The Attorney knows that there is no division on this side of the House in relation to the sunset clause or the prescribed authority. If anything, he should have a look at the Senate committee and joint committee reports. Members of the government, judging on the merits and not bound by their caucus room, voted for the sensible proposals in the report. So do not come in here and talk about rewriting history. I know who is rewriting history. It was not six hours ago that you were standing up and saying that, in relation to these aspects, they were non-negotiable, you were not going to move on themâthat the sky would fall in if you gave in on a sunset clause and there would be constitutional problems in relation to the prescribed authority. We nailed that pretty quickly. The other arguments are straw man arguments. I will deal with them in the near future.

talk.start.para: âI indicated last night when I was speaking on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 that the Labor Party support tough legislation to counter terrorism in this country. We have always supported that and we have said so from the beginning. We have been prepared to enter the debate, consider the advice and make judgments based around itâand that is what the bill, which is continuing to come back from the Senate, is doing. I cannot understand why the government are not prepared to adopt all the amendments. There has been an indication this morning that the government are prepared to move on two amendmentsâone after we tabled advice from the former Solicitor-General, which the government now accepts. We still have not seen the government's advice as to why they were arguing unconstitutionality before. Now we have them tapping the mat on unconstitutionality.

speech.para: Why do the government keep going to the brink but then only want to play politics? They do not want a solution; they just want to play politics. Also, we have now got them acknowledging that they will accept a sunset clause. What has taken them so long? If they are prepared to accept that this should be a bill that we trial, if you like, for the next three years, why do they not support the other amendments? It is because the other amendments go to fundamental principles. The first is that people who are being detained for questioning have access to lawyers. What is wrong with society having access to lawyers from a panel of lawyers that was recommended by a Senate committee, which members of the government agreed with? The Attorney-General is ignoring the advice coming from members of his own party, let alone the Labor Party. Why should people not be allowed to have access to lawyers if they are being detained? We accept that they should not be able to play around with the system and use it to delay. That principle has been attempted to be accommodated. It is a fundamental principle that they should have access to lawyers. Why will this government not accept that?

The second issue goes to the age at which people can be detained. Why should people aged 14 years be involved in this bill? As the member for Brand indicated, if it is a suicide bomber aged 17, you do not need this legislation; you use other legislation. Under this legislation we are talking about circumstances in which people can be taken in for questioning at the age of 14 and detained for up to seven daysâand for 48 hours they do not have access to a lawyer. How could anyone in those circumstances accept that this government is serious about dealing with principle as distinct from playing politics?

Then we have the questioning regime which they insist should enable them to question for up to seven days. Under the amendments that we have put forward, there is the ability to question for up to 20 hours. That does not mean less than a day; it means 20 hours of questioningâeight hours more than is currently provided for under the Crimes Act. We recognise that the special circumstances of this case go beyond the provisions that pertain under the Crimes Act, but that is not good enough for the government. Do not tell me that the authorities, the questioning agency and intelligence-gathering agency, ASIO, cannot get an understanding after 20 hours of questioning.

We are saying that the government has the capacity to get the bill through today. That is the challenge to the Attorney-General. Instead of coming into this place and trying to explain away his guilt in thisâhe could not even explain it at a press conference yesterday afternoonâwe say to the Attorney-General, `Change your mind and accept the amendments now' and we can have the bill through today.

That is the opportunity that faces you, Attorney. We can have this bill through before Christmasâa bill which is not just advanced by the Labor Party but supported by members of your own party. One can only assume that, if you reject this opportunity, you want to play politics with it. (Extension of time granted) We can only assume that, if the Attorney persists with the stance he is taking now, he is playing politics with it. He is denying the opportunity for his government to give strength and power to ASIO to deal with the threat of terrorism in this country. This is a unique opportunity, as I indicated before. These are powers that do not exist in other democratic countries in the world. These are significantly enhanced powers for ASIO, which we accept in the context of the war on terror. But we are not going to compromise on the fundamental principles, and we are not going to ignore the advice that was determined by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on all the evidence that came before it.

Attorney, why is it that you think you are the one who is right on this when you have been proven wrong on the unconstitutionality? The fact of the matter is that you do not have the courage to stand up to people in your own party who want to play politics with this. The people who consider the issues understand why these amendments are important. We urge you again, given that you have made the concessions on two of the points we have been arguing at length for some time, to go the extra step. Concede the extra three points, because you will have a bill before Christmasâa bill that strengthens the hand of ASIO; a bill that looks after the interests of the Australian citizens but that does not put some in jeopardy. Your legislation does. It takes away their rights. It is not fair in these circumstances.

If you think the Australian public is going to accept a position in which you deny people the right to lawyers and in which you say you need to be able to detain them for up to seven days, it will not wear it. The Australian public does want tough new powers, but it also wants the rights of its citizens protected. That is where you have to get the balance right, and the bill that has come back from the Senate gets the balance right. You want to distort the balance, and you are not doing your role or the country any service. I urge you to consider again these amendments in the interests of better powers and the protection of our citizens. Have the capacity and the decency to get the balance right rather than just play grubby politics with this bill.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the House insists on disagreeing to amendments Nos 2, 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 16 to 28, 30, 32 to 37, 40 to 47, 51 and 54 to 56 insisted on by the Senate.

speech.para: If I were to speak in support of this motion, I would simply be repeating what I have previously said. I will not detain the House on that account.

talk.start.para: âI can understand why the Attorney did not want to speak for long; he would be repeating what he said earlier. What he said earlier was defending the indefensible. That is the truth of it, and that is why he could not get up this time and speak for another five minutes. The government's opposition to what are reasonable amendments to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 is indefensible. If the government accept the Senate amendments, we will have legislation that ASIO can work with. What will it give them? It will give them additional powers. What have the opposition said they will do in return for bringing in a questioning regime? We have said, `Let's introduce penalties in terms of secrecy provisions.' The main thrust of the government's proposal is: we want to question for intelligence gathering. That is what they are saying. But, when you question the government further, they do not want to release people on the suspicion that they might talk to someone.

speech.para: We have come up with secrecy provisions that say, `If people leave the prescribed authority and disclose, they are liable to penalty.' That makes them no longer nonsuspects; that makes them accused who can be prosecuted, brought back in and kept in custody. We are told by the Attorney-General that he has problems with the drafting of these provisions. We have drafted them, but he says that he is not happy with them. There are number of precedents that this government can look at. The Australian Crime Commissionâthe former National Crime Authorityâand ICAC have the same provisions. That is our trade-off in relation to a questioning of the detention regime.

This is a fundamental matter of principle. As I said earlier, this is not Pinochet's Chile; this is Australia 2002. We do not pinch our citizens off the street, keep them incommunicado with no lawyers, and try to crush them by keeping them incommunicado for seven daysâthat is what you want to do. This is more than an intelligence-gathering exercise. The government say one thing but the reality is another. They want to treat people who are not accused of offencesânonsuspectsâworse than people accused of the most heinous of crimes. Under the Crimes Act, you can only keep suspects for 12 hoursâfour hours and then a further eight hours. You have to charge them or release them. Under our amendments, you can keep them for four hours plus another eight plus another eightâthat is 20 hours of pure questioning, which is more than adequate.

These powers are not available in America, the subject of a heinous terrorist attack, because their constitution prohibits it. The UK has had a bit of experience with terrorism, but these powers are not available in the UK for nonsuspects. Yet this government insists on these powers of detention for seven days. We say, `Yes, bring them in for questioning.' Neither I nor the Labor Party have any objection to people being brought in for questioning with lawyers. Our statute books have plenty of examples of that: if you are subpoenaed, you are required to attend. We also say, `If you attend under this legislation and tell lies, you are subject to five years imprisonment.'

It is absolutely indefensible for this government to maintain its opposition to what are reasonable amendments. Our track record on this is spot-on. We negotiated the terrorism bills that were first introduced into this parliament by this Attorney and this government, and we got them to a state where they were consistent with the values and the principles that we seek to defend from terrorists. You do not surrender to terrorists by, in effect, throwing out the values that we are defendingâthe presumption of innocence, the rule of law and access to a lawyer. This is not a dictatorship; this is not a fascist regime that we are defending. (Extension of time granted) The Labor Party will not support a police state, which is what this government basically want in persisting with their amendments. Judge them not on their rhetoric but on the quality of their legislation. The Intelligence Services Bill went through a committee prior to September 11, giving ASIO and the other authorities broad powers in intelligence gathering.

In relation to the incident in Bali, what happened to the terrorism bills? Proscription occurred through the UN. Those laws worked. More importantly, what the terrorists saw was a united response from our parliament. What the Labor Party are offering this government is a united response to an amended bill from the Senate. But we will not offer to surrender liberties that people went to war and died for. When my parents came to this country, they came under the Aliens Act. They were photographed, their addresses were taken and they were not allowed to move around this country, not because they were guilty of anything but because of the suspicion that people were non-white where they came from. Haven't we learnt from the mistakes of the past not to judge people on the basis of race or religion? We want to go after terrorists, not innocent citizens. What worries me is that the government says in relation to this: `We want intelligence-gathering powers, not punitive powers.' We are offering that through the amendments and the amended bill from the Senate. We are offering additional powers.

This Attorney says the bill does not go far enough. Attorney, there is an old saying: a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush. In this instance, the parliament is about to rise. The Labor Party will not retreat or surrender on fundamental principles in relation to this bill. We are united; we have shown that. You are defending the indefensible. It is in the national interest that you go the rest of the way with these Senate amendments, because they are offering additional powers. But what you want are repressive powers. They are not in the national interest. It is my view that you will not be able to sustain this in the public domain. Why? Because it is unreasonable. On the basic test, it is unreasonable.

I urge the government, even though it is late in the dayâit is early in the morning, but late in the day in terms of the debate on this billâto consider and reconsider what I think is a crazy position on their behalf. As has been said, and, I anticipate, will be said again in this debate, these are additional powers. The Labor Party have come a long way. I will not have it said that we have shifted and changed. We have maintained a principled position. We have sought to accommodate the reasonable requests of the government. We have listened to the experts that have come before the parliamentary committee. If you look at what we have done, you will see that we have been willing to move, because we do not want to take purely technical points. We are not taking technical points; they are fundamental. We say: after 20 hours of investigation, let them go or charge them. I commend our position to the government. Do not surrender what we are fighting forâour liberties, our values. Go forth with a bill that both sides of this parliament can agree with. I commend the amendments from the Senate. I commend members of the government who sat on the committees, who judged the terrorism bills on their merit and who support, in their reports and in what they have signed off on, all the amendments that the Labor Party is insisting on.

talk.start.para: âThis country needs the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002. It needs a bill that will ensure that we have in the coming weeks and months the capacity to allow our intelligence agencies to do the very best they can in securing information from people in the community who may have a vague understanding, or even a more substantial understanding, of actions intended here or elsewhere that will take the lives of our citizens or the citizens of other countries. The bill is needed. It will not be a satisfactory outcome if we walk away at the conclusion of these proceedings without such an act.

speech.para: The Attorney-General got one thing right when he said that the Labor Party had shifted ground. Yes, we have. Many of us started off with an assumption that if these powers were to reside anywhere, they ought to reside in respect of the fully accountable and knownâin terms of the names and positionsâparticular individuals concerned in the police force. Those powers ought properly to reside with them, just as some equivalent of them resides with the New South Wales Police force, which has other strands of accountability attached to it.

We took the view that ASIO was a different sort of body and that the powers of detention, the powers of compulsory questioning and the powers, ultimately, to charge people with a failure to answer those questions and be jailed ought not properly reside within an organisation devised for different purposes. We have changed on that. We have attempted to move to the government's position so that we can get an outcome for the Australian people. That is why we have moved on thisânot because we have been confused in our objectives. Our objectives all along have been to achieve an outcome that ensures that there is some questioning of those who may have knowledge of possible terrorist acts in order that those acts may be prevented or we get the best possible particulars and information about them. That is why we have shifted. It is a reasonable thing for us to see you shift as well.

I think it is the profound conviction on this side of the House that the government do not move because they see a political advantage in not doing so. If that is the government's motive, their judgment in those areas is beginning to be shaky. Their judgment in political terms may well have been excellent in the latter parts of last year, but there is recent evidence around that if that is the motiveâa willingness to sacrifice Australian interests for political interestâit is no longer paying off as it has in the past. We witnessed that terribly last week when statements were made by the Prime Minister in regard to pre-emptive strikes, which had a major damaging effect on our capacity to mobilise the coalition we need to mobilise. Amongst the Muslim states or states with substantial Muslim minorities in our immediate region it was an ill-judged statement. I do not think that it did the Prime Minister any good, I do not think that it did the Liberal Party any good and we know for sure that it did not do the country any good. The same applies here.

Frankly, Minister, the public will not understand the differences between us. We stand here for a regime that will ensure that people can be questioned for 20 hours. In the way in which that is framed, that effectively means two to three days detention while that questioning is done. We have put forward amendments to the bill which have been carried by the Senate which ensure legal representation. You say that yours ensures legal representation as well. They will not understand the difference between us. I could go through virtually every single item of the regime. You can say the same: `Look, we do that.' We say, `We do it this way.' Frankly, there is going to be no political advantage to any particular side in the collapse of this legislation at the end of the day, though some may think there will be. There will be none. But I tell you what there will be if this bill does not go through. If this bill does not go through, an opportunity which is available to Australian security services, but not to those of our principal ally, will be lost. An essential additional component of the powers of ASIO will disappear. There will be plenty of blame to go around when that occurs, but the essence of what is needed will not take place. That essential protection will not be put in place. There will be no political gains, but there will be major security losses for the ordinary Australian. (Extension of time granted)

There is a negotiatorâthat is, Senator Faulknerâwho is authorised by the Leader of the Opposition to negotiate on the part of the Labor Party. We have had conversations. I do not want to go into the internal detail of those conversations; that would be improper. We are still interested in arriving at a position that is sensible on one particular item, as the Attorney-General knows. He has expressed concern about disallowable instruments. Senator Faulkner has indicated to him that, if something else appropriate can be put in place, he is prepared to give consideration to that. That is the bottom line. If the Attorney-General accepts that, he may not necessarily have the unanimous support of the parliament, because there are parties that do not agree with this proposition, but he will have the support of the opposition. He will have the combined support of the government and the opposition to see that this legislation goes through and gets put in place.

I appeal to the Attorney-General to rethink his position, to comprehend the extent to which we have made substantial compromises on matters of principle and direction. But there are some fundamental principles that will not be compromised. We have some fundamental concerns that we will not budge on, and they relate to the detention of children who are not suspects. That is not acceptable. As far as we are concerned, we cannot approach that situation. As for the rest of it, frankly, the regime that we put forward has additional protections that the government's does not. Those protections do not render it ineffectiveânot at all. If the Attorney-General remains convinced that they do, there is no harm, because the original legislation which was before us will not get through.

At least give this a chance to work. The Australian people need it. The Australian people are owed it. Our contemporary circumstances require it. There will in the end be no particular political advantage in us ripping each other up on this issue on the hustings. The public will see us basically in `screaming agreement' and wonder what the heck we are talking about. In those circumstances, I ask you, Attorney-General, to go away and think again. You have about half an hour before this gets back into the Senate. You have already had that conversation, as I suggested, with Senator Faulkner. I suggest that you have another one and see what you can come up with.
