debateinfo.title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT (PREGNANCY AND WORK) BILL 2002

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: âThe original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Barton has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

âI am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on this amendment to the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002 today. Every day, when I walk through the front door of my office here in Parliament House, I look at a very large photograph, which takes up most of the wall in the foyer of my office. The caption underneath it says, `Feel the power'. It is a very special and memorable photo because in 1996 the largest number of women ever were elected to the parliament on the coalition side. They numbered 25, and 25 of those women are featured in this photo. When you examine it carefully, you see that most of those women are still in the parliament and that three-quarters of them are or have been senior office holders. Four are currently serving as ministers, one in cabinet; three are former ministers; one is a government whip in this House; one is a Senate whip; and one is the retiring former President of the Senate, Margaret Reid. There is a former government whip, and there are six parliamentary secretaries and one retired parliamentary secretary. There are also many chairs of committees in that group of women.

speech.para: One of the most noticeable features of the increase in the number of women in parliament on both sides is the number of young women who have successfully combined pregnancy and motherhood with their work in the parliament and in their electorates. I highlight this because it is a wonderful example of women who work in a very demanding environment being very effective representatives and combining pregnancy and child rearing with their careers. Tonight, a lot of us have been going about our work for about 24 hours. We have had a young woman here in the chamber over the course of this night: Jackie Kelly, a parliamentary secretary and the member for Lindsay. She is a very good example of somebody who has had, and continues to have, a very successful career as a member of parliament and yet, over the course of her service to this parliament thus far, she has had and is raising two young children. I think that is a wonderful inspiration for many women, and for many young women in particular.

The fact that we have to have legislation to protect women with respect to the subject of this bill, which is pregnancy and work, demonstrates that we still have a very long way to go to change some people's perception of the ability and suitability of pregnant women to take part in the work force.

It has been 15 years since the Sex Discrimination Act was introduced, and it is evident that the operation of the act in relation to pregnant and potentially pregnant women is still not well understood. I have to say that black-letter law is always very helpful in bringing about change but, in itself, it does not. I know that the member for Fowler was very critical of aspects of this amendment, yet I think that it is practical. It goes to the heart of the problem. It is about changing people's perception. That means educating, encouraging. It is not one of those things where you can jackboot people into making the mental shifts that are necessary if we are going to move ahead on this issue.

There are few exceptions where pregnant women or women likely to become pregnant could be put at risk. That is an old argument that has been put for many years. In fact, we saw the member for Lindsay, when she was Minister for Sport and Tourism, argue this case for women in the sporting arena in the very public dispute over women netballers. We have had a lot of discussion about whether it is safe for women to work in certain occupations when they are pregnant, and I think that it has been demonstrated that there are very few jobs that women cannot do and very few activities that women cannot participate in when they are pregnant. This bill makes provision for employers to take this into account without any risk of breach of sex discriminationâthat is, the odd occasion, the odd exception, is allowed for, but there are very few of those.

This amendment had its origins in a report to government in 1999, the report of the national pregnancy and work inquiry, entitled Pregnant and productive: it's a right not a privilege to work while pregnant. We have come a long way since the days when women were discriminated against in the work force because they married. That was something that was very common when I was a young woman and about to enter the work force. We all knew that we were only there, in some sectors of business and in the Public Service, as long as we remained single. The Public Service and many private organisations and companies had a policy of women not being able to return to their jobs once they were marriedâand certainly not when they were pregnant. However, the level of complaints in relation to pregnant and potentially pregnant women is still high, indicating that there remain cultural and attitudinal problems in respect of this matter.

In light of the level of complaints, the Commonwealth Attorney-General, the Hon. Daryl Williams, referred this national inquiry to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission under the auspices of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 in August 1998. The act provides the framework for the investigation and conciliation of complaints of unlawful acts of discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status, pregnancy, potential pregnancy, sexual harassment and dismissal on the grounds of family responsibilities. The reason for the inquiry was that, in the calendar year 1997, 14.7 per cent of all complaints accepted under the Sex Discrimination Act that proceeded to conciliation included an allegation of discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy. By May 1999, at the commencement of this inquiry, that figure had risen to 17.4 per cent. Discrimination was evident across all employer groups, including private and public sector workplaces. This was the first national inquiry into pregnancy and potential pregnancy discrimination in the workplace.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission consulted widely with individuals, employees, employers, employer organisations, trade unions and others. I think it is enormously important that wide-ranging consultations take place so that we can get the best idea of what is going on in the workplace and how we can best put some proposals together to stop that practice. Anecdotal evidence indicated that discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy and potential pregnancy was much higher than the official figures. Many cases were mediated by parties other than HREOC and were therefore not included in the official complaints figures.

As a participant in the UN women's conference in Beijing in 1997, I became acutely aware of the level of discrimination against women in the workplace across the world. It is an international problem. Under the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, the foundation principle is that discrimination against women violates the principles of equality of rights and respect for human dignity. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men in the political, social, economic and cultural life of their countries. It hampers the growth of prosperity of society and the family, and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of their countries and humanity. Australia is a signatory and has obligations under that convention. These obligations involve governments ensuring that they do what they can to eliminate the prejudices and the customs that give rise to a notion that women are inferior to men.

I was pleased recently to be a guest of the Chinese government and the China Society for Human Rights Study to talk about issues of human rights. People representing far continents were there, and we talked about what are human rights. Human rights are about human dignity. It is important for women and men, in fact, to have the dignity that comes from having a place in the work force. We discussed how sometimes customs and cultural backgrounds can be an impediment to providing real human rights and not stripping people of their dignity. Sometimes the prejudices are hidden behind what some people see as customs and culture. That is unfortunate because it is very difficult then for people to move forward and to allow others to have dignity.

Going back to the national pregnancy and work inquiry report, I was pleased to read the comments of the Queensland Chamber of Commerce and Industry. We have been in this place for a long time and I do not recall it being mentioned, but one of the earlier speakers on this bill tonight was rather critical of the business sector in relation to women in the work force. It was raised in the context of paid maternity leave. To balance that and to be fair, yes, there are some employers and employer groups who are sometimes not terribly supportive of making it easier for women to enter the work force and to balance family responsibilities with their paid work. On the other hand, as I said, I was pleased to read the comments of the Queensland Chamber of Commerce and Industry in their submission to the inquiry. I had something to do with the Queensland chamber when I was shadow minister for women and, later, minister for women. In their submission they said:

quote.para: As Australian businesses expand both nationally and internationally, there has been a need for companies to be more competitive. Being competitive does not mean just from an economic perspective but also in terms of how the company is perceived. ... By adopting family friendly policies and complying with legislative requirements with respect to discrimination, businesses are indicating the importance of these issues. ... It is important to businesses, especially on an international level to show that they are complying with these Conventions, not just for their own public image reasons.

speech.para: So, to be fair, many business leaders and businesses in our country are very supportive of making it easier for women to juggle their paid work and family responsibilities. The Queensland Chamber of Commerce and Industry gave good reasons why providing equal opportunity in the workplace for men and women makes good economic sense.

In responding to the report, the government expressed its preference for a policy of education, guidance and raising awareness as the most effective way to promote the protection of the rights of individuals and equality of opportunity. The member for Fowler was somewhat critical. I do not think that is justified, because the government response to this has been to ensure that there is development and distribution of pregnancy guidelines by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. It is enormously important that we try to work closely with employers to ensure that they understand what is required of them. This makes it much easier for them to move forward and it can avoid protracted legal cases, which are not always useful.

The government has proposed these amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act to clarify that discrimination on the grounds of breastfeeding is prohibited, as is asking questions about pregnancy or potential pregnancy at job interviews, and that information about pregnancy gathered from medical examinations may not be used for discriminatory purposes. Finally, a very important part of what the government is trying to achieve with these amendments is to make occupational health and safety information relating to pregnancy available to the public to raise awareness in the workplace. A lot of the measures in the amendments to this bill are very sensible, and they will help a great deal with some of the problems that have become evident in this report.

As some of my colleagues have already highlighted, prejudice against pregnancy in the workplace is just one of many challenges for governments and the community to deal with. There is also a vigorous debate taking place about the merits of introducing paid maternity leave. One of the critical issues for women wanting to raise a family and to continue in the work force is the availability of high quality affordable child care, including care outside school hours. I was interested to listen to the speech given by my good colleague the member for Petrie on the amendment to this bill today because she raised some issues about child care. I know that, as I have, she has had the experience of juggling work and family responsibilities without always having the support of a partner.

It is difficult for many women. Narrowing the solution down to a maternity leave allowance for 14 weeks, or some other period, will not really solve the bigger problem for many women and families who are trying to juggle work and family responsibilities. This debate needs to be wider than it currently is and to take in this issue of child careânot just for children who are very young but also for children who are going to school. We need to make sure high quality outside school hours care is available and affordable. That is critical to women being able to continue moving forward in their careers in the paid work force while juggling this with the important role of raising a family.

Many schemes have been discussed over the years and there have been many debates on how to achieve a balance between work and family responsibilities. It is something that Mr Howard recognised when he first came into this place as Prime Minister. I remember launching our policies and hearing him talk with considerable understanding about the tension that exists in balancing work and family responsibilities. Any of us who have gone through that experience know that he is absolutely right: there is a tension there. It is the challenge of the 21st century to ensure that we can balance the work and family responsibilities of men and women.

But that is a debate for another day. We are here now to discuss the amendment to the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002. It will clarify provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act that protect pregnant, potentially pregnant and breastfeeding women from discrimination. The Attorney has introduced this bill. He introduced it in September 2001, however, when the last election was called, and the bill lapsed. I am very pleased to see it returned to this chamber for debate. I am sure that all of the women in this place, and certainly the women in the community, will be very pleased when the bill is passed.

talk.start.para: âI hope my voice holds for the time that is available to contribute to this debate on the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002. It is an incredibly important debate. The member for Pearce is absolutely right to argue that we need to see the dynamics of the work and family interrelationship in a much broader context. That is one of the reservations I have about the bill that has come before us: in my judgment it is a very limited, narrow and inadequate response to what was really quite a significant national report. Due credit must be given to the then Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Susan Halliday, who did a great job consulting with people, recording real life experiences and making, in all, about 46 recommendations, of which only three have been picked up by the government in the bill before us.

speech.para: A lot of women were concerned about the length of time that it took from the presentation of the report to the Attorney-General back in June 1999 to the parliament actually giving full and proper consideration to the issues contained within it. In essence, the report found that erroneous tactics and exploitative practices were continuing, despite the advances that we all thought we had made in this area, and that these practices were being utilised to remove pregnant women from the workplace or to deny pregnant or potentially pregnant women access to equal employment opportunities.

I was fortunate enough to be at the launch of the report. Some of the case studies in the report were quite horrific. I have been lucky enough to work in situations where both direct and indirect practices of discrimination, by and large, had been eliminated. But she did refer to cases, for example, where women miscarried because they were not allowed to sit down at work, where men were sacked for attending their baby's birth, and where women were harassed about their appearance or removed from front desk work. In one very horrendous caseâreferred to earlier this evening by the member for Bartonâa woman working in a car factory was denied a chair despite the fact that she was bleeding and in severe pain. She collapsed at work when she was seven months pregnant, and the baby was born prematurely with an underdeveloped heart.

It was quite shocking to read these case studies and to comprehend the fact that, even though we thought at the theoretical level that things had really improved for women, for many womenâparticularly in the blue-collar areasâlife had changed very little. The rhetoric of equal employment opportunity had not in reality made their working lives and conditions that much better. To that extent it is disturbing that the government appear to lots of women to be sitting on their hands and not properly responding to the breadth of the issues and the diversity of the recommendations made in that report.

I think the bill is a totally inadequate response. It has only taken up three of the 40-odd recommendations. The ones that have been picked up by the government really only go to the clarification of existing provisions of the act. They concern the asking of questions about pregnancy or potential pregnancy, the use of pregnancy related medical information and whether breastfeeding is grounds for discrimination on the basis of sex. The minister, in his second reading speech, said the following, and this confirms what I believe are the limitations of the response:

quote.para: ... the bill does not expand the operation of the act, but greatly improves, simplifies and clarifies important provisions of the act that provide protection from unlawful discrimination for pregnant, potentially pregnant and breastfeeding women.

speech.para: Of course, the Labor response is to welcome those developments, although we see them as inadequate. I think that the amendments that have been moved by the member for Barton pick up a number of significant and glaring omissions in the government's to date limited response. I am hoping that the minister will give serious consideration to the range of amendments that we have proposed.
I want to take the opportunity in the time that I have to refute the statement made by the minister in his second reading speech, in which he argued:

quote.para: Once again, practical and concrete steps are being taken by this government to remove sex based workplace discrimination and to improve the lives of working women ...

speech.para: We find a lot of generalised statements being made by this government about their alleged understanding and empathy with the issues that confront women at work and a perception that they are really involved in trying to do something meaningful about the work and family interface. I want to argue that the rhetoric and the reality for women and for menâbut predominantly for women, who continue to bear the major responsibility for family and childrenâare in fact miles apart.

Whilst the government have been sitting on this report and failing to respond, the numbers of women who continue to make complaints to HREOC, claiming discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy, has jumped by almost 150 per cent. The number of women, according to the annual report, making formal complaints soared from 86 in 2000-01 to 212 in 2001-02. Pregnancy discrimination has jumped from 16 per cent of previous sex discrimination cases to 30 per cent this year. That is probably a good thing, because it means people are more intent on asserting their rights under the law and seeking redress.

I want to give you a couple of examples of what continues to occur in our workplaces and about which the government is saying or doing very little. I cite a recent article in the Daily Telegraph where a couple of case studies were given. A clerk claimed she was told by her supervisor to have an abortion after finding out she was pregnant soon after joining a real estate firm. She insisted she did not know she was pregnant when she took the job. She refused to have an abortion and was sacked. After conciliation, she was reinstated and paid $4,000 in damages. A casual worker with a government department was told she could not breastfeed or express milk at work, or take her baby to the office. After conciliation, the department changed its policy and paid her $1,200. An import and wholesale company refused to provide a full-time administrative assistant with light duties, insisting she carry on lifting and carrying, despite doctor's orders. She received $9,000 after conciliation. The point I am making is that the horrific stories that were first revealed by Susan Halliday in that really wonderful report continue to occur, and this is three or four years after her initial report. Things are not improving out there in the real world where discrimination on the grounds of sex and on the grounds of pregnancy appears to be continuing unabated.

We hear a lot of rhetoric from the government regarding the balance between work and family life. I think the member for Pearce was absolutely right in that the bill that we are looking atâand hopefully the amendments that the government will see fit to supportâare very restricted. We need to focusâand I am very confident that our party will in the new yearâon the kind of broad dimensions of that interface between work and family life.

I am pleased that the Prime Minister appears to have become a latter-day convert to feminism. I had always thought that his views of the world were very much predicated on the stereotype of the family behind the white picket fence, but his recent comments in this House give me some hope that perhaps attitudes are changing. They need to change very quickly because our society is changing very quickly. The proportion of couples with children where both partners work has risen from 44 per cent just a couple of decades ago to 62 per cent of the work force in 2000. So 62 per cent of couples who have children are in the work force. This figure really surprised me: more than halfâ51.3 per centâof new mothers in two-parent families are back at work when the child is between one and two years of age.

Two decades ago you probably could have argued that most women returned to work when the child was around preschool age, four or five; but the pattern now is one where large numbers of women return to work when the child reaches the age of one or two. I guess a lot of these younger women are part of generation X, which does not want to make a choice between family and career but wants to have society cope with their aspirations to combine the best of both. There are lots of women who want the option of having a career and children, and the statistics indicate that a lot of them are doing it with virtually no time off from their careers and no time at home in the early periods of their children's development.

I was disappointed but not really surprised to hear what the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations said on a recent Sunday program. It reinforced a lot of things that the minister is prone to generalise about. In reference to a question he was asked about the issue of work and family life and maternity leave, he said something to the effect: `Yes, it is an issue but it is an issue that really has to be determined by individuals. Governments cannot legislate one-size-fits-all.' On this side of the chamber we agree that governments cannot provide `one size fits all' solutions, but governments are here, surely, to make a difference to the standard of living and the quality of life of the people we are elected to represent.

I think it is a total cop-out to transfer the onus for balancing work and family life onto individuals as if we, as people who legislate on their behalf, cannot do things that can make a material and significant improvement to that very important balance. As we all know, the difficulties for women are many. There are a growing number of difficulties because many women are precariously employed, and if you are a casual worker or a worker on an individual contract of employment you really have no bargaining power to effect family friendly policies at your workplace. A recent article that was prepared by our shadow minister for workplace relations pointed to the fact that under this government, despite the rhetoric of their so-called commitment to the balance, even where there were collective agreementsâassuming some level of union involvement, or at least that the work force was organised and women had some chanceâwomen were going backwards. So it was not just those who were precariously employed but often workers with secure employment, covered by collective agreements, who were finding their conditions deteriorating and not improving.

I would like to go to a couple of examples of the work that has been undertaken by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations. The work showed in fact that, under this government, there has been a decrease in the percentage of collective agreements containing flexible starting and finishing times, a decrease in the percentage of collective agreements providing for family and carer's leave, a decrease in the percentage of collective agreements providing for paid maternity leave, a decrease in the percentage of collective agreements providing for home based work, and no growth in the percentage of collective agreements containing flexible annual leave, paid family leave, regular part-time work or family responsibility provisions and child-care provisions. What it found was that, as we all know, there had been an explosion in the percentage of collective agreements providing for insecure forms of employment such as contract labour and casual labour.

When this government goes around expressing and professing sympathy and commitment to family friendly policies, with people believing that they understand the importance of work and family interface, then I think these people would do well to look beyond the cloak of the rhetoric and see what is actually occurring under this government, because the picture is one of regression and not one of progress. In that context, I think it is important to draw on the government's own reports and evidence to support our contention that the government needs to move at a much faster rate to make the kind of necessary adjustments and provide the supportive environment and frameworks so that working peopleâthe two-income couples, with both people in the work force, that are now the normâcan access family friendly arrangements and make their lives easier to balance.

With those general remarks, I want to commend the amendments that have been prepared by our shadow ministers. I think they do what the member for Pearce was urgingâthat is, to see the whole debate in a much broader context. I am very disappointed with the government's response. As the member for Fowler described it, we had a very pregnant pause while waiting for the bill to come before this chamber. I think the bill is very narrowâit is very restricted and limited.

I also wanted to take this opportunity to put on the public record the views of many women in Australia who would want to commend the former Sex Discrimination Commissioner for the groundbreaking work that she did. I think we all marvelled at the fact that a woman appointed under the Howard government to that very important position was able to bring these very serious issues of concern to the public's attention. I regret very much that the Attorney-General and the government did not see their way clear to renew her tenure in that position, because I think she would have continued to make very significant contributions to public policy about very important issues that confront each and every one of us when we go back to our electorates. In conclusionâand I am glad my voice has held upâI ask the government to give serious consideration to the very sensible amendments that have been moved by our shadow minister, amendments that pick up a lot of the recommendations where the bill is found wanting in terms of the proposals that would give true expression to a very significant piece of work undertaken by HREOC.

talk.start.para: âWhilst I rise in support of the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002, like the member for Throsby I am disappointed that the bill goes nowhere near far enough. The bill amends the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to implement only three of the 46 recommendations made by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report, Pregnant and productive: it's a right not a privilege to work while pregnant. The amendments in this bill clarify three areas: whether discrimination against breastfeeding women is a ground of sex discrimination; the asking of questions about pregnancy or potential pregnancy during job interviews; and the use of information obtained in medical examinations.

speech.para: The length of time the government has taken to adopt these recommendations is an indication of what little regard it has for women in the paid work force. The HREOC report was released in August 2000. The government responded to the recommendations in November 2000. But here we are, almost two years later, finally trying to implement only three of the 12 recommendations to amend the Sex Discrimination Act. The amendments contained in the pregnancy at work bill are welcome but they do not go far enough nor address the entirety of the report.

One of the key premises of the HREOC report is that post pregnancy issues, such as breastfeeding, are central to sex discrimination. In their submission to the HREOC inquiry, the Women's Electoral Lobby said:

quote.para: Pregnancy is a workplace issue that starts well before conception and ends long after birth. It is impossible to separate pregnancy and family responsibilities.

speech.para: The fact that this bill does not amend the Sex Discrimination Act to cover breastfeeding as a ground of unlawful discrimination is extremely disappointing.

The government's position is in stark contrast to Labor's. We have moved amendments to cover breastfeeding as a ground of unlawful discrimination as well as having previously introduced a private member's bill to this effect. You have to ask: what is the government's problem here? It is that it has a limited understanding of the lives of women. In relation to women in the paid work force, the government has dismissed the importance of paid maternity leave, calling it `middle class welfare'; taken no action on the specific disadvantage faced by women in accumulating superannuation; and ignored the chronic shortage of child-care places in outer urban and regional cities such as in my electorate, Ballarat.

I was very pleased to hear the member for Pearce raise the issue of child care in the context of this debate. I must admit I was somewhat surprised that she raised this issue, given that day after day in question time we hear the minister responsible saying what a fantastic job this government has done with child care and out of school hours care. The issue of access to affordable child care is one that we feel very deeply about in my electorate. We have over 100 families on child-care waiting lists, and many women and men are unable to accept positions and participate fully in the community because they cannot access child careâboth long day care and out of school hours care. The government has consistently refused to do anything about this and fails women and families on these issues.

I take this opportunity to examine why the legislation is necessary in the first place. According to HREOC, 18 per cent of complaints received by them in the years 1999 to 2000 concerned alleged discrimination on the basis of pregnancy or potential pregnancy. We heard from the member for Throsby that it looks like this percentage has increased in the intervening period. These figures are only the tip of the iceberg, as many complaints simply go unreported. Consultations during the commission's inquiry into pregnancy and work showed that harassment and inappropriate behaviour towards pregnant employees were not uncommon. According to the commission, discrimination included: constant references to the pregnancy, touching of employees' stomachs, badgering about the ability to cope with the workload, or constant questioning of pregnant employees about whether they really intended to return to work.

The discrimination was often subtle and not ill intentioned. But the consistent message from pregnant employees was that they found it demeaning, and it made it difficult for them to feel valued in their work environment while pregnant. They felt they did not receive equal treatment in relation to recruitment and promotion processes. According to the commission, 54 per cent of women in one study believed that their careers had been affected by taking maternity leave, a further 44.1 percent said their salaries had stalled, 34 per cent believed their careers had taken a backward step and 29.9 per cent said they had sacrificed their careers to give birth.

There appears to be a comparatively low awareness of pregnancy discrimination laws in comparison to antidiscrimination laws. The commission's development of pregnancy guidelines was a welcome step towards assisting employers and employees to develop a more family-friendly workplace. Figures from 1999 saw 3.8 million women employed and 257,394 live births recorded in Australia. The average age of women at the birth of their first child was 27.1 years, which is also the age of greatest career progression and when women are entering their prime earning years. Increasing numbers of women are putting off having children, in many cases due to work pressures and the expectation that women will have the primary role in child care. Families, and particularly women, have increasingly complex lives. Women are managing family responsibilities and paid work, they are often caring for older family members, they are heavily involved in their children's schooling and they participate in a broad range of community activities. For many women in my electorate, child-care arrangements alone are a logistic nightmare.

Governments need to understand that the current low fertility rate and the decisions women are taking to put off having children indicate a growing trend by women to make a choice between work and family rather than to seek both. HREOC argues that such choices are still necessary because of the failure of workplace practices to accommodate the realities of pregnancy and family responsibilities. It is for this reason that Labor have committed to paid maternity leave as one plank of balancing work and family policy. We are extremely conscious that any such plan must not place an impost on small business, but it is a policy whose time has well and truly come. So important is this issue that motherInc has conducted a widespread community survey on www.motherInc.com.au to keep the issue of paid maternity leave on the national agenda. Recommendations 44, 45 and 46 of the commission's report relate to paid maternity leave. The report recommended that the government undertake economic modelling and analysis of paid maternity leave options, and called on the government to encourage broad debate. I am very pleased to see Pru Goward reporting this week on paid maternity leave. It took us a while, but we are getting there.

The government has given mixed signals on paid maternity leave and seems to view it as an exclusive benefit for women who work in large companies and government departments, but women who work in small to medium enterprises and in low-paid and casual jobs can basically go hang. The government's only answer to family policy has been the baby bonus, which, as women are now discovering as they try to access it, is minimal and skewed towards women on higher incomes. The Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002 addresses some of the problems pregnant employees experience. However, I again highlight the comments of many of the groups who participated in the pregnancy and work inquiry: pregnancy is a workplace issue that starts well before conception and continues well after the birth of a child. The issue of access to child-care places is critical to balancing family and work. I reiterate comments made in my first speech to this parliament when I said that the government's market based child-care policies are not working in outer metropolitan and regional Australia, and the government must act urgently to address the situation. In conclusion, while I support the amendments contained in the bill, the government should support all the changes to the law and take other actions to give effect to the full recommendations of the HREOC report Pregnant and productive: it's a right not a privilege to work while pregnant.

talk.start.para: âIn rising to speak on the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002, I have to say I never believed I or my colleagues would be here, in the House, for so long. In my case it has been 25Â¼ hours since I walked inâand we are still going in debate with the House not stopping. Nevertheless, I welcome the bill before the House because I believe it is thoroughly overdue. This legislation is a step in the right direction, but we as legislators must be forceful in our endeavours to create a society that accepts that it is now a given that women can work if they choose as well as have children and raise a family.

speech.para: Legislation which protects pregnant women from discrimination is long overdue. The government should have given this legislation the priority it deserves rather than delayed it to such a late time in the parliamentary cycle. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report Pregnant and Productive: it's a right not a privilege to work while pregnant has been published and on the public record for a number of years. The HREOC report identified three areas of sex discrimination in the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 which were not clearly identified by employers and employees and which required clarification, and this legislation attempts to address that. The areas referred to by HREOC relate to whether discrimination against breastfeeding women is a ground for sex discrimination, the asking of questions about pregnancy or potential pregnancy during job interviews and the use of information obtained in medical examinations. The HREOC report recommended that the act be amended to clarify the points raised, hence the debate we are now having on this legislation.

It is completely unacceptable in the 21st century that there is evidence which suggests that women who are pregnant or considering having children will suffer disadvantage and discrimination in our society. Women in Australia have fought many long and hard battles to overcome the barriers which prevented them from having equal status in Australian society. Historically, Australia has been the leading advocate for women's rights. We were one of the first countries to provide women with the right to vote. Notably, South Australia provided their women with the right to vote in the late 19th century. We were one of the first countries to enable women to run for public office, with Dorothy Tangney and Edith Cowan notable pioneers. In New South Wales, men had a propensity to dominate the political spectrum, for it took over 130 years before a woman became a minister in that stateâand I know what I am talking about because I was that woman.

The Sex Discrimination Act 1984, which was legislated by the Hawke Labor government, is the benchmark regarding the legislating against discriminatory practices in Australia. However, the HREOC report made a number of recommendations to further strengthen it in an attempt to prevent the still widespread discrimination against women in the workplace. It is pertinent to ask why the government has decided not to implement all the recommendations of the HREOC report.

Let us look at the recommendations that the government will not implement. They are numerous. I would like to mention just a few of them, because I believe they are very important and that they should have been included in this bill. Those I was concerned about that have not been mentioned would empower HREOC to publish enforceable standards in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy, and would ensure coverage of unpaid workers. They would ensure that the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations specifically consider the position of pregnant and potentially pregnant employees in any future workplace relations reform, to ensure that such employees are not exposed to the possibility of direct or indirect discrimination, and that the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations and the Office of the Employment Advocate ensure information is available to all workplace participants in relation to their rights and responsibilities in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy pursuant to the Workplace Relations Act 1996 awards. Also, in relation to making certified agreements or Australian Workplace Agreements, the Office of the Employment Advocate would be required to collect and regularly publish information about the provisions in AWAs concerning pregnancy and maternity issues, and the Sex Discrimination Commissioner would be able to refer discriminatory awards or agreements to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission on their own initiative.

They are not what I would describe, from reading just a few of those, as hard amendments to implement. Yet the government has not attempted to do that in this legislation. Those I have mentioned are just some of the 46 recommendations of the report. However, this legislation embraces only three. This is a very tepid approach to improving the rights of women to have careers and to even think about starting a family at the same time. What this government does not understand is that this is a fundamental human right. The recommendations I quoted would go at least some of the way to changing the culture in the workplace that discriminates against women and their families, but we know a number of the ministers in the government feel no compunction to change this culture. I note that only one of our male counterparts has taken part in this debate.

Another example I have championed for a number of years is the government's refusal to sign the optional protocol to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Womenâor CEDAW, as we refer to it. I have previously spoken in this House to deplore the government's contemptuous approach to this vital element in improving the human rights of women by strengthening international law. I would also like to state that I have asked the minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Womenâin fact, it is question No. 1156 on the Notice Paperâwhy the government still refuses to sign the optional protocol, considering that 75 states have now signed and, of those, 47 have ratified it. I also note that the government has not been a member of the UN Commission on the Status of Women since 1996. This is in stark contrast to the activist role the Hawke and Keating governments played in that commission.

Signing the optional protocol would have been a gesture to confirm that Australia is indeed a country with an undeniable and firm commitment to the rejection of all forms of discrimination against women, wherever and whenever they occur. Instead, the government refuses to sign for, I suspect, no more valid reason than to pander to the interests of the far Right and hence undermine the functions of the United Nations. During the 13 years Labor was in power, from 1983 to 1996, Australia developed a reputation as a leader in the areas of antidiscrimination and human rights. This was particularly due to the active diplomatic agenda of Gareth Evans. Australia signed and ratified CEDAW, and in 1995 the Keating government was active in negotiations to create the optional protocol the Howard government now refuses to sign. I believe the government's refusal to support women's rights on the international stage and this rather flimsy attempt we have before us to improve discrimination provisions show quite explicitly that, regardless of its rhetoric about supporting families and enunciating polices that are pro-family, the government has absolutely nothing to back up that rhetoric.

Paid maternity leave is something that the Labor party supports and that the government has dithered over. The Prime Minister, we know, is against the proposal but is playing a game of public relations semantics at the moment, designed to placate some of his would-be loyal constituents on this issue. We remain the only party in the House with a firm commitment to universal paid maternity leave and we intend to create a partnership with business, unions and the community to determine a funding model. Labor has made exceptions for small businesses in many of our policies. They include my private member's bill, which protects 100 per cent of workers' entitlements, introduced now for the fifth time. Unlike the government's scheme it makes a firm commitment to protecting 100 per cent of our workers' entitlements, and that certainly includes our women workers.

Protection of workers' entitlements is something the workers of Australia are waiting to see, and the women of Australia are waiting for a government that is genuinely committed to enforcing the right of women to work and have a family. The Labor Party has always prided itself on being a reformist party, and this area of socioeconomic policy is crying out for somebody to take the bull by the horns and bring the current mentality into the 21st century. One business has been quite groundbreaking in its policy towards paid maternity leave: Westpac. As reported in the Australian on 10 May 2002, Westpac introduced paid maternity leave in 1995. At that time the retention rate of female employees was 54 per cent. By 2000 the retention rate at Westpac had increased to 93 per cent. In other words, the rate had almost doubled. This is a success story. It shows that businessâif it is, firstly, socially responsible and, secondly, business savvyâcan incorporate paid maternity leave and ensure the business is able to grow.

Conversely, I know of a case involving another large financial institution. I will not name them here, but I can if that is requested. A senior female employee, who had been highly successful and beneficial to the company, went on the standard 12 weeks maternity leave. During that time she asked the company if she could return to work on a part-time basis, considering she had just had her second childâthe first was only a toddler. The type of work she did meant that quite a bit of it could have been done at home. The company decided to put the blowtorch onto her. Again, this was a women who had given a number of years of outstanding commitment and service, and who had risen through the ranks because of her talents and ability. She was now being pressured to return full-time or contemplate the alternative, which was, obviously, resignation. After she received outside advice on her rights the pressure was turned back on her employer and, fortunately for all involved, a compromise was reached. But why should talented women have to go through this because they have a family?

In another case I am aware ofâagain, I could reveal the detailsâa loyal and hardworking employee has been working in a multinational company for eight years, is now pregnant and is attempting to negotiate a package involving maternity leave. She has offered to do one day per week of work from home during that periodâwhich she now does on the weekends anywayâbut that is not good enough for the company. They appear to be absolutely flummoxed as to why one of their employees would even want to become pregnant. This is a case which occurred in today's Australia. There are countless cases of some form of discrimination or other against pregnant women in the workplace; and I will go to some more well-known cases on the public record later.

The day before yesterday, Pru Goward, the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, released a report titled A time to value: proposal for a national paid maternity leave scheme. In that report Ms Goward recommended that paid maternity leave be funded by the federal government and provided to women at the birth of a child. I note that Ms Goward also recommended that this apply to all women in paid work for 40 of the 52 weeks before the birth of the child, and that they receive $431 a week for 14 weeks. This amount is in line with the federal minimum wage. It is interesting that Ms Goward has recommended that paid maternity leave be for a duration of 14 weeks. Why I state this point is that the government has refused to ratify the revised Maternity Protection ConventionâILO No. 183âof June 2000, which calls for a minimum of 14 weeks paid maternity leave. So every OECD country has agreed to 14 weeks paid maternity leave, except Australia and the United States.

Again, this is an example of this government knowing of no other way than to follow, without question, whatever the United States does. I know the government believes that everything that comes out of the United States is gospel, but let us look at some of the problems that American women are having. Sylvia Ann Hewlett, in her article, `Executive Women and the Myth of Having It All' published in the Harvard Business Review, provides a very interesting synopsis on women, particularly successful professionals who are forced to make life choices. The disturbing point that Hewlett makes is that the typical female professional in midlife has `not made a choice but a creeping non-choice' to, firstly, not be able to find a partner due to the incredibly long hours they are forced to work to maintain their career and, secondlyâdue to thisâto have no children. According to Hewlett, this affects one-third of professional women in the 41 to 55 age bracket. This rises to 42 per cent in the corporate sector.

This example is from the United States but things are quite similar back home in Australia. An article in the Age by Jane Cadzow on 17 August 2002 illustrated a totally awful situation where a corporate lawyer in Sydney went through labour throughout a telephone conference with colleagues overseas. This conference began at 10 p.m.âan ungodly hour, I believe, to begin a meeting; but this is what is expected in the professional world, even when you are nine months pregnant. She gave birth to a daughter by emergency caesarean at 4:15 the next morning after taking a cab by herself to the hospital. Not once during the meeting did she let on to her colleagues the extreme discomfort that she was in for fear of being snubbed. Within hours of giving birth, she was asking her secretary to supply her with her emails; again, this was due to fear. This is a horrific example. To think that a woman in this day and age has to go through this just to maintain her career is something that society should be ashamed of.

If professional women have problems, what about workers that are in jobs at the lower end of the economic spectrum? These women are, arguably, less able to combat discriminative employers, and I would suggest that much harassment is not even reported. However, it would appear that the campaign maintained to educate women on their rights is showing some signsâI am pleased to sayâof getting through to our communities at large. According to a report in the Daily Telegraph of 29 October 2002, the number of women claiming that they have been discriminated against on the grounds of pregnancy has increased by nearly 150 per cent between the years 2000-01 and 2001-02. In terms of numbers, it went from 86 to 212. Again, I doubt that this is anywhere near the number of actual discriminatory events; however, it is a positive sign that women are becoming more aware of their rights and that some are being empowered to challenge discrimination.

Unfortunately, we still have a long battle to win when you have the barbaric example of a young clerk in a real estate firm being told, after she fell pregnant, that she should have an abortion. I cannot even believe that we have such low-lifes out there who are so callous that they would treat a human being in that way. The government appears quite prepared to protect people of such base mentality running a business, but it is not fully prepared to assist hardworking and honest young women to combine work and family life.

The government constantly espouses the rhetoric of being pro-family. Their record in this area and in other areas like child care prove the opposite. And public comments by leading ministers, including the Prime Minister, show that they are in no hurry to begin real reform and incorporate the Sex Discrimination Commissioner's and, might I add, Labor's proposal for paid maternity leave. The Prime Minister has stated in the near past that he is none too enthusiastic about the proposal for paid maternity leave. He stated on Melbourne radio station 3AW on 18 April 2002 that:

quote.para: If you are to impose it on employers, that will actually discriminate against some women because there could well be fewer women employees, no matter what sex discrimination laws might say because many small firms just won't be able to afford it.

speech.para: Is the Prime Minister condoning discrimination? I mean that is the essence of this government. It claims to be reformist but it does nothing to assist in areas where governments have a responsibility to be proactive and lead the community. Instead, the government is quite content to let the law of the jungle take precedence and, after some of the cases I have presented today, it is not just an analogy but an actuality. Other ministers, such as the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, have stated that there is no way that employers should pay, and his counterpart, Senator Minchin, refuses to countenance the proposal of the taxpayer funding paid maternity leave, claiming that it is `middle-class welfare'âa contemptuous do-nothing approach.

Labor have not indicated that businesses should solely foot the bill for paid maternity leave. We believe that it is a shared responsibility which we have made a commitment to achieving. What is required is for all stakeholdersâgovernment, business, unions and employeesâto join together to find a solution. That is the Labor way. We are an inclusive party, not divisive. This issue is absolutely fundamental to formulating a sensible population policy in this country. It is not just about immigration, it is also about creating a sustainable population growth at home.

We have heard much of the government's propaganda about creating a family friendly environment, particularly with its much trumpeted baby bonus; however, even that policy is aimed at assisting those who are in less need of assistance at the expense of low-income families. Treasury itself has warned that a plummeting birth rate is the most daunting social and economic challenge over the next half century. This is a challenge that most Western societies face; however, other than increasing immigration, other areas of population policy are rarely discussed. So I am glad that we are now in the midst of a vigorous and crucial public policy debate. We cannot dither on this. We have a responsibility to get this rightâand we in the Labor Party certainly intend to do so. We plan to give young families a spread of choices, but these must be spread right throughout the community from professional women to shop assistants and clerks.

The Australian economy cannot afford to lose or underutilise the skills, ideas and potential of Australian women because they want to start a family. Recently, the member for Parramatta commented that the reason the birthrate was falling was due to men failing to commit. It is another simplistic argument from a government that refuses to commit to real reform. Instead, the government refuses to countenance paid maternity leave, it will not sign the optional protocol to CEDAW or the updated Maternity Protection Convention. It pays lip-service to family friendly policies. These three amendments are welcome but they do not go far enough. Instead, here on this side of the House Labor is committed to working with all members of the community to formulate a population policy that is both economically responsible and socially caring. That is the Labor way. We will continue to fight for women's right to work and have a family.
Debate (on motion by Ms Gillard) adjourned.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr ANTHONY
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the House insists on disagreeing to amendments Nos 18, 22, 24, 37, 39, 40, 42, 43, 47, 49, 50, 54, 61, 63 to 65 and 74 to 77 insisted on by the Senate.

speech.para: Very briefly, I wish to say that the government are opposed to the measures put up by the Australian Labor Party. Indeed, we are very disappointed that they are jeopardising the whole Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill 2002, in which there are enormous benefits, particularly for those individuals who are disadvantaged, through our personal support programs, our working credit program and through our literacy, numeracy and language program. All of that is being jeopardised now by the recalcitrant view of the Australian Labor Party, particularly their view of being soft on compliance. It is rather ironic that it was the Australian Labor Party, particularly through Working Nation when they were last in power, who had a one-strike rule. It was a `one strike and you are out' rule. The actual compliance regime was far more severe. Indeed, in today's dollar terms the penalty would have been around $2,355 for a third activity test breach when the Australian Labor Party were in government.

We believe that the Labor Party are not genuine and serious about welfare reform. There are a lot of good measures, which I have mentioned, in this particular bill. We have made enormous changes over the eight months since the Pearce report so that the breach rate has actually dropped by about 30 per cent; we have introduced suspension payments, third breach waivers, clean slate provisions and a whole range of measures to assist those who are vulnerable or at risk. This has been a quite deliberate attempt by the government to ensure that there is a safety net for those who cannot help themselves but, by the same token, we are very firm on ensuring that there is compliance and that people do have to undertake their activity tests and administrative requirements. We do not believe that the proposals put forward by the Labor Party should be considered at all. Indeed, they send the wrong signal. What we are on about, of course, is proper work and activity requirements. On that measure, we do not accept the amendments put up by the Australian Labor Party and we disagree with them.

talk.start.para: âI rise to oppose the motion moved by the minister. The amendments that we have moved put some essential fairness into the social security system, fairness that has been missing under this government. This minister and Senator Vanstone have had a penalty system operating which is essentially a `shoot first, ask questions later' breaching system. This has resulted in hundreds of thousands of people being fined and, in many cases, being fined unjustly. Even the government have recognised that there is a problem in the system but they have not got the gumption to come into this House and introduce some fairness into the system. Is it any wonder that people in the community think that this is a government that is very strong in controlling the weak and very weak in controlling the strong?

speech.para: The other advantage of these amendments that we are moving relates not just to the fairness that we are putting into the system. We are also putting in measures which will enhance compliance, because we believe that people should be responsible in the social security system and that they do have a responsibility to contribute and participate. Indeed, one of the most extraordinary things about what is happening here today is that the government is refusing to pass the one beneficial measure in this bill that would actually reward work over welfare. How extraordinary for the government to come into the House today and refuse to pass their own measure. They refuse to pass the working credit, the only beneficial thought they have had in social security in seven years. Do you know where they got it from? They got it from the Australian Labor Party. They got it from us, because it is our policy. They got it from us, because we do believe in rewarding work over welfare.

What this government does, with the current penalty system and the structure of withdrawal of benefits and moneys earned, is very simple. The minister for employment over there says that unemployed people should work casually, they should take any work that they can get. Do you know what he does when they get it? He taxes them 80c in every additional dollar they earn over the threshold. That is why this government has created a welfare trap which is trapping many Australians on benefits. They want nothing more than to stand on their own two feet and to have their hard work rewarded, but they cannot do it because of the welfare trap and because of the punishing effective marginal tax rate of 80c in the dollar for every additional dollar earned.

That would be addressed in this bill through the working credit. The problem is that the government has come into the House today and refused to pass it. It has got to be one of the few occasions in the history of politics and public policy in this country where a government comes into the House and says, `We are not going to pass our own beneficial measure.' Why are they not going to pass it? I will tell you why they are not going to pass it. They want to hold the unemployed who work hard out there hostage. They want to hold them hostage, because they will not introduce greater fairness into the system. We are going to fight for fairness. We are going to fight for responsibility. We are going to fight for compliance. We are going to fight because we are committed to a system which does two things: one, it rewards work over welfare; and, two, it invests in the capacity of individuals so that they have the ability to stand on their own two feet. You can only do that if you enhance compliance and participation. Some of the measures that we have put forward here do that. They give the unemployed and others the incentive to comply and to participate in the system.

What we are getting from the government here today is what we have had for the last seven years. It is a continuance of the welfare trap, the punishment of those on low incomes, and the inability to recognise that if you invest in people then what you will get is a much healthier and wealthier community. This action this morning is simply the action of a government that does not believe in investing in people. It is a government that has cut gaping holes in the social security safety net in recent times. It is a government that has attempted to cut the pensions of disability support pensioners by $52 a fortnight. When it comes to actually adhering to the one beneficial measure that they have put forward in seven years, they have decided to junk it, because they have had a fit about the fact that Labor is intent on introducing fairness into the system. (Time expired)
